question: What is the potential complexation capacity of TripolyP and how quickly does it reach equilibrium?
answer: TripolyP has a complexation capacity of 1 ¬± 0.01 molPb/molTripolyP at both a 30-minute HRT and 24HS, and it reaches apparent equilibrium within 30 minutes, with Pb0.45¬µm concentration variations not exceeding 38.5 ¬± 15.5 ¬µg Pb0.45¬µm m‚Åª¬≤.
context: TripolyP had a potential complexation capacity-calculated as the molar ratio of median dissolved lead and median residual polyphosphate-of 1 ¬± 0.01 molPb/molTripolyP (at both a 30-min HRT and 24HS). Moreover, TripolyP achieved apparent equilibrium within 30 mins. That is, Pb0.45¬µm concentrations between a 30-min HRT and 24HS did not vary by more than 38.5 ¬± 15.5 ¬µg Pb0.45¬µm m -2 .

question: What are the default settings for DSDPFlex in terms of exhaustiveness and search depth?
answer: The default setting for DSDPFlex is exhaustiveness = 384 using GPU threads and search_depth = 40.

Vina uses 8 and 64 CPU cores (Intel Xeon Platinum 8358) when exhaustiveness is set to 8 and 64, respectively. DSDP and GNINA use 1 GPU (NVIDIA RTX A4000).

question: What change in enantiomer formation is observed when the W211A mutation is introduced in MaRedAm?
answer: The W211A mutation reverses the enzyme‚Äôs stereoselectivity, producing the opposite enantiomer compared to the wild-type. For example, while the wild-type generates (R)-enantiomers, W211A leads to (S)-enantiomers with 42% e.e. for compound 3b (compared to 74% e.e. for the wild-type) and 52% e.e. for compound 4b (compared to 63% e.e. for the wild-type).
context: Alanine mutants W33A, R35A, Y139A, and Y181A in MaRedAm (Table ) led to noticeable changes in the stereoselectivity of these enzymes. The two neighbouring MaRedAm variants, W33A and R35A, exhibited improvements in e.e. values, yielding, for example, (R)-rasagiline 3b in up to 95% e.e., compared to 74% e.e. achieved by the wild-type enzyme, Table . In contrast, the Y139A mutant led to a marked decrease in e.e. (64% e.e, (R)-4b). Similar trends were observed with these mutants for the synthesis of 4b, with W33A, R35A, Y118A, and Y181A all leading to significant improvement in e.e. of up >97% compared to 63% e.e. achieved by the wild-type enzyme. Again, Y139A led to a considerable decrease in e.e. value (25%). The bulky protic residues Y118, Y139A, and Y181A were also associated with decreased activity and afforded lower conversion values. Remarkably, the MaRedAm mutation, W211A, confers a profound switch in stereoselectivity to form the opposite enantiomer for both transformations (3b, W211A gave 42% e.e. (S) versus 74% e.e. (R) for wild-type; 4b, W211A gave 52% e.e (S) versus 63 % e.e. (R) for wild-type). Biotransformation reactions with purified enzyme preparation for selected variants (wild-type, W35A, W33A and W211A) across three transformations confirmed this pattern of stereoselectivity changes, Supporting Information, Table .

question: How many 3-cation composition spaces were identified where the predicted compositions meet the criteria even though none of their 2-cation subspaces in the training set do?
context: Considering 3-cation oxides, 535 of the 28612 compositions in the training set meet these criteria, comprising 47 3-cation composition spaces. In the prediction space, 602 compositions are predicted to meet these criteria, comprising 144 3-cation spaces not in the training set. Naturally, some of these 3-cation spaces will be predicted to meet the criteria because a 2-cation composition in the training data meets the criteria and the model predicts that adding 10% of an additional cation does not alter the absorption spectrum significantly enough to fail the criteria. The more notable predictions are thus the 3-cation spaces predicted to have a composition meeting the criteria even though none of the 2-cation subspaces in the training data meet the criteria. There are 44 such 3-cation spaces from H-CLMP(T) predictions: Ag-Fe-La, Ce-Fe-Mo, Fe-Mo-Zn, Fe-La-Zn, Mo-Pr-V, Ca-Gd-Pd, Ca-Mg-Pd, Fe-Pd-Zn, Ce-Fe-Zn, Fe-Pd-Yb, Ag-Fe-Pd, Ag-Fe-P, Bi-Cr-Yb, Ce-Pd-Pr, Cu-Fe-Pd, Eu-Fe-Nd, Ca-Pd-Zn, Ca-Co-Pd, Cu-Fe-La, Bi-Cr-Gd, Fe-La-Yb, Fe-K-Yb, Ag-Fe-Mo, Bi-Eu-Mn, Fe-La-Nd, Cu-Fe-Mo, Fe-Mn-Pd, Ca-Ce-Pd, Eu-Fe-Pd, Ag-Fe-Ti, Mn-Mo-Pr, Bi-Cr-Eu, Fe-P-Zn, Ca-Pd-Pr, Bi-Mo-V, Ca-Cu-Pd, Ag-Ca-Pd, Ag-Bi-Cr, Fe-Sr-Yb, Ce-Fe-Pd, Ca-Pd-Sm, Bi-Cr-K, Bi-Cr-Nb, Ca-Ni-Pd.

question: What are the reconstruction rate improvements of the eOHE variants compared to the original OHE method?
answer: eOHE-v1 shows a 10% improvement while eOHE-v2 shows a 5% improvement.
context: SELFIES achieves the best performance in reconstruction rate for eOHE, compared to other molecular string representations. While OHE achieved a reconstruction rate of 76%, 83% and 70% for SMILES, DeepSMILES, and SELFIES, eOHE-v1 reached almost 77%, 91% and 90%, and eOHE-v2 reached 76%, 86% and 81% respectively. This implies a 10% improvement in reconstruction rate for eOHE-v1 and 5% for eOHE-v2, in addition to the lower memory usage, in the same training time.

question: How was the issue of benzylic thioetherification during ticlopidine synthesis addressed?
answer: The problem was solved by replacing 4-FC6H4SH with a sterically hindered variant, 2,4,6-triisopropylthiophenol, which prevented radical recombination with ArS‚Ä¢ and avoided the undesired reaction at the benzylic position.
context: We further sought to exploit the ability of intercepting the diradicaloid o-QDMs by H-atom transfer (HAT) to synthesize tetrahydroisoquinoline alkaloids and related bioactive molecules directly from simply arylaldimines (Table ). This class of alkaloid displays a wide range of biological properties, including as antineutroinflammatory and anticancer antibiotic activities. Our initial attempt to synthesize ticlopidine (Ticlid¬Æ) 21, a commercial medicine to prevent strokes, from an imine derived from 2-vinylthiophene-3-carbaldehyde and 2chlorobenzylamine led to benzylic thioetherification potentially due to reaction at the benzylic position with 4-FC6H4S‚Ä¢. We were able to address this issue and synthesize ticlopidine 21 by simply switching 4-FC6H4SH to its sterically encumbered variant, 2,4,6-triisopropylthiophenol, to prevent the radical recombination with ArS‚Ä¢. Moreover, we also utilized imines derived from 2-vinyl-4,5-dimethoxybenzaldimine with 3,4-dimethoxybenzylamine, 3,4-methylenedioxybenzylamine and 4-fluorobenzylamine, respectively, to prepare intebremine 22, intebrinine 23 and MAO-B-In-15 (a MAO-B inhibitor) 24. 25b, 29 Likewise, we were also able to convert an imine derived from 2-vinyl-4,5methylenedioxyphenylcarbaldehyde with 4-methoxybenzylamine to another alkaloid viguine 25. Table . Application of intercepting diradicaloid o-QDMs by HAT to synthesize dihydroisoquinoline alkaloids and related bioactive molecules a a Conditions: 0.50 mmol scale reaction in 3 mL solvent with 3 equiv of ArSH. b 4-FC6H4SH was used. In-situ generated imine was used directly without purification. After confirming the formation of azabicyclic o-QDMs and their diradical nature, we proceeded with conducting [4 + 2] cycloaddition reactions to intercept them in their 1,3-diene form. As such, when aldimine 1 was heated with N-phenylmaleimide at 130 ¬∞C in dioxane for 3 h, the [4 + 2] cycloaddition product 26 was produced in 95% yield (Table , entry 1) via the formation of two carbon-carbon (C-C) bonds across the dibenzylic 1-and 4-positions of the azabicyclic o-QDM (such as 18). The reaction can be readily scaled up to gram scale without loss in yields (14.48 mmol, 5.07g, 92%). The reaction can be conducted in toluene, DCE, MeOH and DMF in similar yields (69-82%) (entries 2-4). The reaction proceeded in moderate yields (38-43%) in other solvents like MeCN, DMA, NMP and DMSO (entry 5). The reaction could also be run without solvent (neat), at 100 ¬∞C, in 1 h or with 1 equiv of N-phenylphthalimide to obtain the product in good yields (entries 6-9). After establishing the optimal reaction parameters, we examined the scope of o-QDMs for [4 + 2] cycloaddition (Table ). The azacyclic o-QDMs could be intercepted with a range of cyclic dienophiles, such as maleic anhydride, maleimide, N-alkyl (methyl, t-butyl, cyclohexyl) maleimide and N-aryl maleimide (27-32) in high endo selectivity. The azacyclic o-QDMs also tolerate acidic protons as shown by the [4 + 2] cycloaddition with N-(4-hydroxyphenyl)maleimide (32). The o-QDMs were also reactive with acyclic symmetric dienophiles like trans-1,2-dibenzoylethylene (33). Unsymmetric dienophiles such as methyl vinyl ketone and methyl acrylate furnished the [4 + 2] cycloaddition products (34-35) as a mixture of endo and exo products in moderate selectivity. Next, we examined the scope with regard to different electronic and steric variations on 2-alkenylaldimines. The reaction tolerates both electron rich and deficient substituents, such as methyl, tert-butyl, methoxy, dimethoxy, 1,3-dioxanyl, fluoro, difluoro, trifluoromethyl and nitro, at different positions on the aldiminyl arenes (36-48). Likewise, the 2-alkene in 2-alkenylaldimine can also be varied with methyl, phenyl, ester and benzyl ether at the ÔÅ° and ÔÅ¢-positions (39-55), demonstrating that both disubstituted terminal (49-51) and internal (52-55) alkenes can participate in the reaction. More sterically hindered tri-and tetrasubstituted 2-alkenes bearing two and three methyls, carbocycles and N,O-heterocycles at both the ÔÅ°and ÔÅ¢-positions also undergo 6ÔÅ∞-electrocyclization followed by [4 +2] cycloaddition (56-61), showcasing the robustness of this method and high reactivity of azacyclic o-QDMs to create highly hindered bridged azabicyclic structures. The reaction also shows a high level of compatibility with substituted anilines on the imine. For example, imines derived from anilines substituted at ortho, meta and para-positions with methyl, methoxy, dimethoxy, thiomethyl, chloro, bromo, iodo and meta-dinitro groups, are excellent substrates for [4 + 2] cycloaddition (62-69). Imines derived from polyaromatic amines (70) and heteroaryl amines (71) are also compatible for the reaction. Reactions can also be conducted with 2-alkenylketimines derived from 2-alkenylacetophenone and 2-alkenylbenzophenone (72-73). Conditions. a Reactions were run with 0.50 mmol imine and 0.75 mmol N-phenylphthalimide in 3.0 mL dioxane at 130 ¬∞C for 3 h. Unless stated otherwise, the ratio in parenthesis represent endo:exo. In-situ generated imine (1.0 mmol) was used directly without purification.

question: What are the mass in mg and the percentage yield of (HTriNOx 2-)Ga-OPh (9) obtained after stirring the reaction for approximately 12 hours?
answer: The compound was obtained in 85 mg with a 75% yield.
context: Yield: 0.12 g, 0.18 mmol (56%). Synthesis of (HTriNOx 2-)Ga-OPh (9): Phenol (15.4 mg, 0.164 mmol) was added as a solid to a stirring toluene (~10 mL) solution of 2 (100 mg, 0.164 mmol) in a vial. The reaction was allowed to stir at room temperature for ~12 h after which volatiles were removed from the reaction under vacuum. The resulting solid was washed with ether (~2 mL) followed by hexane (~2 mL) and then was dried under vacuum to give 9 as a white powder. Yield: 85 mg, 0.12 mmol (75%).

question: What is the composition of the pipette solution used during whole-cell recordings in the voltage sensitivity experiment on hDAT-HEK cells?
answer: The pipette solution contained (in mM): 115 K-gluconate, 10 HEPES, 2 MgCl2, 20 KCl, 2 MgATP, 1 Na2-ATP, and 0.3 GTP, adjusted to pH 7.3 with a final osmolarity of 280 ¬± 5 mOsm.
context: Voltage sensitivity in HEK cells. hDAT-HEK cells were plated on PDL-coated coverslips at a density of ~0.5 ÔÇ¥ 10 5 cells/coverslip. On the day of the experiment, a coverslip was mounted on an upright Olympus BX50WI (Olympus, Tokyo, Japan) microscope equipped with a 40√ó water immersion objective, differential interference contrast (DIC) optics and an infrared video camera and constantly perfused at a rate of 1 mL/min with saline containing (in mM): 118.6 NaCl, 3 KCl, 2.7 HEPES-Na, 3.3 HEPES, 1.2 MgCl2‚Ä¢6H2O, 2 CaCl2, and 10 glucose (pH 7.2 -7.4, 250 -255 mOsm/L). Whole-cell recordings were performed with a MultiClamp 700B amplifier (Molecular Devices, Forster City, CA) and InstruTECH ITC-18 A/D board (HEKA, Holliston, MA). Electrophysiological data were acquired using WINWCP software (developed by John Dempster, University of Strathclyde, UK). The pipette solution contained (in mM): 115 K-gluconate, 10 HEPES, 2 MgCl2, 20 KCl, 2 MgATP, 1 Na2-ATP, and 0.3 GTP (pH 7.3; 280 ¬± 5 mOsm). A cell was held at -60 mV in voltage clamp mode and a series of voltage steps was applied between -100 and +90 mV. Simultaneous recording of VSD optical signal was performed with an ORCA Fusion digital camera (Hamamatsu, Japan) using a DSRed fluorescent filter set (545 nm excitation filter, 30 nm bandpass; 570 nm dichroic; 620 nm emission filter, 60 nm bandpass; Chroma Technology Corp, VT) and recorded using HCImage software (Hamamatsu, Japan). Electrical and optical signals were synchronized with Master 9 multichannel TTL pulse generator (A.M.P.L., Israel). Background-subtracted time series of images were analyzed in ImageJ (NIH, USA), with the plasma membrane as the ROI.

question: How does electrochemical CO2 capture using aqueous anthraquinone solutions function?
answer: It functions by employing AQ2‚Äì, which acts as both a Lewis base and a Br√∏nsted base, thereby facilitating CO2 capture and release through a mechanism that involves both nucleophilic addition and a pH-swing.
context: In previous works, electrochemical CO2 capture in non-aqueous media is driven by electrochemically activated Lewis bases (nucleophiles) which undergo nucleophilic additions with CO2; electrochemical CO2 capture in aqueous media is driven by electrochemically activated Br√∏nsted bases which undergo proton-coupled electron transfer induced acid-base reactions . In this work, electrochemical CO2 capture with aqueous anthraquinone solutions is driven by AQ 2-which is both a Lewis base and a Br√∏nsted base. The electrochemical CO2 capture & release cycle involves both nucleophilicity-and pH-swing. (b) Six anthraquinone candidates that are soluble at neutral pH. Screened molecules: AQDS, 2,6-D2PEAQ, and AQ-1,8-3E-OH. Re-designed molecules: 1,4-, 1,5-, and 1,8-BTMAPAQ.

question: What types of substrates and leaving fragments were used to generate various alkyl halides in the deconstructive halogenation process?
answer: Both linear and cyclic alcohols were employed as substrates, including primary, secondary, and tertiary alcohols that were easily generated from aldehydes, ketones, and esters. The leaving fragments included formaldehyde, acetone, benzaldehyde, acetaldehyde, and acetophenone, which provided diverse primary, secondary, and tertiary carbon radicals.
context: With the simple and gentle optimized conditions established, we proceeded to evaluate the scope of the deconstructive chlorination process. Not only for chlorides, this reaction is also applied to produce bromides and iodides via changing halide sources. Many compounds with important functional groups were suitable sources for alcohol substrates. As shown in Fig. , linear (1-47) and cyclic alcohols (48-67) all reacted successfully, giving the corresponding alkyl halides in synthetically useful to excellent yields. To investigate the structural diversity of substrates, commercially available (1-6) or readily prepared primary, secondary, and tertiary alcohols, which were generated easily from aldehydes (7, 8), ketones (9-16), and esters (17-47), were all explored. With formaldehyde (1-4, 17), acetone (5, 6, 12, 13, 18-47), benzaldehyde (7), acetaldehyde (8), or acetophenone (9-11, 14-16) as the leaving fragment, the reaction presented diverse primary, secondary, and tertiary carbon radicals to yield various alkyl halides. As coupling fragments with halides, heterocycle, ring-structured alkyl, benzyl, alkenyl, linear alkyl with or without arene replacements, and alkyl with or without heteroatoms were all tolerated. Delightfully, homobenzylic halides with different phenyl substitutes could be produced in moderate to good isolated yields from different sources (4-6, 14-16, 18-22). Electronic effects on benzene rings didn't show much impact on the process. A similar observation was found for benzylic radical fragments (1-3, 17). It is notable that even when active benzylic/allylic sites were accessible, no regioisomer was found besides the desired product (3-6, 8, 14-23, 27).

question: Which polar aprotic solvents were used to prepare the concentrated solutions of SWCNT anions and sodium cations, and what isotopic variants were utilized with these solvents?

Solutions were measured using total neutron scattering with detailed three-dimensional modelling performed via Empirical Potential Structure Refinement (EPSR, Supplementary Information 1).

question: What are the energetic contributions of the Tyr264 and Tyr268 residues in the binding analysis of the PLpro-fortunellin complex?

context: Furthermore, using MMGBSA analysis, the total binding energy (ŒîG bind value), predominantly contributed by gas-phase interaction energy (ŒîG gas ) and Vander Waal interaction energy (ŒîG VDWAALS ), was calculated to be -29.6076kcal/mol with a standard deviation of ¬±4.3975kcal/mol (figure (II-G) and table ). question: What challenge in detecting individual probes arises from the observed chemical shift behavior of the DNP-MRI probes?
answer: The labeled carbons converge at approximately 170.3 ppm at pH 7.4, causing the signals from different probes to overlap and preventing their separate detection by C NMR.
context: We developed new DNP-MRI probes, Xaa-[1-13 C]Gly-d2-NMe2 (Xaa = Glu, Arg, Leu), by modulating the N-terminal structure of the APN probe to optimize enzymatic reactivity. These probes demonstrated efficient conversion with APA, APB, and LAP, suggesting their potential for in vivo multiplexed analysis of RAS-related AP activities. However, the chemical shifts of the labeled carbon in each Xaa-[1-13 C]Gly-d2-NMe2 probe were found to converge at approximately 170.3 ppm at pH 7.4 (Fig. ). Therefore, signals from Xaa-[1-13 C]Gly-d2-NMe2 (Xaa = Ala, Glu, Arg, Leu) could not be separately detected by C NMR.

question: How did the nature of the silver salt and the solvent choice influence the reaction yield, and what yields were achieved with AgBF4, AgSbF6, and DCE?
answer: Silver salts with non-coordinating counterions such as AgBF4 and AgSbF6 raised the yield to 61% and 66% respectively, whereas those with strongly coordinating counterions were nearly ineffective. Additionally, when DCE was used as the solvent, the reaction yield reached an excellent 98%.
context: To our delight, the use of AgBF4 and AgSbF6 led to an increase in yield (61% and 66%, respectively) (entry 4-5); whereas, other silver salts like AgNTf2 and AgOTs, bearing strongly coordinating counterion, were found to be almost ineffective for this transformation (entry 6-7). This observation suggests that silver salts with non-coordinating counterion are more efficient for this transformation. Subsequently, various solvents like o-DCB, DCE, MeOH, CHCl3 and 1,4dioxane were screened; amongst which, the use of DCE provided an excellent yield of 98% (entry 9). Further, while screening other (P, N)-ligated gold complexes, it was found that MorDalPhosAuCl could also catalyse the reaction giving a 56% yield of the desired product (entry 11). 16 With the optimized reaction conditions in hand, we turned our attention to explore the scope of alkenyl iodides 1 by treat-ing it with O,O-diphenyl phosphorothioate 2a (Scheme 2). To our delight, several styrenyl-based alkenyl iodides having electron-donating (-OMe, -Me) and electron-withdrawing substituents (-CO2Me, -CF3) at para position worked well in the reaction to afford the S-alkenyl phosphorothioates (3b-3i) in moderate to good yields (31-89%). Also, meta and ortho substituted styrenyl iodides reacted to deliver the products (3j-3m) in 48-84% yields. Notably, the styrenyl iodides bearing iodo, bromo and chloro substituents react in a chemoselective fashion to deliver the products (3d, 3f, 3g, 3k and 3m) in 48-87% yields. Next, naphthyl-based alkenyl iodides (1n and 1o) and disubstituted styrenyl iodides 1p and 1q coupled efficiently to give desired products (3n-3q) in 54-93% yields. Also, octenyl-derived alkenyl iodide 1r and ethyl-3-iodoacrylate 1s provided the corresponding products (3r and 3s) with high yields (75% and 91%, respectively). Certainly, the (Z)-isomer of 1s delivers the (Z)-isomer of product 3s selectively. Delightfully, estrone-derived alkenyl iodide 1t also worked well to afford the product 3t in 78% yield. Further, we sought to investigate the scope of phosphorothioates 2. Both O,Odiphenyl phosphorothioate 2a and O,O-dialkyl phosphorothioates (2u-2w) were found to react well with (2iodovinyl)benzene 1a to afford the desired products (3a, 3u-3w) in moderate to excellent yields (62-98%). Remarkably, the phosphoroselenoation of alkenyl iodide 1a could also be achieved by using phosphoroselenoate salt as the coupling partner, resulting in a 72% yield of the S-alkenyl phosphoroselenoate 3x.

question: Which chemical reagents are used to activate the carboxyl groups on the nanoparticles for streptavidin conjugation?
answer: 1-ethyl-3-carbodiimide (EDC) and N-hydroxysulfosuccinimide (Sulfo-NHS)
context: LINARDA nanoparticles were supplied by GENOTIX Biotechnologies (USA). LINARDA nanoparticles are also 500 nm in size, exhibit yellow-green fluorescence (Cy3-like) and are carboxyl functionalised. These nanoparticles were conjugated to streptavidin using 1-ethyl-3-carbodiimide (EDC) and N-hydroxysulfosuccinimide (Sulfo-NHS). The process started with centrifugation of 50 ŒºL stock COOH-LINARDA (L1) (1.5√ó10 8 NPs/ŒºL) at 13,400 rpm for 3 min to remove the supernatant. Nanoparticles were then conditioned twice with 100 ŒºL of 50 mM 2-morpholinoethanesulfonic acid (MES) buffer at pH 5.5, followed by centrifugation at 13,400 rpm for 3 min. The pellet was resuspended in 80 ŒºL 50 mM MES pH 5.5 and 10 ŒºL EDC (50 mg/mL) and 10 ŒºL Sulfo-NHS (50 mg/mL), both freshly prepared in 50 mM MES pH 5.5, were added to the mixture. After incubation for 20 min at 1,200 rpm and 25¬∫C, LINARDA (L2) nanoparticles were centrifuged at 13,400 rpm for 3 min, washed twice with 100 ŒºL 50 mM MES pH 5.5, conditioned with 100 ŒºL 50 mM MES pH 6 and centrifuged at 13,400 rpm for 3 min. After removal of the supernatant, 100 ŒºL streptavidin at 150 Œºg/mL in 50mM MES pH 6 was added to the LINARDA (L2) nanoparticles. This mixture was incubated for 2 hours at 1,200 rpm and 25¬∫C. Finally, the conjugated LINARDA (L3) nanoparticles were centrifuged at 13,400 rpm for 3 minutes, washed with 200 ŒºL LINARDA Wash Buffer, centrifuged again under the same conditions and incubated with LINARDA Quenching Buffer for 1 hour at RT. After quenching, Strep-LINARDA (L3) was washed twice with 250 ŒºL LINARDA Wash Buffer and stored in 2 mL Super Assay Buffer (Genotix Biotechnologies, USA). Throughout the protocol, sonication and vortexing were used to avoid aggregates and ensure a good conjugation yield.

question: What types of alcohol substrates and functional groups proved compatible with the coupling methods, and what results were achieved in modifying medicinally relevant scaffolds?
answer: The protocol successfully utilized a wide range of alcohols, including simple hydrocarbon-, ether-, or acetal-containing substrates as well as those bearing tetrahydropyran, morpholine, lactam, and pyridine heterocycles. It also tolerated protic motifs such as amine derivatives and unprotected distal alcohols, enabling selective activation in diol substrates. In late-stage derivatization of medicinally relevant scaffolds, the method produced hydromethylated products from compounds like quinine (34% yield), retapamulin (30% yield), common steroids (70% yield), and picrotoxinin (47% yield), while also allowing hydroalkylation of a derivative of ataluren with yields ranging from 43‚Äì73%.
context: To probe the versatility of this new coupling technology, we next investigated the scope of alcohols amenable to Table . Scope of Metallaphotoredox Cross-Coupling of Alkenes and Methanol a a Coupling performed with methanol (3 equiv), NHC-1 (3.3 equiv), pyridine (3.15 equiv) in MTBE (0.50 M) for 15 min at room temperature, then manganese catalyst 3 (20 mol%), nickel catalyst 4 (10 mol%), iridium photocatalyst 5 (0.25 mol%), benzoyl peroxide (4 equiv), potassium acetate (0.5 equiv), water (5 equiv), alkene (0.5 mmol, 1 equiv), TMDS (5 equiv) and performed NHC adduct in DMA:MTBE (1:4, 0.067 M) with blue LED irradiation for 2 h at room temperature. b Yields determined by NMR with 1,4-dinitrobenzene as internal standard. c Yields determined by NMR with 1,4-dinitrobenzene as internal standard reference to the known products due to volatility. See Supporting Information for experimental details. deoxygenative hydroalkylation (Table ). Using an alternative Ni-diketonate sorting catalyst, an array of primary substrates were paired with tertiary olefin-derived radicals to efficiently access diverse quaternary products (see SI for additional examples of hydromethylation or hydroalkylation). In these cases, simple hydrocarbon-, ether-or acetal-containing alcohols were broadly successful (24-30, 52-68% yield), as were substrates bearing tetrahydropyran (31 and 32, 73% and 55% yield, respectively), morpholine (33, 52% yield), lactam (34, 63% yield) or pyridine (35, 60% yield) heterocyclic functionality. Moreover, the functional group tolerance of this method allowed for retention of protic motifs such as amine derivatives or unprotected distal alcohols (36-40, 51-89% yield). The latter finding is particularly significant when considering the selectivity of NHC-mediated deoxygenation for activating less-substituted sites within diol substrates. As such, this protocol could enable the stepwise and site-selective elaboration of native polyols into complex scaffolds using olefin feedstock partners. Lastly, to rapidly produce drug-like, C(sp 3 )-rich molecular architecture from native functionality, we harnessed olefinalcohol coupling for the late-stage derivatization of medicinally-relevant scaffolds (Figure ). Using methanol, hydromethylated products were expediently furnished from bioactive compounds bearing a typically unreactive olefin within their structure, including the antimalarial quinine (41, 34% yield), the antibiotic retapamulin (42, 30% yield), common steroids (43, 70% yield) and the plant-derived stimulant picrotoxinin (44, 47% yield). Delightfully, this reactivity was also extendable to other quaternary carbon formations, as both the aforementioned substrates and a derivative of the muscular dystrophy therapeutic ataluren were efficiently hydroalkylated using diverse primary alcohols (45-48, 43-73% yield). Across all cases, the unique tolerance of this method for labile functionality (including readily-oxidized amines and sulfides, coordinating alcohols and pyridines, or oxidative additionprone 1,2,4-oxadiazoles) was critical for the generation of complex molecular architecture in an efficient manner.

question: What are the approximate elongation at break values for the sensors S-PUF/V2O5, S-PUF/V2O5/PPy-10, S-PUF/V2O5/PPy-15, and S-PUF/V2O5/PPy-33?
answer: The elongations at break are approximately 56.8% for S-PUF/V2O5, 56.7% for S-PUF/V2O5/PPy-10, 57.5% for S-PUF/V2O5/PPy-15, and 57.8% for S-PUF/V2O5/PPy-33.
context: It should be noted that the tensile stress-strain curves of the sensors including S-PUF/V2O5, S-PUF/V2O5/PPy-10, S-PUF/V2O5/PPy-15, and S-PUF/V2O5/PPy-33 displayed two fracture peaks, which are attributed to the different elongations at break of different structural layers in the sensors based on a sandwich structure (Figure , Movies S1-S4, Supporting Information). The anode material was broken first, followed by the cathode material and the PAM gel upon stretching. The elongations at break for S-PUF/V2O5, S-PUF/V2O5/PPy-10, S-PUF/V2O5/PPy-15, and S-PUF/V2O5/PPy-33 are approximately 56.8%, 56.7%, 57.5%, and 57.8%, respectively. Hence, 50% tensile strain was chosen to investigate the tensile and sensing properties of the composite materials and sensors.

answer: In the perpendicular transition, the selection rules are ŒîJ = 0, ¬±1 and ŒîK = ¬±1, while in the parallel transition they are ŒîJ = 0, ¬±1 and ŒîK = 0. This difference results in distinct rotational profiles for each transition.

question: How do the lattice constants of IrxRhy alloys change as the proportion of Rh increases in the alloy?
answer: The lattice constant decreases as Rh increases; it goes from 3.894 √Ö in Ir100 to 3.884 √Ö in Ir75Rh25, then to 3.876 √Ö in Ir50Rh50, 3.867 √Ö in Ir25Rh75, and finally 3.857 √Ö in Rh100.
context: To build the alloy surfaces, IrxRhy structures are constructed with varied atomic ratios (Ir100, a = 3.894 √Ö; Ir75Rh25, a = 3.884 √Ö; Ir50Rh50, a = 3.876 √Ö; Ir25Rh75, a = 3.867 √Ö; and Rh100, a = 3.857 √Ö). The lattice constants of the alloys are calculated using Vegard's Law, where a ‚Ä¢ Ir and a ‚Ä¢ Rh are the lattice parameters of the pure metals, while xIr is the mole fraction of Ir [Eq. 4].

question: What is the synthesis process for methylene diphenyl diisocyanate (MDI) starting from aniline, and which isomers are produced?
answer: Methylene diphenyl diisocyanate (MDI) is synthesized through a four-step process that begins with aniline. In this process, aniline reacts with formaldehyde in the presence of an acid catalyst to form a mixture of methylene diphenyldiamines (MDA) and polymeric aniline (pMDA). The synthesis ultimately produces three common isomers: 4,4'-MDI, 2,4'-MDI, and 2,2'-MDI.
context: Methylene diphenyl diisocyanate (MDI) is a diaromatic diisocyanate with three common isomers (4,4'-MDI, 2,4'-MDI and 2,2'-MDI) produced by a 4 step synthesis starting from aniline. The process for producing MDI (Erreur ! Source du renvoi introuvable.A) involves the reaction of aniline with formaldehyde in the presence of an acid catalyst to produce a mixture of methylene (diphenyldiamines) (MDA) and polymeric aniline (pMDA).

question: How was the critical micelle concentration (CMC) of Œ±-CD-(CMG)4-DOPE determined?
answer: The CMC was determined using a fluorescence probe technique with pyrene. The samples were prepared by serially diluting a PBS stock solution over a range of concentrations from 250 to 0.025 ¬µM while maintaining a constant pyrene concentration of 0.2 ¬µM. Fluorescence spectra were recorded with an excitation wavelength of 334 nm and an emission range of 350‚Äì450 nm. The ratio of the fluorescence intensities at 385 nm and 375 nm (I385/I375) was plotted against the sample concentrations, and a logistic function was used to fit the data to determine the CMC value.
context: Œ±-CD-(CMG)4-DOPE TLC: Rf = 0.32 (CHCl3/MeOH/H2O 3:6:1). The critical micelle concentration (CMC) was determined by the fluorescence probe technique using pyrene as a fluorescence probe. The samples for CMC measurements were prepared by serial dilution of stock sample PBS solution with concentration varied from 250 to 0.025 ¬µM. Pyrene concentration (0.2 ¬µM) was kept constant during measurements. The pyrene fluorescence spectra were recorded using a RF-5301PC spectrofluorophotometer (Shimadzu, Japan), Œªex= 334 nm, Œªem= 350-450 nm, slidwidth(ex) = slidwidth(em) = 3 nm, step width 1 nm. The sample concentrations were plotted against the I385/I375 peaks ratio of the fluorescence intensity and subsequently fitted with a logistic function, whereby the CMC value of each sample was determined.

question: What transformation does the reagent KPF6 perform during the synthetic process?
answer: KPF6 converts the bromide salt into the hexafluorophosphate counterion via a metathesis reaction.
context: The N-(2-(bromomethyl)benzonitrile)benzimidazole (0.55 g, 2.34 mmol) was added to the synthesized N-(2-bromobutyl)-N'-benzylbenzimidazolium bromide, iii‚ÄßBr (1.00 g, 2.36 mmol) dissolved in acetonitrile (20 mL) and the reaction mixture was refluxed for 24 h at 80 -100 ÔÇ∞C. Upon cooling at room temperature, a sticky brown precipitate formed then filtered and washed with acetonitrile (5 mL) and diethyl ether (2 ÔÇ¥ 3 mL). Bromide salt was used for further synthesis, whereas the hexafluorophosphate salt was used for characterization purposes. The bromide salt was converted into hexafluorophosphate counterion by metathesis reaction using KPF6 (0.13 g, 1.00 mmol) in methanol (10 mL). The mixture was stirred for 3 h, filtered and washed with distilled water (3 x 2 mL) and then recrystallize from acetonitrile/diethyl ether.

question: What do the large Stokes shifts observed for compounds 1, 2, and 3 indicate about their emission process?
answer: They indicate that the emission process is phosphorescent, confirming involvement of triplet states.

These large Stokes shifts suggest a phosphorescent nature of the process. The photoluminescence properties of 1, 2 and 3 are close to those of the 1D [Cu(SPh)]n, [Cu(o-SPhCO2H)]n and [Cu(o-SPhCO2Me)]n that exhibit intense luminescence with strong peaks centered at 645, 719 and 596 nm, respectively, upon excitation at 359, 412 and 415 nm, respectively. The low energy emission of [Cu(SPh)]n, considering previous studies on Cu(I) thiolates, has been assigned to ligand to metal charge transfer (LMCT). Therefore, the photoluminescence properties of 1, 2 and 3 can originate from LMCT. The luminescence lifetime decay of 1 at RT is fitted by a biexponential curve with components of 10.8 ¬µs (97 %) and 139.6 ¬µs (3 %). Next, 2.9 ml of phosphate buffer (0.1 M, pH 8) was added followed by dropwise addition of 2-mercapto-ethanol (0.01 ml, 0.14 mmol, 2 equiv.) as 0.1 ml of a stock solution (0.1 of ml 2-mercapto-ethanol in 0.9 ml of pH 8 phosphate buffer) at room temperature. question: What method was used for calibrating the collision energy, and which thermometer ions served as the standards?
answer: Schr√∂der's method was employed, using the dissociation energies of benzylpyridinium and benzhydrylpyridinium ions as the calibration standards.
context: The reagents and solvents were commercially obtained. Ligands tris(pyridin-2-ylmethyl)amine (TPA), (6-aminopyridin-2-ylmethyl)bis(pyridine-2-ylmethyl)amine (MAPA), bis(6-aminopyridin-2-ylmethyl)(pyridine-2-ylmethyl)amine (BAPA) and tris(6-aminopyridin-2-ylmethyl)amine (TAPA) were prepared according to the procedures reported in the supporting information. The ionic complexes, denoted as [(L)Co III (O2)] + , were generated by an in-flow mixing of [(L)Co II (NO3)2] + (25 ¬µM in acetonitrile) and H2O2 (3.5 %, (v/v) in acetonitrile) prior to the injection to the mass spectrometer. The mass spectrometry experiments were performed with a Finnigan LCQ XP mass spectrometer equipped with an electrospray ionization (ESI) source. The conditions were: capillary temperature 200 ‚ÑÉ, spray voltage 4.5 kV, capillary voltage 0 V, tube lens offset 20 V. The collision energy was calibrated by Schr√∂der's method 9 using the dissociation energies of known benzylpyridinium-and benzhydrylpyridinium thermometer ions (Table , Figures ). The energy-resolved CID experiments were performed with mass selected [(L)Co III (O2)] + complexes (Figures S4, S6, S10, S14) in the full range of collision energies (Figure ). The relative intensities of the parent and the fragment ions were plotted as a function of the collision energy (Figures ). The fragmentation threshold (the bond dissociation energy) was determined as an extrapolation of a tangent of the sigmoidal fits of the experimental data to the zero intensity.

question: Which reaction pathways were proposed for 5-benzoyl-pyrrolo[2,1-a]isoquinoline 3a, and what unusual selectivity was observed?
answer: The study proposed two pathways: one via a Pd-catalyzed cross-dehydrogenative coupling that leads to an intramolecular cyclization between two functionalizable C-H centers (site-1 and site-2) to afford an 8H-indeno-pyrrolo[2,1-a]isoquinolinone moiety, and another by tuning the conditions to achieve a C-H amination between N-H and site-1 to form a 9-tosyl-9H-indolo-pyrrolo[2,1-a]isoquinoline. This investigation also revealed an oxygen-induced chemoselectivity that had not been observed before.
context: In the substrate 5-benzoyl-pyrrolo[2,1-a]isoquinoline 3a (Scheme 1), we identified two fucntionalizable C-H centers, at site-1 & site-2. Under Pd-catalyzed crossdehydrogenative coupling conditions, we hypothesized that an intramolecular cyclization will happen between site-1 and site-2 affording 8H-indeno-pyrrolo[2,1-a]isoquinolinone moiety 4a. In addition, by tuning the reaction conditions, we postulated that a C-H amination could be effected between N-H and site-1 for the synthesis of 9-tosyl-9Hindolo-pyrrolo[2,1-a]isoquinoline 5a. These investigations resulted in unraveling an oxygen induced chemoselectivity which to the best of our knowledge is unknown thus far.

question: What chromatographic techniques were employed for monitoring chemical reactions?
answer: Reaction progress was monitored via thin-layer chromatography using alumina plates coated with Merck silica gel 60 F254 or Merck silica gel 60 RP-18 F254 and analyzed under UV light at 254 nm, as well as by high performance liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry and low resolution electrospray ionization mass spectrometry.
context: General remarks. Starting materials (chemicals) were purchased from commercial suppliers (Abcr, Acros, Alfa Aesar, BLDpharm, Sigma Aldrich, TCI) and used without any further purification. Solvents were used in p.a. quality and dried according to common procedures, if necessary. Literature known reference compounds (2-4, 20-24) were either purchased from commercial suppliers (Selleckchem (2), MedChemExpress (4, 22)) or synthesized according to previously published procedures (3, 20-21, 23-24). Thin-layer chromatography (TLC) for reaction monitoring was performed with alumina plates coated with Merck silica gel 60 F254 (layer thickness: 0.2 mm) or Merck silica gel 60 RP-18 F254 (layer thickness: 0.2 mm) and analyzed under UV-light (254 nm). As an alternative method for reaction monitoring, we used high performance liquid chromatography mass spectrometry (HPLC-MS) or low resolution electrospray ionization mass spectrometry (LRMS-ESI). HPLC-MS analyses were performed using a Thermo Scientific Dionex UltiMate 3000 HPLC system in combination with a DAD detector (220/230/254 nm) and an Agilent ZORBAX ECLIPSE, XDB-C8 column (3.0 mm x 100 mm, 3.5 ¬µm). Elution was performed at room temperature under gradient conditions. Eluent A was water containing 0.1% (v/v) formic acid; eluent B was methanol. Linear gradient conditions were as follows: 0-0.2 min: A=75%, B=25%; 0.2-6.0 min: linear increase to B=100%; 6.0-8.5 min: B=100%; 8.5-9.0 min: linear decrease to A=75%, B=25%; 9.0-12.0 min: A=75%, B=25%. A flow rate of 0.4 mL‚Ä¢min -1 was maintained during the entire elution. Mass detection was performed with a BRUKER amaZon SL mass spectrometer using ESI as ionization source. As an alternative method for low resolution electrospray ionization mass spectrometry (LRMS-ESI), we used an Advion expression¬Æ compact mass spectrometer (CMS) coupled with an automated TLC plate reader Plate Express¬Æ (Advion). Flash column chromatography was performed with hand packed Silica Columns 60M (0.040-0.063 mm, 230-400 mesh) as a stationary phase on a Biotage SP-1 or Selekt automated flash purification system with UV-Vis detector. Yields were not optimized. NMR spectra were recorded using either a Bruker Avance 400 ( 1 H: 400 MHz, C: 101 MHz), Bruker Avance DRX 500 ( 1 H: 500 MHz, C: 126 MHz), or a Bruker Avance 600 ( 1 H: 600 MHz, C: 151 MHz) instrument. The spectra are referenced against the NMR solvent and are reported as follows: 1 H: chemical shift Œ¥ (ppm), multiplicity (s = singlet, d = doublet, dd = doublet of doublets, t = triplet, m = multiplet, b = broad), integration, coupling constant (J in Hz). C: chemical shift Œ¥ (ppm), abbreviations: carbons that could not be found in C spectra (DEPTQ) but in HMBC or HSQC are additionally marked with a hashtag (#). Signals that are partially overlaid by a solvent signal are marked with an asterisk (*). The assignment resulted from HMBC and HSQC experiments. High resolution mass spectra were measured with a timsTOF Pro Mass Spectrometer from Bruker Daltonics using ESI as ionization source. Purity was determined for all tested compounds by HPLC and UV detection and was >95%.

question: What potential mechanism of action was proposed for compound 31's activity against Leishmania donovani?
answer: Compound 31 may work by targeting potassium channels, as its structurally related analog is known to act on KCNQ2 potassium channels that are present in Leishmania donovani.
context: An interesting related scaffold, carboxyimidamide-substituted benzo[c][1,2,5]oxadiazoles, demonstrated promising activity, with 31 (Fig. ) proved to be active against Leishmania donovani. A structurally related carboxyimidamide MLS001146594 (32) (Fig ) is well known for its action on KCNQ2 potassium channels, which are also present in L. donovani (CAJ1987321.1). These putative potassium channels may be involved in several cellular pathways, suggesting a potential mechanism of action for 31 (Fig. ).

question: What are the rotational selection rules for the 5 (‚Üí! and 1 (‚Üí! transitions, and how do they differ?

question: What conditions and supplements were used to maintain the cells and how was their integrity ensured?
answer: The cells were maintained at 37¬∞C in a humidified incubator with 5% CO2 in atmospheric air and grown in a medium supplemented with 10% fetal calf serum, antibiotics (100 mg/mL streptomycin and 100 U/mL penicillin), 2 mM glutamine, 1 mM NaHCO3, 1 mM C3H3NaO3, and 20 mM HEPES. Additionally, the cell lines were validated monthly and checked for mycoplasma contamination every 2 weeks.

question: Which hybrid compound showed the highest in vitro potency against SARS-CoV-2 among the quinoline-based compounds, and what were its EC50 values compared with chloroquine and remdesivir?
answer: Quinolineadamantane 15 demonstrated the highest potency with an EC50 value of 1.5 ŒºM, which is more effective than chloroquine with an EC50 of 3.8 ŒºM and remdesivir with an EC50 of 4.0 ŒºM.
context: In summary, these study reinforce our hypothesis that artemisinin and quinoline hybrid compounds could be effective as a COVID-19 treatment. We synthesized and explored the in vitro anti-SARS-CoV-2 activities of fifteen artemisinin-and quinolinecontaining hybrid compounds 1-15. All artemisinin-based hybrids 1-7 display superior potency against SARS-CoV-2 (EC 50 values 7.8 -46 ŒºM) outperforming artesunic acid. The most active artesunic acid-derived hybrid 7 (EC 50 = 7.8 ¬µM) is also significantly more potent in vitro than its parent compound artesunic acid (EC 50 >50 ¬µM) and shows low cytotoxic effects on benchmark Vero E6 cells. Notably, also synthetic peroxide-based hybrids 8-13 were remarkably potent against SARS-CoV-2. Most active synthetic peroxide-quinoline hybrid was 10 (EC 50 = 11.5 ¬µM). Among quinoline-based new compounds, quinolineadamantane 15 (EC 50 = 1.5 ŒºM) is the most efficient in vitro, outperforming chloroquine (EC 50 = 3.8 ¬µM) and remdesivir (EC 50 = 4.0 ¬µM), used as reference drugs. These promising results further underline the high potential of the hybridization concept for further investigations and hybrid-based drug design of efficient antiviral agents to treat SARS-CoV-2 infections.

question: What are the comonomers with which ring-unsubstituted ECPP has been copolymerized?
answer: Ring-unsubstituted ECPP has been copolymerized with acrylonitrile, styrene, vinyl acetate, acrylic esters, and 1,2-ethanediyl ester of 2-methylpropenoic acid.
context: Synthetic manipulation of polymer substrates via copolymerization is one of the oldest and most reliable methods to increase the functional diversity of soft materials . Ringsubstituted ethyl 2-cyano-3-phenyl-2-propenoates (ECPP), RPhCH=C(CN)CO2C2H5 continue to attract attention as comonomers for modification of commercial polymers. Ring unsubstituted ECPP has been copolymerized with acrylonitrile , styrene , vinyl acetate , acrylic esters , and 1,2-ethanediyl ester of 2-methylpropenoic acid .

question: How was competing desulfonylation controlled in the synthesis of sulfonyl BCP iodides derived from electron-deficient aryl sulfonyl bromides?
answer: The reaction was cooled to -40 ¬∞C to limit competing desulfonylation.
context: With conditions in hand for iodo-and bromosulfonylation of 1, the scope of the reaction was studied (Figure ). Aryl sulfinates bearing neutral or electron-donating substituents(2a-2c) gave the corresponding sulfone BCP iodides and bromides 3a-3c in near quantitative yields (96-100%, up to ~2 g scale). Halogenated arenes were well-tolerated, particularly for BCP bromide synthesis (3d-3f, 50-100%). Good to excellent yields were also observed for electron-deficient aryl sulfonyl bromides 3g-Br-3i-Br (for example, the p-CF3 aryl sulfone 3i-Br was obtained in 97% yield from the isolated sulfonyl bromide intermediate on 0.7 g scale, or in 61% yield using a one-pot procedure); however the corresponding iodides performed less well, and typically benefited from cooling to -40 ¬∞C to limit competing desulfonylation. Sterically-encumbered o-tolyl and mesityl sulfinates proceeded smoothly, giving BCP iodide 3j-I in 88% yield, and mesityl adducts 3k-I and 3k- Br in 66% and 82% yield respectively. A lower yield of 3j-Br was observed (33%) due to competing benzylic bromination of the methyl group. Additional m-electron-withdrawing substituents were also accommodated, with 3,5-di-F and 3,5-di-CF3 arenes affording sulfonyl BCP halides 3l and 3m in 58-100% yield. The inferior reactivity observed with acetamide 2n was surprising, even on cooling to -40 ¬∞C, possibly due to competing reaction at the amide. A bis-arylsulfinate could even be used successfully to deliver bis-sulfonyl BCP iodide 3o-I and bromide 3o-Br in 26% and 92% yield respectively. [3.1.1]Propellane 4 is emerging as a convenient reagent to access novel m-substituted arene bioisosteres; 12 pleasingly, the addition of sulfonyl halides translated smoothly to this propellane, giving sulfonyl BCHep halide products in excellent yields (5a-I, 87% and 5a-Br, 100%).

question: What yield range differences were observed when using electron-rich compared to electron-deficient aryl bromide electrophiles in the cross-coupling reaction?
answer: Electron-rich aryl bromides delivered yields ranging from 49% to 72%, while electron-deficient aryl bromides produced yields between 42% and 66%.
context: After optimizing the reaction conditions, we explored the substrate scope. As shown in Figure , OTs and OTf substituted 4-tert-butylbenzene are effective electrophiles, yielding 52% and 78% of product 8, respectively. Other aryl bromides, including both electron-rich and electron-deficient arenes, were suitable electrophiles for this cross-coupling reaction (9 to 19). The aryl bromides with electron-rich substituents (8 to 14) delivered slightly higher yields (49% to 72%) compared to those with electron-deficient substituents (15 to 19, with yields ranging from 42% to 66%). This may be due to the low reactivity of electron-rich aryl bromides in the oxidative addition reaction with the Ni I intermediate, which slows down the competing homo-coupling reaction of aryl bromides. The aryl bromide electrophiles with various functional groups, including methoxy group (11 and 12), ester (15), fluoride (16), ketone (18), and trifluoromethyl group (19), as well as protection groups such as amide (13), acetal (14), and tert-butyloxycarbonyl (Boc) (20 and 21), were found to be effective in this reaction. The para-substituted methoxy bromobenzene delivered a yield comparable to that of the meta-substituted methoxy bromobenzene (52% yield for 11 and 49% yield for 12). While the C(sp 3 )-C(sp 2 ) cross-coupling product was not obtained when using ortho-substituted methoxy bromobenzene electrophile. Yields of 54% and 61% were obtained for products 16 and 17, respectively, from 1-bromo-4-fluorobenzene and 1-bromo-4-chlorobenzene. For substrates with strong electron-withdrawing substituents such as methoxycarbonyl (15) and acetyl (18) groups, and œÄ-conjugation extended aryl groups (22), the use of the 2,2'-bpy ligand resulted in the most favorable results (with yields of 66%, 42%, and 51% for 15, 18, and 22, respectively).

question: What happens to the lead colloids dispersed by HexametaP when the reaction time is extended from 30 minutes to 24 hours?

question: Which chiral ligand enabled the formation of 50% yield of product 2b with 85% ee and recovery of 45% yield of 1b with 95% ee, resulting in a selectivity factor of 43?
answer: The reaction with (R,R)-Et-DuPhos (L11) achieved those results.
context: either reactivity or enantioselectivity. (R)-DIOP (L3) and (R,R)-Ph-BPE (L4) delivered the target product with low S factor. The reaction with (R,R)-Me-DuPhos (L10) proceeded smoothly to give the hydrosilylated product 2b in moderated enantioselectivity and recovered 1b in excellent enantioselectivity (S = 11). To our delight, 50% of 2b in 85% ee was formed in the presence of (R,R)-Et-DuPhos (L11) and starting material 1b was recovered in 45% yield with 95% ee, corresponding to a selectivity factor of 43. However, more bulky (R,R)-i Pr-DuPhos (L12) barely occurred. Other types of chiral ligands were also valued, providing insufficient enantioselectivities (For more details, see the Supporting Information). Finally, the stereocontrol was further improved to 95% ee of (R)-2b and 64% ee of the recovered (R)-1b using [Rh(cod)Cl]2 (1.0 mol%) and (R,R)-Et-DuPhos (2.4 mol%) in dichloromethane at 0 o C after systematically screening of other reaction parameters.

question: How were the His6-tagged LpMIP proteins purified and prepared for storage?
answer: The purification process began with binding the proteins to a NiNTA gravity flow column, followed by washing with a buffer containing 20 mM Tris (pH 8), 20 mM imidazole, and 300 mM NaCl. The protein was then eluted with 20 mM Tris (pH 8), 500 mM imidazole, and 300 mM NaCl. Imidazole was removed by overnight dialysis in the presence of TEV protease at a molar ratio of 20:1 to cleave the His6-tag. After tag removal, a reverse NiNTA gravity flow column was used to separate the cleaved protein, and final purification was achieved via size exclusion chromatography on a HiLoad Superdex S200 16/60 column using 50 mM Tris (pH 7) and 150 mM NaCl before the protein was concentrated and stored at -20¬∞C.
context: Genes encoding N-terminally His6-tagged LpMIP (1-214) or LpMIP (77-214) in a pET11a vector were purchased from GenScript. Proeins were expressed in E. coli BL21 gold (DE3) cells (Agilent Technologies) grown in LB-medium supplemented with 1 mg/mL Ampicillin at 37¬∞C. Expression was induced at OD600 nm of 0.8 with 2 mM IPTG (final concentration). Cells were further grown at 37¬∞C for 4 h and harvested via centrifugation. Cell pellets were stored at -20 ¬∞C until further use. After suspension in lysis buffer (20 mM Tris pH 8, 20 mM imidazole, 300 mM NaCl, 0.1% Triton X100, 1 mM DTT, 1 mM benzamidine, 1 mM PMSF, lysozyme, DNase, RNase), cells were lyzed via sonication. The supernatant after centrifugation (45 min at 10,000 xg at 4¬∞C) was applied to a NiNTA gravity flow column (Qiagen). After washing with 20 mM Tris pH 8, 20 mM imidazole, 300 mM NaCl, the protein was eluted with 20 mM Tris pH 8, 500 mM imidazole, 300 mM NaCl. Imidazole was removed via dialysis over night in the presence of TEV protease in a molar ratio of 20:1 to remove the His6-tag. A reverse NiNTA gravity flow column was used to separate cleaved protein which was then further purified via size exclusion chromatography (HiLoad Superdex S200 16/60 column, GE Healthcare) with 50 mM Tris pH 7, 150 mM NaCl. Purified proteins were concentrated via VivaSpin centrifugal concentrators (Merck) and stored at -20¬∞C.

question: How do the databases COMPAS-3x and COMPAS-3D differ in terms of the number of compounds, ring counts, and computational methods used?
answer: COMPAS-3x contains approximately 39,000 PBHs with 4 to 11 rings where geometries and properties are calculated using xTB (GFN2-xTB), whereas COMPAS-3D includes about 9,000 pc-PBHs with 4 to 10 rings, and their geometries and properties are determined via DFT at the CAM-B3LYP-D3BJ/aug-cc-pVDZ//CAM-B3LYP-D3BJ/def2-SVP level of theory.
context: (1) COMPAS-3x, and (2) COMPAS-3D. The former contains ‚àº39k PBHs consisting of 4-11 rings, with geometries and properties calculated with xTB (using GFN2-xTB). The latter contains ‚àº9k pc-PBHs consisting of 4-10 rings, with geometries and properties calculated with DFT at the CAM-B3LYP-D3BJ/aug-cc-pVDZ//CAM-B3LYP-D3BJ/def2-SVP level of theory. In addition to the generation and curation of both data sets, we compared the two computational methods, and performed a structure-property analysis on the collected data.

question: What are the reported IC50 values for TT@UCNPs@PEI/L-D, TT@UCNPs@PEI/L-C, and TT@UCNPs@PEI/L-D-C compounds when used against HepG2 cells?
answer: The IC50 values are 38.04 g/ml for TT@UCNPs@PEI/L-D, 130.9 g/ml for TT@UCNPs@PEI/L-C, and 14.24 g/ml for TT@UCNPs@PEI/L-D-C.
context: The intracellular oxygen generation of TT@UCNPs@PEI/L-D, TT@UCNPs@PEI/L-C and TT@UCNPs@PEI/L-D-C compounds against HepG2 cells were determined by the fluorescent microscopy. Briefly, HepG2 cells were grown on coverslips at a density of 2 √ó 10 5 cells/well inhypoxic condition and incubated for 24 h. Thereafter, cells were incubated with O 2 -sensing probe [(Ru(dpp)3)]Cl2 for 30 min. Then, cells were treated with TT@UCNPs@PEI/L-D (IC 50Value: 38.04 g/ml), TT@UCNPs@PEI/L-C (IC 50 Value: 130.9 g/ml) and TT@UCNPs@PEI/L-D-C (IC 50 Value: 14.24 g/ml) and again incubated for 24 h. After that,cells were subsequently washed with 1X PBS. Finally, the coverslips were mounted in glycerol and the slides were observed by using the fluorescent microscope.

question: What chromatography method and solvent system were used to purify the crude product in the small scale pilot reaction?
answer: The crude product was purified by chromatography using a 25 g Biotage SNAP KP Si cartridge with a gradient of 2‚Äì45% ethyl acetate in cyclohexane.
context: Five batches of 1 were combined (73.4 g) and purified by column chromatography (15-20% EtOAc in hexane) to give 1 (65.3 g, 53%) as a crystalline, white solid of high purity. Small scale pilot reactions: THF (3.0 mL) was added to 4-methylbenzenesulfonohydrazide (250 mg, 1.34 mmol, 1.0 equiv.) in a thick-walled reaction vial with stir bar and the vial was sealed with a crimped septum cap. An aqueous solution of dimethoxyacetaldehyde (0.22 mL, 60% in H2O, 1.48 mmol, 1.1 equiv.) was added via syringe and the mixture stirred at RT for 2 h. Separately, 2,4-dichloro-3-(trifluoromethyl)aniline (4) (334 mg, 1.48 mmol, 1.1 equiv.) and AcOH (80 ŒºL, 1.34 mmol , 1.0 equiv.) was dissolved in THF (0.5 mL), and this solution was added to via syringe. The mixture was then heated at 75 ¬∞C for 18 h in a DrySyn block. TLC (30% EtOAc in cyclohexane) showed no aniline remaining. The reaction mixture was cooled to RT, concentrated and the residue partitioned between CH2Cl2 (30 mL) and water (20 mL) with vigorous mixing for 5 minutes. The 2-phase mixture was passed through a phase separator and the organic phase concentrated. The crude product was purified by chromatography on a 25 g Biotage SNAP KP Si cartridge (2-45% EtOAc in cyclohexane) to give 1 (286 mg, 1.01 mmol, 76%) as an off-white solid.

question: How many linear interpolation geometries were used to compute VEE and SOC between the nearly planar S1(min(1)) and the ring open S1(min(2)) structures?
answer: Eight linear interpolation geometries were used.
context: The DBT ring open S1 structure (a.k.a., S1(min(2))) was optimized at the TD-B3LYPG-D3BJ/CPCM/def2-TZVPD||B3LYPG-D3BJ/CPCM/def2-TZVPD level of theory in cyclohexane using an initial guess geometry that made use of the optimized nuclear coordinates of a ring open S1(min) structure reported for thiophene to which we added benzene moieties to for DBT. The guess geometry for the puckered S1 structure of DBT was also taken from the optimized S1(min) structure reported for thiophene to which we added the benzene moieties. However, optimization of this guess structure at the TD-B3LYPG-D3BJ/CPCM/def2-TZVPD||B3LYPG-D3BJ/CPCM/def2-TZVPD level of theory in cyclohexane converged to the nearly planar S1(min(1)) structure. The LIICs was done using eight linear interpolation geometries from the S1(min(1)) structure to the S1(min(2)) structure . VEE and SOC for those linear interpolated geometries were then computed at the TD-B3LYPG-D3BJ/CPCM/def2-TZVPD||B3LYPG-D3BJ/CPCM/def2-TZVPD level of theory in cyclohexane.

question: How does the presence of excess COD affect the PCy3 complex in the reaction?
answer: Excess COD causes the PCy3 complex to undergo disproportionation, forming Ni(COD)2 and (PCy3)2Ni II Br2.
context: We also found that PCy3 (%Vbur (min) = 30.2 %) could form a L1Ni I dimer (12 (L = PCy3)) from 5 with a 1:1 ratio of phosphine:Ni. In the presence of excess COD, the PCy3 complex is more prone to disproportionation-generating Ni(COD)2 and (PCy3)2Ni II Br2-than ligands with higher %Vbur (min) values. This is unsurprising given that stable L2Ni 0 and L2Ni II complexes can readily form with PCy3. Nonetheless, the ability to synthesize [(PCy3)Ni I Br]2 differs from the ligand structure-speciation trends observed in generation of the analogous Pd I dimers. Like CyP(t-Bu)2 and Cy2P(t-Bu), the L2Ni I Br monomer (13 (L = PCy3)) was readily obtained with PCy3.

question: What are the effective cavity dimensions and interlayer spacing in the sql-1-M-NCS coordination networks?
answer: The effective cavities measure 7.5 √Ö by 7.5 √Ö and the distance between the layers is 4.5 √Ö.
context: sql-1-M-NCS (M = Fe and Ni) were synthesized by heating their precursors {[M(bpy)(NCS)2(H2O)2]‚Ä¢bpy}n at 50 ¬∞C in vacuo. These precursors were prepared by a water slurry method. The crystal structures of sql-1-Co-NCS and sql-1-Ni-NCS were previously determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction and we determined the crystal structure of sql-1-Fe-NCS here by refinement of synchrotron PXRD data (Fig. and). The three sql-1-M-NCS CNs are comprised of M(II) cations coordinated to four equatorial bpy ligands and two axial NCS - ligands. Their synchrotron PXRD patterns match well (Fig. ). The effective cavity sizes (7.5 √Ö√ó 7.5 √Ö) and interlayer distance (4.5 √Ö) are equivalent, although there are subtle differences in the torsion angle of bpy ligands (54.3 -54.7¬∞) and M-M-M (75.3 -76.4¬∞) and SC-N-M (169.5 -170.9¬∞) angles (Fig. ). The terminal NCS ligands interdigitate with adjacent layers (Fig. ) to block the cavities in the closed phases of sql-1-M-NCS.

question: What did the reaction of 4-pivaloxy substituted benzoxazole 2f reveal about the reactivity of the in-situ generated alkenyl pivalate compared to the aryl-OPiv moiety?
answer: The reaction formed compound 3Af with a 61% yield and moderate regioselectivity, demonstrating that the in-situ generated alkenyl pivalate is more reactive toward the Ni/dcype catalyst than the aryl-OPiv moiety.
context: With the optimal reaction conditions in hands, we further explored the substrate scope of this reaction using 1-tetralones 4 (Scheme 2). In addition to 3Aa, this reaction allowed to synthesize 7-methoxy substituted compound 3Ba in 59% yield with good regioselectivity. Fluorine-substituted 3Ca was also generated in a moderate yield and maintained good regioselectivity. 5-Benzyloxydihydronaphthalen-2-yl benzoxazole 3Da was synthesized with a 53% yield. These results indicated that electronic and positional variations on the aromatic ring on tetralone 4 did not significantly affect this reaction progress. We then assessed of this reaction with various benzoxazoles. Both 5-phenyl-and 5-alkyl-substituted benzoxazoles underwent this reaction, giving the corresponding enloate dance/coupling products in moderate yields (3Ab, 3Ac, and 3Ad). Furthermore, 4-methoxybenzoxazole was incorporated at the C2 position, furnishing 3Ae in 58% yield with moderate regioselectivity. Notably, the potentially competitive 4-pivaloxy substituted benzoxazole 2f reacted smoothly under the present conditions, resulting in 3Af with a 61% yield and moderate regioselectivity. This finding demonstrates that the in-situ generated alkenyl pivalate exhibits higher reactivity toward Ni/dcype catalyst than the aryl-OPiv moiety. Unfortunately, other 1,3-azoles such as oxazole, benzothiazoles, and benzimidazoles were not applicable to these reaction conditions, leading to poor yields of products or no reaction (See the SI for details). Despite extensively investigations, other cyclic alkenes have not yet proven suitable for this reaction. Scheme 2. Substrate scope Conditions: 4 (0.60 mmol), 2 (0.40 mmol), Ni(dcype)(CO)2 (5.0 mol %), dcype (10 mol %), K3PO4 (3.0 equiv), Piv2O (1.5 equiv), THF (1.5 mL), 150 ¬∞C, 48 h.

question: What absolute configuration was assigned to 5-phosphahelicene 16a based on its ECD and TD-DFT spectral data?

question: What specific set of reaction conditions enabled the formation of the cyanation product in a 54% yield?
answer: The optimal procedure involved first mixing benzyl 3‚Äêhydroxypyrrolidine‚Äê1‚Äêcarboxylate with NHC-J (1.2 equiv) and pyridine (1.5 equiv) in methyl tert-butyl ether (0.1 M), followed by a filtration step. This was then irradiated with 450 nm light in the presence of tosyl cyanide (1.5 equiv), 4-CzPN (2 mol%), benzoyl peroxide (1 equiv) and 2,4,6-trimethylpyridine in a solvent mixture of MTBE/acetone/water (15:15:1) at a concentration of 0.017 M to obtain the desired cyanation product in a 54% yield.
context: Extensive optimization revealed that mixing benzyl 3hydroxypyrrolidine-1-carboxylate (1) with NHC-J (1.2 equiv) and pyridine (1.5 equiv) in methyl tert-butyl ether (MTBE) [0.1M] followed by filtration and subsequent irradiation with 450 nm light in the presence of tosyl cyanide 9 (1.5 equiv), 4-CzPN 4 (2 mol%), benzoyl peroxide (Bz2O2,1 equiv), and 2,4,6-trimethylpyridine (Me3Pyr) in a solvent mixture of MTBE/acetone/water (15:15:1) [0.017 M] afforded the desired cyanation product in 54% yield (Table , entry 1). Control experiments demonstrated that additional air is detrimental to the reaction (entry 2). The use of oxygen as the oxidant or performing the reaction in the absence of an oxidant is also detrimental (entries 3-4). Filtration of the NHC condensate mixture or using water as a co-solvent is beneficial but not necessary for the reaction (entries 5-6). At the same time, the collidine base and the photocatalyst are both essential for efficient product formation (entries 7-8).

question: What are the key reaction conditions and purification steps used to synthesize acetylferrocene, and how is its identity confirmed?
answer: In the preparation, a flame-dried flask containing aluminum chloride in anhydrous dichloromethane is cooled to 0 ¬∞C. A separate solution of ferrocene in dichloromethane is added via cannula transfer, after which acetyl chloride is added dropwise. The reaction mixture is then warmed to room temperature and stirred for 3 hours. After cooling back to 0 ¬∞C, ice water is added slowly to quench the reaction, leading to a biphasic mixture that is separated using a separation funnel. The aqueous layer is extracted with dichloromethane, and the combined organic layers are washed with brine, dried over sodium sulfate, filtered, and the volatiles removed under vacuum. This isolation procedure yields acetylferrocene as a brown solid in 84% yield, and its identity is confirmed by 1H NMR data showing signals at Œ¥ 4.77, 4.50, 4.20 for the cyclopentadienyl protons and a singlet at Œ¥ 2.40 for the acetyl methyl group.
context: A flame-dried 2 L round-bottomed flask was taken into a glovebox and charged with aluminum chloride (25.8 g, 1.2 equiv., 193.5 mmol) and anhydrous DCM (350 mL, [AlCl3] = 0.55 M) under N2. The resulting mixture was cooled to 0 ¬∞C. In a separate flame-dried 500 mL round-bottomed flask equipped with a stir bar, ferrocene (30.00 g, 1.0 equiv., 161.3 mmol) was dissolved in anhydrous DCM (350 mL, [ferrocene] = 0.45 M) under N2. The ferrocene solution was added via cannula transfer to the round-bottomed flask containing aluminum chloride. Acetyl chloride (5.06 g, 4.59 mL, 1.2 equiv., 64.5 mmol) was added dropwise and the solution was allowed to warm to room temperature and stirred for 3 h. The reaction was then cooled to 0 ¬∞C and ice water (400 mL) was slowly added, resulting in an exotherm. The biphasic mixture was allowed to warm to room temperature and transferred to a separation funnel. The aqueous layer was extracted with DCM (3 x 200 mL) and the combined organic layers were washed with brine, dried over Na2SO4, filtered, and the volatiles removed under vacuum to afford acetylferrocene (2, 30.73 g, 134.7 mmol, 84% yield) as a brown solid. H NMR data matched those reported in the literature. 1 H NMR (CDCl3, 600 MHz): ÔÅ§ 4.77 (t, J = 2.0 Hz, 2H, Cp-H), 4.50 (t, J = 2.0 Hz, 2H, Cp-H), 4.20 (s, 5H, Cp-H), 2.40 (s, 3H, C(O)-CH3).

question: What were the proportions of products present in the reaction mixture after 8 days?
answer: After 8 days, the reaction mixture contained 76% residual glycerol-1-phosphate, 20% total lysophosphatidic acids (a mixture of 2-hydroxy-3-decanoyl-glycerol-1-phosphate and 2-decanoyl-3-hydroxy-glycerol-1-phosphate), and 4% phosphatidic acid (2,3-didecanoylglycerol-1-phosphate).
context: 20 ŒºL of a 1.0 M solution of glycerol-1-phosphate sodium salt in water (G1P; 0.02 mmol) was diluted into water (0.78 mL) and D2O (0.2 mL) in a plastic Eppendorf tube. The pH of the solution was adjusted to 7.4. Separately, N-decanoyl imidazole (NDI; 44.4 mg, 0.20 mmol; 10 eq.) was dissolved in acetonitrile (1.0 mL) in a glass test tube equipped with a magnetic stirrer bead and capped with a rubber septum. The solution of G1P was added dropwise (by pipette) to the solution of NDI and the mixture was stirred vigorously (800 rpm) at room temperature. {Note: Mixing is endothermic and the drop in temperature causes some of the NDI to precipitate; it does, however, dissolve on stirring}. The reaction was monitored by P NMR (D2O), withdrawing aliquots after 24 h, 48 h, 96 h, and 8 d, and also by TLC, with plates developed in chloroform/methanol/water (65:25:4, v/v/v) and spots visualized by molybdenum blue. The presence (or absence) of NDI, decanoic acid, mixed anhydrides, and phospholipids (as observed by NMR) was confirmed at each time point. {Note: By TLC, NDI, Rf 0.9, and decanoic acid, Rf 0.8, show as white spots. Mixed anhydrides, Rf 0.6, phosphatidic acid, Rf 0.3, and lysophosphatidic acids, Rf 0.1, show as blue spots. The various mixed anhydrides and isomeric lysophosphatidic acids are not resolved. G1P is not stained by molybdenum blue}. By 96 h, NDI was completely consumed (TLC) and by 8 d mixed anhydrides were no longer visible (NMR). The mixture obtained after 8 d consisted of residual G1P (76%), 2-hydroxy-3-decanoyl-glycerol-1-phosphate and 2-decanoyl-3-hydroxy-glycerol-1-phosphate (lysophosphatidic acids; 20% total), and 2,3-didecanoylglycerol-1-phosphate (phosphatidic acid; 4%). G1P: Four mixed anhydrides were visible by P NMR between 24 and 96 h. These species appeared at -7.23, -7.62, -7.72, and -8.19 ppm respectively.

question: Which heterocyclic sulfinate provided a notably low yield when converted to its corresponding bromide product, and what was that yield?
answer: 2-pyrazole sulfinate gave a poor yield of the bromide product at 15%.
context: Many heteroaryl sulfonyl halides excelled under these protocols. Electron-rich 5-membered heterocyclic sulfinates performed best, such as thiophene 2p and 2-bromothiophene 2q, with yields ranging from 82-99% for both the iodide and bromide products. The thiophene sulfonyl BCP bromides could be prepared on 2.5 g scale from the isolated sulfonyl bromides with equally impressive 98% yields for both substrates. 3-Pyrazole sulfinate 2r was similarly successful, giving the BCP iodide and bromide 3r-I/Br in 92% and 100% yields, respectively, whereas 2-pyrazole sulfinate gave a poor yield of the bromide 3s-Br (15%). 3-Furyl sulfonyl BCP bromide 3t-Br was achieved in 53% yield using PPh3‚Ä¢Br2 complex to prepare the sulfonyl bromide in situ. Substrates containing N-nucleophilic sites proved challenging, presumably due to competing reactivity with the sulfonyl halide: 13 oxazole 2u gave a low yield of the BCP iodide 3u-I (19%) but a 67% yield of the bromide 3u-Br. Iodosulfonylation of pyridylsulfinate 2v was unsuccessful, while the pyridyl sulfonyl bromide adducts 3v-Br-3x-Br were isolated in reduced yields of 15-31%, on up to 0.5 g scale. Pleasingly, we found that the methodology could be readily applied in pharmaceutical and agrochemical settings, successfully achieving BCP derivatives of vasodilating drug sildenafil (3y-I, 84% and 3y-Br, 82%) and the rice herbicide cafenstrole (3z-I, 55% and 3z-Br, 59%).

question: What materials and process were used to prepare the catalyst ink for the anode electrodes on the proton exchange membranes?
answer: The catalyst ink was prepared by combining iridium oxide catalyst powders, isopropyl alcohol (99.9%), deionized water (18 MŒ©), and Nafion D2021 ionomer dispersion with an ionomer content of 12 wt.%. The ink was then homogenized using magnetic stirring and ultrasonication.
context: Preparation of Catalyst-Coated Membranes (CCMs): All electrodes were fabricated on Nafion¬© 115 proton exchange membrane (IonPower, USA) to have a 4 cm 2 active area. For the anodes, catalyst inks were prepared using iridium oxide catalyst powders, isopropyl alcohol (99.9 %, Kimix), deionized water (18 MŒ©, Millipore) and Nafion¬© D2021 ionomer dispersion (IonPower, USA). The ionomer content in the anodic inks was fixed at 12 wt.%. The ink suspensions were homogenized using a combination of magnetic stirring and ultrasonication.

question: What reaction conditions and catalyst load were employed to achieve the complete conversion of 4-methoxyphenyl isocyanate into N-boryl methyl amine while leaving the isothiocyanate untouched?
answer: The reaction used one equivalent of 4-methoxyphenyl isocyanate, one equivalent of 4-methoxyphenyl isothiocyanate, and three equivalents of HBpin under neat conditions with a 4 mol% load of aluminum dihydride I catalyst, resulting in the complete conversion of the isocyanate into N-boryl methyl amine.
context: Next, we analyzed the catalytic activity of aluminumdihydride I complex for intermolecular chemoselective hydrodeoxygenation reaction between isocyanate and isothiocyanate, or selenocyanate. The reaction of one equivalent 4methoxyphenyl isocyanate (4h), one equivalent 4methoxyphenyl isothiocyanate, and three equivalent HBpin under 4 mol% of compound I at neat conditions resulted in the complete transformation of 4h into N-boryl methyl amine (7h) over unreacted isothiocyanate. In addition, 4-fluorophenyl isocyanate (4m) / 4-bromophenyl isocyanate (4o) was reduced fully into corresponding N-boryl amine products (7m/7o) in comparison to untouched reducible isothiocyanate substrates under 2 mol% catalyst I load. At last, 4e was transformed into corresponding borylated N-methyl amine (7e) in 70% yield over selenocyanate under three folds of HBpin (Scheme 5).

question: How do the anti-leukemia activities of achiral compounds compare with those of enantiopure chiral quinazoline-thiohydantoin fused heterocycles, and what is their effectiveness against multidrug-resistant leukemia cells compared to doxorubicin?
answer: Achiral compounds showed no significant activity against the leukemia cell lines, while all enantiopure chiral heterocycles (with one exception) displayed high anti-leukemia effects. In particular, these chiral compounds were more effective against multidrug-resistant P glycoprotein-overexpressing cells, with IC50 values ranging from 0.127 ŒºM to 12.932 ŒºM, which is stronger than the activity of doxorubicin (IC50 = 23.27 ŒºM).
context: In order to investigate the anti-leukemia activity of novel quinazolinethiohydantoin fused heterocycles, we employed some selected examples of the synthesized quinazoline-thiohydantoin fused heterocycles against sensitive wild-type CCRF-CEM and multidrugresistant P glycoprotein-overexpressing CEM/ADR5000 cells (Table ). Interestingly, while investigated achiral compounds 3a, 3j-3l and 3n-3p showed no significant activity against the CCRF-CEM and CEM/ADR5000 cell lines, all chiral enantiopure heterocycles 5a-5c, 5f, 5g, 5j, 5k, 5n-5w (except 5u) showed high anti-leukemia effect (Table ). As a main result, the analyzed compounds exerted a stronger activity against multidrug-resistant P glycoproteinoverexpressing CEM/ADR5000 cells (the range of IC50 values was between 0.127¬±0.019 ¬µM and 12.932¬±3.563 ¬µM) than the reference drug doxorubicin (IC50 = 23.27 ¬µM). To estimate the selectivity of our novel quinazoline-thiohydantoin-fused heterocycles, we have investigated them also against healthy human peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs). Remarkably, all tested compounds were significantly less active against healthy human PBMCs, than against sensitive and multi-drug-resistant leukemia cells. The range of IC50 values in PBMCs was between 1.5¬±0.02 ŒºM and >100 ŒºM.

question: What operating mode and specific mass transitions were used for the quantification of ATX-II and ATX-I?
answer: The system was operated in multiple reaction monitoring (MRM) mode using negative electrospray ionization, with ATX-II monitored by transitions of m/z 349 ‚Üí 285 and 349 ‚Üí 331, and ATX-I by transitions of m/z 351 ‚Üí 315 and 351 ‚Üí 333.
context: LC-MS/MS analysis was performed on a high-performance liquid chromatography (UHPLC) system (UltiMate3000) coupled to a triple-quadrupole mass spectrometer (TSQ Vantage, Thermo Scientific) applying a validated method and Tracefinder TM (version 3.3) software for data evaluation. Briefly, the mass spectrometric system was operated in multiple reaction monitoring mode (MRM, quantifier/qualifier ions for ATX-II: m/z 349 -> 285/331, and for ATX-I m/z 351 -> 315/333) using negative electrospray ionization. Both altertoxins were quantified by matrix-matched calibration (ATX-II: 0.1-100 ng/mL, ATX-I: 0.2-200 ng/mL). For quality control, standards in pure solvent were included in the same sequence (10% methanol in water).

question: What method was used to produce the vesicle stock, how were the vesicle sizes confirmed, and what were the measured diameters for DMPC and DMPC/PG vesicles?

question: What reagent is used for the hydrolysis of 1-azetines to yield ethyl Œ±,Œ±-disubstituted Œ≤-aminopropionate hydrochlorides and which minor product forms when both substituents are phenyl?

question: What solvent mixture and steps were used to extract the tomato samples?
answer: Tomato fruits were chopped, homogenized, and 1.000 ¬± 0.005 g of the homogenate was extracted by adding 5 mL of a solvent mixture composed of methanol, water, and acetic acid in a 79/20/1 (v/v/v) ratio. The mixture was shaken for 60 minutes, then diluted 1:1 with a methanol/water mix (10/90, v/v), centrifuged at 20,000 rcf for 15 minutes at 4 ¬∞C, and stored at -20 ¬∞C until LC-MS/MS analysis.
context: All samples were extracted as described in . Intact tomato fruits were chopped and homogenized before applying the same procedure as for the preparation of the puree samples (see above). All homogenized samples (1.000 ¬± 0.005 g) were extracted by adding solvent (5 mL, methanol/water/acetic acid, 79/20/1, v/v/v) and shaking for 60 min using an over-head shaker (Roto-Shake Genie, Scientific Industries, USA). These extracts were subsequently diluted 1:1 with methanol/water (10/90, v/v), centrifuged (20.000 rcf, 4 ¬∞C, 15 min) and stored at -20 ¬∞C until LC-MS/MS measurement.

question: What percentages of the top performing structures are made up of the different metal nodes?
answer: Approximately 40% of the top performing structures contain the Ni-based mn1 node, around 30% contain the Ni-based mn12 node, about 8% contain the Co-based mn13 node, and roughly 5% contain the Zn-based mn2 node.
context: We find that most of the top performing structures contain the metal nodes mn1 (Ni based)-‚àº40% of the top performing structures, mn12 (Ni based)-‚àº30%, mn13 (Co based)-‚àº8%, and mn2 (Zn based)-‚àº5%. question: What crystalline calcium carbonate is produced by tunicate Herdmania momus and how does its solubility compare to calcite and aragonite?
answer: Tunicate Herdmania momus is composed of vaterite, and vaterite is about tenfold more soluble than both calcite and aragonite.
context: tunicate Herdmania momus is composed of vaterite. , Amorphous calcium carbonate, ACC, encompasses several hydrated, disordered phases that are widespread as transient phases, precursors to crystalline biominerals. Stable ACC occurs in some crustacean exoskeletons and storage organsgastroliths. , , Among the crystalline calcium carbonates, calcite is least soluble (Ksp=10 -8. ), aragonite solubility is comparable but somewhat more soluble (Ksp= 10 -8. ), and vaterite is about tenfold more soluble (Ksp=10 ). The less stable vaterite often transforms into calcite or aragonite in an aqueous solution in vitro.
