question: What structural characteristics and bond length measurements were found in the cyclo-PbP4 middle deck of compound 7?
answer: Compound 7 exhibits a triple-decker structure with a planar cyclo-PbP4 middle deck. In this structure, two P-P bonds adjacent to the Pb atom measure 2.1104(12) √Ö and 2.083(4) √Ö, the other P-P bond (between P2 and P3) falls within the typical range for a single bond, and the average P-Pb distance is 2.625(3) √Ö.
context: While the isolation of 7 and 8 as pure compounds has so far not been possible, their identity was firmly established by singecrystal X-ray analysis and multinuclear NMR spectroscopy (vide infra). Additionally, the resonances for the terphenyl-P4 butterfly complex, Dipp Ar2P4 were observed, confirming the fate of the terphenyl ligand attached to the lead centre (see Figure S43, SI). Note that these resonances are not present in the 31 P NMR spectra for the reaction of 2 with P4; in this case, the fate of the terphenyl substituent remains presently unclear. It should be noted that the one-pot reaction of E, Pb(acac)2, and P4 also forms 7, as observed in the 31 P{ 1 H} NMR spectrum, but only small amounts of crystalline material could be isolated, which were contaminated with Mg( Dep nacnac)(acac). Scheme 2. Synthesis of compound 7 and 8, reagents and conditions: i) 3 (1 equiv.), +P4 (1 equiv.)/‚îÄCOD, ‚îÄP4Ar‚Ä≤2, toluene, 55 ¬∞C, 16 h; ii) E (2 equiv.), +Pb(acac)2 (1 equiv.), P4 (1 equiv.)/‚îÄMg( Dep nacnac)(acac) (2 equiv.), ‚îÄCOD (2 equiv.), toluene, ‚îÄ30 ¬∞C to r.t., 16 h; iii) ‚îÄPb, toluene, storage at r.t.. Similar to complex 6, the molecular structure of 7 (Figure , SI) features a triple-decker structure with a planar cyclo-PbP4 middle deck. The bond lengths are similar to those observed for 6, with two short P-P bonds adjacent to the Pb atom (P1-P2 2.1104 (12) and P3-P4 2.083(4) √Ö), and a longer P2-P3 bond in the typical range for P-P single bonds. The P-Pb distances (av. P-Pb 2.625(3) √Ö) are in the typical range expected for P-Pb single bonds. The 31 P{ 1 H} NMR spectrum for 7 is in line with the molecular structure, showing a singlet at Œ¥ = 67.9 ppm and multiplet signals at Œ¥ = 18.5 and 64.9 ppm (Figure , SI).

question: How did the reaction outcomes differ between para electron-donating and electron-poor substituents on mono-substituted azobenzenes?

context: To study this method's substrate preference, we applied the conditions optimised for unsubstituted 1a to a set of mono-substituted azobenzenes (Fig ). question: What were the key steps and conditions used to prepare wastewater samples using solid phase extraction (SPE) prior to chromatographic analysis?
answer: Wastewater samples (50 mL) were first filtered through GF/F 0.7 ¬µm glass microfibre filters and spiked with 50 ng of an internal standard mix. SPE was then performed in duplicate using 60 g of Oasis HLB sorbent, which was preconditioned at 1 mL/min with 2 mL of methanol followed by 2 mL of water. The samples were loaded onto the cartridges at 5 mL/min, dried under vacuum, and the analytes were eluted with 4 mL of methanol at 1 mL/min.
context: Wastewater samples (50 mL) were filtered using GF/F glass microfibre 0.7 ¬µm filters (Whatman, Fisher Scientific, UK) and spiked with 50 ng of IS mix (50 ¬µL of a 1 ¬µg mL -1 methanolic IS solution) according to methodology by . Solid phase extraction (SPE) was performed in duplicate using 60g Oasis HLB sorbents (Waters, UK) preconditioned at 1 mL min -1 with 2 mL MeOH followed by 2 mL H2O. Samples were loaded onto cartridges at 5 mL min -1 and dried under vacuum. Analytes were eluted with 4 mL of MeOH at 1 mL min -1 . Methanolic extracts were dried under the stream of nitrogen using a TurboVap evaporator (Caliper, UK, 40 ¬∫C, N 2 , <5 psi) and dried extracts were reconstituted in 500 ¬µL 80:20 H2O:MeOH. Extracted analytes were separated using 0.2 ¬µm, 2.1 mm in-line column filter and a BEH C18 column (150 x 1.0 mm, 1.7 ¬µm particle size) (Waters, Manchester, UK) and a Waters Acquity UPLC system (Waters, Manchester, UK). 20¬µL of a wastewater extracted were injected onto the column. Separation was undertaken using methods: NCDpos method using ESI+ with mobile phase A composed of H2O:MeOH 95:5 + 0.1 % formic acid and mobile phase B: 100 % MeOH, and gradient: 0-20 min 0 %B, 20.0-26.0 min 100 %B, 26.0-26.5 min 100 %B, 26.5-34.0 min 100 %A; and NCDneg method with mobile phase A composed of H2O:MeOH 80:20 + 1mM NH4F and mobile phase B: 5:95 H2O: MeOH + 1 mM NH4F, and gradient: 0-0.5 min 0 %B, 0.5-2.5 min 60 %B, 2.5-8.0 min 100 %B, 8.0-14.0 min 100 %B, 14.0-14.1 min 100 %A, 14.1-22.5 min 100 %A. Identification and quantification of analytes was undertaken with Xevo TQD Triple Quadrupole Mass Spectrometer (Waters, Manchester, UK) equipped with an electrospray ionisation source. Nitrogen was used as the nebulising and desolvation gas, and argon as the collision gas. Analysis was performed in both ESI+ and ESI-with a capillary voltage of 3.20 kV, the desolvation temperature of 400 ¬∞C and the source temperature of 150 ¬∞C. The cone gas flow was 100 L h -1 and the desolvation gas flow was 550 L h -1 . All analytes were analysed using MRM (Table ). For ESI-, the parent ion [M-H]was selected, and for ESI+ mode, [M-H]+ was selected. The most abundant daughter ion was used for quantification and the second most for confirmation. ESM Table includes the MRMs for all analytes. Data processing was carried out using MassLynx (version 4.1, Waters) and TargetLynx software (Waters).

question: What recovery percentages were reported for Sb(V) and Sb(III) and what does this indicate about the column recovery efficiency?
answer: The recovery for Sb(V) was 100 ¬± 5% and for Sb(III) was 100 ¬± 6%, indicating complete column recovery.
context: Complete column recovery of Sb(III) and Sb(V) was confirmed using a mixed standard of 1000 ng Sb(III) from Sb2O3 and 1000 ng Sb(V) from KSb(OH)6. The recovery of Sb(V) was 100 ¬± 5% (n=4, 2œÉ) and the recovery for Sb(III) was 100 ¬± 6% (n=4, 2œÉ). question: What are the solubility properties of the synthesized PQX n-mer polymers?
answer: The PQX polymers are insoluble in CHCl3 and neutral water, but they dissolve in MeOH, DMSO, and basic water. Additionally, when present at 0.09 mM based on monomer units, they are soluble in pure water that contains various amines at concentrations above 0.2 mM.
context: The PQX n-mers, P1(n) and P2(n), bearing achiral carboxymethoxymethyl and carboxyethoxymethyl, respectively, were prepared by living polymerization of achiral monomers having the corresponding ester side chains using an organonickel initiator, followed by hydrolysis (Scheme 1). In this study, P1(40), P1(100), and P2(40) were synthesized. These polymers are insoluble in CHCl3 and neutral water, but soluble in MeOH, DMSO, and basic water. P1 and P2 (0.09 mM based on monomer units) were found to be soluble in pure water containing various amines (>0.2 mM).

question: What are the EC50 values of the most potent artesunic acid-derived and quinoline-adamantane hybrids in cultured-cell-based models, and how do these values compare to standard treatments?
answer: The artesunic acid-derived hybrid 7 exhibits an EC50 of 7.8 ¬µM, while its parent compound has an EC50 greater than 50 ¬µM. The quinoline-adamantane hybrid 15 shows an EC50 of 1.5 ¬µM, which is more potent than chloroquine and remdesivir, with EC50 values of 3.8 ¬µM and 4.0 ¬µM, respectively.
context: In the present study, we demonstrate that these new hybrid compounds are indeed highly efficacious in cultured-cell-based SARS-CoV-2 models. The most active artesunic acid-derived hybrid 7 (EC 50 = 7.8 ¬µM) is, e.g., significantly more potent in vitro than its parent compound artesunic acid (EC 50 >50 ¬µM). Among the quinoline-based hybrids, quinoline-adamantane 15 (EC 50 = 1.5 ŒºM) is the most efficient agent in vitro, outperforming both reference drugs chloroquine (EC 50 = 3.8 ¬µM) and remdesivir (EC 50 = 4.0 ¬µM). Remarkably, the new hybrid compounds show low or no cytotoxic effects on Vero E6 cells (CC 50 up to 110 ¬µM), which are used as a model for SARS-CoV-2 susceptible cells.

question: Which device achieved the highest maximum external quantum efficiency and what was its electroluminescence peak wavelength?
answer: The device based on CzpPhTrz reached an EQEmax of 17% and emitted at 480 nm.
context: The dominant molecular designs for PCP-containing TADF emitters are those with PCP-fused N-heterocyclic donors. The [2]paracyclo[2]-(1,4)carbazolophane (Czp) was introduced as a sterically more demanding and stronger donor that produces emitters with smaller DEST compared to analogues using carbazole (Cz). Compounds CzpPhTrz, CNCzpPhTrz and CF3CzpPhTrz emit at ŒªPL of 482, 458, and 456 nm and all have high –§PL of up to 70% in 10 wt% doped films in bis[2-(diphenylphosphino)phenyl] ether oxide (DPEPO) or 2,8bis(diphenylphosphoryl)dibenzo [b,d]thiophene (PPT). The enantiomers of CzpPhTrz emit CPL with |gPL| of 1.3 √ó 10 -3 . OLEDs with the latter two emitted at ŒªEL of around 460 nm and showed EQEmax of 7.4 and 12%, respectively. The devices suffered from severe efficiency roll-off resulting from the long œÑd of 135 and 158 Œºs, respectively, and possible degradation as a new emission band at longer wavelength was observed under electrical excitation. The device with CzpPhTrz emitted at ŒªEL of 480 nm and reached an EQEmax of 17%. The analogous phenoxazine-derived PCP, PXZp-Ph-Trz, has also been reported where the enantiomers emit CPL with |gPL| of 3.3 √ó 10 -3 . The solution-processed CP-OLEDs emitted at ŒªEL of 560 nm, showed an EQEmax of 7.8% and an electroluminescence dissymmetry factor |gEL| of 4.6 √ó 10 -3 .

question: How does the dialkylation method achieve high selectivity and broad functional group compatibility?
answer: The reaction utilizes optimized conditions where unactivated alkenes are reacted with electrophilic alkyl iodides to form products with tertiary or quaternary centers in up to 92% yield and greater than 20:1 regioisomeric ratios. This approach tolerates a wide range of functional groups including esters, various alkyl halides (bromides, tosylates, iodides), (hetero)aryl halides, amides, silanes, phosphine oxides, phthalimides, epoxides, carbonates, acetals, alkynes, silyl ethers, and heterocycles, demonstrating both significant chemoselectivity and versatility in catalysis.
context: With the optimized conditions in hand, we began to evaluate the reaction scope using unactivated alkenes of different substitution patterns (Table ). In the presence of 3a and electrophilic alkyl iodides 2aÔÄ≠d, dialkylation proceeded smoothly to furnish the desired products 4aÔÄ≠4ao bearing tertiary or quaternary carbon centers in excellent chemoselectivity with up to 92% yield and >20:1 regioisomeric ratios (r.r.). Terminal alkenes containing a vast array of common acidic and basic functional groups such as ester (4b, 4m, 4q, 4s, 4vÔÄ≠x), alkyl bromide (4e), alkyl tosylate (4f), alkyl iodide (4m), (hetero)aryl halide (4v, 4x), amide (4g), silane (4h), phosphine oxide (4i), phthalimide (4j), epoxide (4k), carbonate (4l), acetal (4o), alkyne (4r), silyl ether (4t) and heterocycles (4n, 4p, 4u, 4wÔÄ≠y) are well-tolerated in our system. Remarkably, sp 3and sp 2 -hybridized organohalides (4e, 4f, 4m, 4v, 4x) which are typically prone to reaction with low-valent nickel species 17 did not interfere with dialkylation, providing complementarity to established catalytic regimes (see Scheme 1) and facilitating access to molecules with useful halogen handles for downstream functionalizations. 18 3a (2.0 equiv) PhCF 3 ( Sterically demanding internal alkenes which sometimes pose reactivity challenges in Ni catalysis 12f also served as effective substrates for SH2-enabled alkene cross-coupling. Cyclic and acyclic 1,2-disubstituted (4z, 4ad), trisubstituted (4aa, 4ab) and even tetrasubstituted (4ac) C=C bonds are amenable to dialkylation, although regioand diastereochemical control prove difficult in some cases. To further showcase functional group compatibility, we extended the catalytic dialkylation manifold to the late-stage functionalization of alkenes embedded within or appended to multifunctional bioactive compounds. Gratifyingly, dialkylated products 4aeÔÄ≠4am were secured in good yields and site selectivities, highlighting the robustness of our transformation towards the construction of complex C(sp 3 )-rich architectures at advanced stages of synthetic processes. The reactions affording 4agÔÄ≠ai and 4ak took place selectively at the sterically less hindered C=C bond. It merits mention that there was no competitive addition of the intermediate open-shell species to the electron-deficient ÔÅ∞-bonds of ÔÅ°ÔÄ¨ÔÅ¢-unsaturated carbonyl units in 4agÔÄ≠ai, underscoring the remarkable chemoselectivity. Notably, when dialkylation was executed on alkenes with neighboring strained four-membered rings such as natural products Œ±-pinene and caryophyllene oxide, ring-opening was observed to give 4an and 4ao, respectively. These results suggest the plausible intermediacy of cyclobutylcarbinyl radicals generated by initial addition of the iodoalkane-derived electrophilic radical, which are susceptible to ring cleavage before the second C(sp 3 )-C(sp 3 ) bond-forming event.

question: How do the geometries of the reactive centers differ between the 5- or 6-membered cyclization and the 5-membered cyclization via RC_18_00?
answer: 5- or 6-membered cyclization occurs only at trigonal centers, while the 5-membered cyclization via RC_18_00 takes place exclusively at tetrahedral centers.
context: In 193 cases of exocyclic ring‚áåchain transformations, the ring closing/opening takes place at trigonal or tetrahedral centers. 5-or 6-membered cyclization occurs only at trigonal centers while 5-membered cyclization via RC_18_00 takes place only at tetrahedral centers. There are some instances of ring‚áåchain tautomerism in the thiadiazoline (RC_14_00), boryl/borate (RC_16_00 and RC_17_00), and Œª 5 /Œª 3 -phosphane (RC_24_00) systems that do not involve any unsaturated electrophilic center (or endo-or exo-cyclic bonds) during interconversions but rather involve saturated sulfur, boron, and phosphorus centers, respectively.

question: What are the different reactivities of the two types of 1,2-dimetalloalkenes generated by the new method?
answer: The 1,2-dimagnesioalkenes react as ‚Äú1,2‚Äêbis(Grignard)‚Äù reagents with various electrophiles to form multi‚Äêsubstituted alkenes, while the 1,2-dialumino-1arylalkenes react with aldehydes, resulting in the dearomatization of the aryl moiety.
context: Fig. of 1,2-dimetalloalkenes. a, Generation of polar organometallic species by deprotonation of relatively acidic protons from hydrocarbons (left) and halogen-metal exchange or reductive metalation of organic halides (right). b, Hydrometalation and carbometalation of unsaturated compounds provide the corresponding monometalated polar organometallics. c, 1,2-Dimetalloalkenes generated by two-electron reduction of alkynes can work as a versatile precursor for multi-substituted alkenes. d, 1,2-Dilithio-and 1,2disodioalkenes are too unstable to be utilized as synthetic intermediates. e, There is only one example of an isolated monomeric 1,2-dimagnesioalkene reported by Jones et al. However, synthetic utilities of the species are not fully demonstrated. f, Our work: developing a method for 1,2-dimagnesiation and 1,2-dialumination of alkynes. The generated 1,2-dimetalloalkenes are isolated and structurally characterized. 1,2-Dimagnesioalkenes work as "1,2-bis(Grignard)" reagents towards various electrophiles to provide multi-substituted alkenes. 1,2-Dialumino-1arylalkenes react with aldehydes accompanied by dearomatization of the aryl moiety.

question: How does the reduction potential of sulfone donor 6 influence its effectiveness compared to sulfone donors 4 and 5 in achieving high efficiency for the N-glycosylation reaction?
answer: Sulfone donor 6 has a reduction potential of -1.48 V, making it considerably more reducible than sulfone donor 4 (-1.82 V) and sulfone donor 5 (-1.70 V). This higher reducibility, which aligns well with the reduction potential of photocatalyst PC1 (-1.51 V), is crucial for its effective reaction to produce product 3 under the standard conditions.
context: Control experiments showed that the choice of sulfone donor, the reducing ability of the photocatalyst, Cu(I) catalyst, BTMG base, and photoirradiation were critical to achieving high efficiency for the N-glycosylation. Reduction potential measurements vs. SCE in CH3CN indicated that the BthSO2 donor 6 (E1/2 red = -1.48V) is considerably more reducible than 2-pyridyl sulfone 4 (E1/2 red = -1.82V) and phenyl sulfone 5 (E1/2 red = -1.70V). Neither 4 nor 5 can react with 2 to give 3 under our standard conditions. The reduction potential of PC1 ((E1/2 red [Ir III /Ir II ] = -1.51 V) matches well with sulfone donor 6. PC2 fac-Ir(ppy)3 (E1/2 red [Ir III /Ir II ] = -2.19 V) is slightly less effective but also worked well (entry 12). The addition of photocatalysts like [Ir(dtbbpy)(dFppy)2]PF6 (PC3), [Ir(dF(CF3)ppy)2 dtbbpy]PF6 (PC4), Ru(bpy)3Cl2 (PC5), or eosin Y (PC6) gave lower yields of 3 than the standalone Cu catalysis (entries 13-16 vs. 3). The combination of PC2 and chloride donor 1 did not furnish any product 3 under various conditions, indicating the importance of a delicate interplay between the Cu-mediated and photocatalystmediated pathways. No conversion of 6 took place in the absence of LED irradiation (entry 7). Irradiation with green LED gave a slightly lower yield of 3 than blue LED (entry 20). A sufficiently strong base was necessary for high efficiency. Both BTMG (pKa = 23.6 in MeCN) and 1,8-diazabicyclo(5.4.0)undec-7-ene (DBU, pKa = 24.3 in MeCN) could promote this reaction, but DBU exhibited lower reactivity (entry 17). Product 3 was formed in <5% yield when Et3N or K2CO3 was used as the base (entries 18, 19). Other Cu catalysts could also work but were not as effective as Cu(MeCN)4PF6 (See Supplementary Table ). The use of dtbbpy ligand boosted the yield but was not essential (entries 10 vs. 1 and Supplementary Table ). The reaction worked best in halogenated hydrocarbon solvents. CH3CN and THF provided little amounts of the desired product (entry 21 and Supplementary Table & S5). The performance of the reaction diminished under air atmosphere (entry 23). Interestingly, water was well-tolerated, and the reaction in the biphasic medium of DCM and H2O (v/v = 1:1) gave similar results (~83% yield of 3, entry 22). Trace amounts of side product 8 were formed under most of the conditions tested.

question: Which attachment mechanism in the coalescence of Cu3O4 clusters is more energetically and kinetically favored, and what are its adsorption and diffusion energy values?
answer: The perpendicular attachment mechanism is favored, having an adsorption energy (Eads) of +0.05 eV and a diffusion barrier (Ediff) of +0.61 eV.
context: In modeling the coalescence of Cu3O4 into larger clusters (T-Cu2O), we evaluated the attachment dynamics of a moving Cu3O4 to a static dormant Cu3O4, comparing perpendicular and parallel orientations. The energetically and kinetically superior perpendicular attachment mechanism (Eads = +0.05 eV, Ediff = +0.61 eV; Figs. ) contrasts with the less favored parallel attachment (Eads = +0.42 eV, Ediff = +0.99 eV; Fig. ). This model necessitates O atom detachment to finalize the coalescence into stoichiometric hexagonal overlayers. Interestingly, diffusion of excess O, that results in O detachment, demonstrates a preference for a parallel path (ŒîEads = -0.9 eV; Figs. ), as opposed to an unfavorable perpendicular diffusion (ŒîEads = +0.05 eV; Fig. ).

question: What are the BET surface areas of HCzRhMOP and BnCzRhMOP, and what type of porosity do their N2 sorption isotherms indicate?
answer: HCzRhMOP has a BET surface area of 877 m¬≤/g and BnCzRhMOP has 319 m¬≤/g; their type I sorption isotherms reveal that both materials have microporosity.
context: To reveal the structure-porosity relationship, we first compared the N2 sorption isotherms of HCzRhMOP and BnCzRhMOP measured at 77 K (Figs. and). Both HCzRhMOP and BnCzRhMOP show type I sorption isotherms, which indicates that both MOP amorphous solids have microporosity. The total uptake at P/P0 ‚âà 1 in HCzRhMOP (283 cm 3 (STP) g -1 ) is higher than that in BnCzRhMOP (121 cm 3 (STP) g -1 ). The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface areas of HCzRhMOP and BnCzRhMOP are calculated to be 877 and 319 m 2 g -1 by BETSI 27 (Table ).

question: Which quinoline-based hybrid compound demonstrated the greatest activity against SARS-CoV-2, and what were its EC50 and selectivity index values?
answer: Compound 15 exhibited the highest activity among quinoline-based hybrids with an EC50 of 1.5 ¬± 0.5 ŒºM and a selectivity index of 3.9.
context: All new artesunic acid-containing hybrid compounds 2-7 show activity against SARS-CoV-2 (EC 50 values 7.8 -46 ŒºM) and low or no toxicity at the effective concentrations, indicated by SI (selectivity index) values up to 8.5. The morpholine-containing derivative 7 shows the highest activity (EC 50 = 7.8 ¬± 3.0 ¬µM) with a SI value of 3.2. The morpholine moiety may improve the activity against SARS-CoV-2 due to its basic nature. Among quinoline-based hybrids 8-15, compound 15 was the most active (EC 50 = 1.5 ¬± 0.5 ¬µM and SI = 3.9, see Table and 4).

question: What initial steps were taken in the synthesis, specifically regarding the order of reagent addition and stirring duration?
answer: First, an aqueous solution of trisodium citrate dehydrate and then an aqueous solution of HAuCl4‚Ä¢3H2O were added into 788 mL of water, and the mixture was stirred for approximately 15 minutes.
context: For scale-up production, aqueous solution of trisodium citrate dehydrate (400 mM, 4 mL) and HAuCl 4 ‚Ä¢3H 2 O (32.5 mM, 4.92 mL) were added successively in 788 mL water and stirred for ~15 min. Then freshly prepared NaBH 4 aqueous solution (200 mM, 3.2 mL) was rapidly injected in the above mixture, followed by stirring for 30~60 min. Afterwards, aqueous solution of NH 4 F (1 M, 88.9 mL) was quickly added, stirring for ~20 s, followed by grounding ~12 h to allow complete reaction.

question: What staining methods and assessment techniques were utilized to evaluate the tissue response at the injection site in the animal study?
answer: The evaluation involved HES-stained sections for tissue morphology, immunofluorescence using primary antibodies anti-CD3 and anti-Ly6G to detect specific immune cells, and toluidine blue staining for mast cell detection. Additionally, histopathological scoring (H-Score) was used to quantify tissue inflammation and necrotic changes, along with measurements of the epidermis thickness.

Representative immunofluorescence images of skin sections after 14 days of mice at the injection site after SC administration of: c, Gem and d, Gem-PAAm P7 at 500 mg.kg -1 , using primary antibodies anti-CD3 and anti-Ly6G, and toluidine blue staining for the detection of mast cells respectively. e, Histopathological scoring (H-Score) of tissular inflammation in mice after SC injection of Gem at 1 000, 650 and 500 mg.kg -1 , Gem-PAAm P7 at 650, 500 and 60 mg.kg -1 , Gem-P(AAm-co-BMDO) P2 and P3 at 60 mg.kg -1 , P(AAm-co-BMDO) P5 and P6 at 15 mg.kg -1 and PBS. The values are expressed as the means ¬± SD (n = 3). Unpaired two-tailed t-test; *p < 0.01 (Table ). f, Histopathological scoring (H-Score) of necrotic changes in mice after SC injection of Gem at 1 000, 650 and 500 mg.kg -1 , Gem-PAAm P7 at 650, 500 and 60 mg.kg -1 and PBS. The values are expressed as the means ¬± SD (n = 3). Unpaired two-tailed t-test; ****p < 0.0001 (Table ). g, Measurement of the epidermis' thickness from HES-stained sections of skin sections after 14 days after SC administration of Gem at 1 000, 650 and 500 mg.kg -1 , Gem-PAAm P7 at 650, 500 and 60 mg.kg -1 , Gem-P(AAm-co-BMDO) P2 and P3 at 60 mg.kg -1 , P(AAm-co-BMDO) P5 and P6 at 15 mg.kg -1 and PBS. The values are expressed as the means ¬± SD after 10 measurements per sample (n = 3). h, Representative HESstained sections of skin sections after 14 days of mice at the injection site after SC administration of PBS.

question: What are the two datasets mentioned and how does each dataset provide binding affinity information?
answer: One dataset covers multiple targets with measured binding affinities and is also known as the PDBBind 2016 core set, while the other dataset consists of inhibitors of human Œ≤-secretase 1 and provides binding affinity data in two formats: quantitative IC50 values and qualitative binary labels.
context: Both the CASF2016 and the BACE datasets (BACE-c: classification, BACE-r: regression) report measured binding affinities. The CASF2016 (also sometimes referred to as PDBBind 2016 core set) covers multiple targets, the BACE dataset is a set of inhibitors of human Œ≤-secretase 1 (BACE-1) with both quantitative (IC50) labels (here: BACE-r) and qualitative binary labels (here: BACE-c).

question: How does varying the number of benzyl groups in the octahedral Rh(II)-based MOPs affect their microporosity?
answer: Increasing the number of benzyl groups in the MOPs leads to a linear increase in porosity, demonstrating that the systematic variation of ligand composition influences the packing arrangement and resulting microporosities.
context: Here we show another approach to tuning the microporosity in the amorphous solids of MOPs by systematically changing the composition of two mixed ligands in a series of MOPs. We chose an octahedral-type MOP because of its simpler geometry and fewer numbers of components than the prototypical cuboctahedral MOP. We newly synthesized two octahedral Rh(II)-based MOPs with 9H-carbazole dicarboxylate derivatives: [Rh12(HCz)12] (HCzRhMOP) and [Rh12(BnCz)12] (BnCzRhMOP), HCz = 9H-carbazole-3,6-dicarboxylate and BnCz = 9-benzyl-9H-carbazole-3,6-dicarboxylate. To tune the interaction between the MOPs, we further synthesized mixed-ligand H/BnCzRhMOPs of [Rh12(HCz)12-x(BnCz)x] in various ratios of HCz and BnCz (x = 1, 3, 6, 9 and 11 for HCz/BnCz = 11/1, 9/3, 6/6, 3/9 and 1/11, respectively). HCzRhMOP, H/BnCzRhMOPs and BnCzRhMOP showed the linear correlation of their porosity with the number of the benzyl groups. These results indicate that the systematic variation of MOP compositions highly influences the packing arrangement of MOPs and the resulting microporosities (Fig. ). HCzRhMOP and BnCzRhMOP were synthesized by the reactions of [Rh2(acetate)4(methanol)2] with either H2HCz for HCzRhMOP or H2BnCz for BnCzRhMOP in N,N-dimethyl acetamide (DMA) heated at 120¬∞C. The diamagnetic nature of Rh2 paddlewheels allows us to monitor the reaction of the synthesis of HCzRhMOP by 1 H NMR spectroscopy and to optimize the reaction time to be 24 h (Fig. ). BnCzRhMOP was synthesized in 6 h according to the monitoring of the synthetic reaction of BnCzRhMOP (Fig. ).

question: How do the NMBE values for BC compared to those for PM2.5 reflect the model's performance in estimating concentrations?
answer: The significantly larger NMBE for BC, with values of -0.65 in winter and -0.69 in summer compared to -0.08 and 0.01 for PM2.5, indicates that the model underestimates BC.
context: In Addis Ababa, NRMSE is high for BC in both seasons (winter: 1.14, summer: 1.03). The correlation between the model and the ground data for BC is slightly higher in winter (R 2 = 0.34) than summer (R 2 = 0.42). The NMBE for BC (winter: -0.65, summer: -0.69) is significantly larger than for PM2.5 (winter: -0.08, summer: 0.01) indicating that the model underestimates BC.

question: What are the specific plasmids and their respective amounts used for transfecting HEK293 cells in the NanoBiT-based G-protein dissociation assay?
answer: HEK293 cells were transfected with 1000 ng of ssHF-DOR plasmid, 500 ng of GŒ±-LgBiT plasmid, 2500 ng of GŒ≤1 plasmid, and 2500 ng of SmBiT-GŒ≥2 (C68S) plasmid.
context: Ligand-induced G-protein dissociation was measured using the NanoBiT-based G-proteindissociation assay, in which the interaction between a GŒ± subunit and a GŒ≤Œ≥ subunit was monitored by the NanoBiT system (Promega). Specifically, the interaction between the GŒ±i1 subunit fused with a large fragment (LgBiT) at the Œ±-helical domain (between residues 91 and 92 of GŒ±i1; GŒ±i1-LgBiT) and the Nterminally small fragment (SmBiT)-fused GŒ≥2 subunit with a C68S mutation (SmBiT-GŒ≥2-CS) was examined. HEK293 cells in a 10 cm dish were transfected with a mixture of 1000 ng of ssHF-DOR plasmid, 500 ng of GŒ±-LgBiT plasmid, 2500 ng of GŒ≤1 plasmid, and 2500 ng of SmBiT-GŒ≥2 (C68S) plasmid. After incubation for 24 h, the transfected cells were collected with 0.53 mM EDTA-containing PBS, centrifuged at 190 g for 5 min and suspended in 2 mL of Hanks' Balanced Salt Solution (HBSS) containing 0.01% bovine serum albumin (BSA; fatty-acid-free grade; SERVA) and 5 mM HEPES (pH = 7.4) (assay buffer).

question: What compound is produced by reacting 2,4-dichloro-3-(trifluoromethyl)aniline through diazotization with sodium nitrite followed by treatment with sodium azide and subsequent basification?
answer: 1-azido-2,4-dichloro-3-(trifluoromethyl)benzene
context: Step 1: 2,4-Dichloro-3-(trifluoromethyl)aniline (4) (20.0 g, 87.0 mmol, 1.0 equiv.) was dissolved in 2,2,2trifluoroacetic acid (400 mL) under nitrogen and the mixture was cooled to 0 o C with efficient stirring. Sodium nitrite (7.30 mol/L, 56.5 mL, 412 mmol, 4.8 equiv.) in water was added dropwise over 90 min. whilst maintaining the reaction mixture at ca. 0 o C throughout. The mixture was stirred at 0 o C for an additional 30 min., the ice bath was removed, and mixture allowed to warm slowly for 1 h (final temp. 5-10 o C). The solution of the diazonium salt was re-cooled to 0 o C, and sodium azide (3.85 mol/L, 107 mL, 412 mmol, 4.8 equiv.) in water was added dropwise over ca. 90 min., keeping the reaction temperature below 0 o C throughout. The reaction mixture was left in the ice bath and allowed to warm slowly to RT overnight. The solution of azide 7 in TFA-water was cooled to 0 o C and basified with the dropwise addition of aqueous sodium hydroxide (5.00 mol/L, 1045 mL, 5.23 mol) over ca. 5 h whilst maintaining the temperature at 0 o C. The mixture was warmed to RT, diluted with brine (500 mL) and extracted into Et2O (3 x 700 mL). The combined organic extracts were dried (MgSO4) and partially concentrated in vacuo (water bath set to 24 o C) to a volume of ca. 250 mL. tert-BuOH (200 mL) was then added, and the mixture evaporated until final traces of Et2O have been removed to give 1-azido-2,4-dichloro-3-(trifluoromethyl)benzene (7) as solution in tert-BuOH (119 g total weight), which was used directly in the next step. 1 H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) Œ¥ 7.45 (dd, J = 8.8, 0.8 Hz, 1H), 7.26 (dd, J = 8.7, 0.7 Hz, 1H); LCMS (method 1): Rt 1.97 minutes, 100%.

question: Which probe achieved the highest signal-to-noise ratio and what modification contributed to its superior performance?
answer: Probe 3 achieved a signal-to-noise ratio of 7.8 because it incorporated an azetidine substitution while lacking a methoxy substituent, resulting in increased brightness and improved voltage-dependent fluorescence.
context: Probes 3, 4 and 5 carrying modified variants of the dsRVF-type VSD exhibited improved voltage sensitivity, all in the range of 16.7-18.0% ÔÅÑF/F per 100 mV compared to PEG-supported dsRVF5 probe 2 (P < 0.0001, two-tailed unpaired t-test; Figure , Table ). Despite the similar ÔÅÑF/F per 100 mV for probes 3-5, probe 3 containing the brightest, azetidine substituted and non-methoxylated dsRVF4 VSD provided voltage-dependent fluorescence with the highest SNR of 7.8, a 2.6-fold increase compared to the less bright reference dsRVF5-containing probe 2 (SNR = 3.0). Also probe 5 (SNR = 5.5), containing both œÄwire methoxylation and azetidine-substitution of the xanthene core [dsRVF4(OMe)], proved superior to the dsRVF5(OMe)-containing probe 4 (SNR = 3.9), highlighting the importance of increased brightness originating from the azetidine-substituted chromophore. Nevertheless, the effective sensitivity of probe 5 remained lower than that of probe 3, which lacks a methoxy substituent on the œÄ-wire.

question: Which solvent and base were used during the nucleophilic aromatic polycondensation to synthesize the high molecular weight random copolymers?

context: High molecular weight (Œ∑ inh >0.50 dL g -1 ) random copolymers 11 to 15, containing sulfonatable 2,8-dioxydibenzofuran units (Chart 3), were synthesised by nucleophilic aromatic polycondensation of the activated difluoro-monomers 3 to 6 (Chart 1) with various combinations of the bisphenols 2,8-dihydroxydibenzofuran (1) and 4,4'-dihydroxybenzophenone (2) in diphenylsulfone as solvent, using potassium carbonate as the base, at 320 ¬∞C. The relative proportions of 'non-sulfonatable' monomer 2 and 'sulfonatable' monomer 1 in these copolymers (Table ) would, after sulfonation, go on to define the equivalent weights and ion-exchange capacities of the final ionomers. question: What intermediate is formed when the elongated unsaturated Weinreb amide (E)-20a reacts with a sulfoxonium ylide, and what subsequent transformations does it undergo?
answer: The reaction produces the cyclopropane trans-22, which is then reduced to the aldehyde trans-15r. This aldehyde is subsequently elongated to form trans-(E)-16r, and after a second cyclopropanation reaction, a mixture of trans-syn-trans-23 and trans-anti-trans-23 is obtained.
context: As a second application of successive elongation, we conducted the synthesis of a polycyclopropane (Scheme 5). 22 Some natural products, such as Jawsamycin (FR-900848) 23 and U106305, 24 contain a polycyclopropane structure. As a model substrate, we subjected the elongated unsaturated Weinreb amide (E)-20a to the cyclopropanation reaction. The reaction of (E)-20a with a sulfoxonium ylide gave cyclopropane trans-22, which was reduced to aldehyde trans-15r. This aldehyde was elongated again under our optimized conditions to give trans-(E)-16r. The obtained trans-(E)-16r was subjected to a second cyclopropanation reaction to afford a mixture of trans-syn-trans-23 and trans-anti-trans-23, in which two cyclopropane rings are directly linked. (Z)-20 is (Z,Z)-20ac and (E,Z)-20ac, and they were not detected. The ratio of E/Z is the ratio of (E,E)-20ac/other geometric isomers. k) 1 (4.0 equiv), i PrMgCl (3.6 equiv), reflux, 6 h. l) Yield of (E,E)-20ad,ae and (Z,Z)-20ad,ae. The ratio of E/Z is the ratio of (E,E)-20ad,ae/(E,Z)-20ad,ae.

question: What mass error threshold was applied across the entire mass range for spatial lipidomics annotations?
answer: A 3 ppm error threshold was applied.
context: All .RAW mass spectrometry files and .xml geometry files were ingested into SCiLS Lab Premium (v.2021c; Bruker Daltonics, Bremen, DE) for visualization of datasets using automatic ingest settings. All processing of spectra was completed within Mozaic (v.2023.4.0.b3; Spectroswiss, Lausanne, CH) or Freesytle (v.1.4; Thermo Scientific, Bremen, DE), where annotations were compiled after conversion to .imzML/.ibd format and submission to METASPACE. Annotations were processed with 3 ppm error throughout the entire mass range for spatial lipidomics, and were searched against HMDB v4, CoreMetabolome v3, LIPID MAPS -2017-12-12, and SwissLipids -2018-02-02 where datasets are publically available to browse annotations. Any annotations for spatial proteomics utilized experimental databases and IsoMatchMS for annotation of spectral peaks from averaged data.

question: What are the IC50 values of EGCG, myricetin, and theaflavin for inhibiting the M pro enzyme?
answer: EGCG has an IC50 of 0.4 ¬µM, myricetin has an IC50 of 0.9 ¬µM, and theaflavin has an IC50 of 6 ¬µM.
context: To examine the inhibitory effect of 37 phytochemicals on M pro (MBP-tagged M pro ), Dabcyl-KTSAVLQSGFRKME-Edans was used as a substrate, and the formed cleaved peptide (SGFRKME-Edans) was then estimated using an HPLC fluorescence At 20 ¬µM, several phytochemicals had a considerable suppressive effect on the protease activity of the enzyme (0.5 ¬µM) (Fig. ). However, quercetin, pectolinarin, rutin, and cyanidine-3-glucoside, in which their inhibitory activity to M pro has already been reported, did not show suppressive effect at the concentration examined (20 ¬µM).

question: What are the measured M-N distances in the complexes, and how do the values for the curium complex compare with those of its gadolinium and samarium analogues?
answer: The measured M-N distances are 2.626(3) √Ö for the samarium complex, 2.592(3) √Ö for the gadolinium complex, and 2.5962 √Ö for the curium complex. The curium complex has an M-N distance that is within error of the gadolinium analogue but is notably shorter than that of the samarium analogue.
context: 1-Sm, 1-Gd, and 1-Cm possess M-N distances of 2.626(3) √Ö, 2.592(3) √Ö, and 2.5962( ) √Ö, respectively. Surprisingly, the M-N distance observed in 1-Cm is within error of the 4f congener, 1-Gd, but is substantially shorter than its ionic radii-based analogue, 1-Sm. The M-N distance presented in 1-Sm is slightly shorter than that of a similar molecule, Cp3Sm(py) (py = pyridine), 2.656(3) √Ö. A longer distance would be anticipated in 1-Sm based on the provided steric bulk from the trimethylsilyl groups of Cp‚Ä≤ competing with 4,4‚Ä≤-bpy. However, 1-Gd exhibits a notable longer Gd-N distance in comparison to that reported in Cp3Gd(NH3), 2.501(6) √Ö, due to the significantly smaller size of the coordinated NH3. As there has been no single-crystal structural characterization of organometallic curium to date, comparison to similar coordination environments proves challenging. The Cm-N distance of 1-Cm is greater than those reported in Cm(HDPA)3‚Ä¢H2O (H2DPA = 2,6-pyridinedicarboxylic acid) but less than Cm(S2CNEt2)3(N2C12H8). The average Cm-N distance of Cm(HDPA)3 is 2.541(4) √Ö Scheme 1. Addition of 4,4‚Ä≤-bpy to two equivalents of Cp‚Ä≤3M (M = Sm, Gd, Cm) yields (Cp‚Ä≤3M)2(Œº-4,4‚Ä≤-bpy). and 2.550(4) √Ö for the Œõ and Œî enantiomers, respectively, and the reported Cm-N distance Cm(S2CNEt2)3(N2C12H8) is 2.601(6) √Ö. Curium sets a trend for these bridged organometallic actinide systems in the trivalent state. Previously reported values of isostructural systems containing uranium and americium possess notably longer M-N bonds than 1-Cm: 2.626(7) √Ö, 2.618(2) √Ö, and 2.5962 (16) √Ö respectively, introducing a trend of decreasing M-N distances across the actinide series. This trend excludes thorium owing to its low stability in the trivalent state, resulting in the reduction of 4,4‚Ä≤-bpy and oxidation to Th 4+ . The M-Cent (Cent = Centroid) bond distances observed in 1-Sm, 1-Gd, and 1-Cm are 2.516(3) √Ö, 2.498(4) √Ö, and 2.517(3) √Ö, respectively. Distorted symmetry and steric competition resulting from the increased coordination number causes a deviation in M-Cent distances compared to their Cp‚Ä≤3M counterparts (Table ). A range of M-Cent distances from 2.498(2) √Ö to 2.538(2) √Ö is seen in 1-Cm, 2.496(3) √Ö to 2.537(3) √Ö in 1-Sm, and 2.477(4) √Ö to 2.523(4) √Ö in 1-Gd, presenting a statistically significant variation of about 0.04 √Ö in all three molecules. A decrease in M-Centavg is observed in comparison to isostructural uranium and americium systems. The average M-Cent length and range observed in 1-Gd are longer and spread over a broader range compared to the reported M-Cent distance range seen in Cp‚Ä≤3Gd, 2.434 √Ö -2.441 √Ö owing to increased coordination. Similarly, the Cent-M-Cent angles of 1-Sm, 1-Gd, and 1-Cm are lower than the reported Cent-M-Cent angles of Cp‚Ä≤3M (M = lanthanide), due to the effect of 4,4‚Ä≤-bpy on the coordination environment. The observed average Cent-M-Cent angle in 1-Cm is 117.3¬∞. The Cent-M-N angles of 1-Cm range from 93.761¬∞ to 103.628¬∞. This considerable difference can be attributed to the bulkiness of the trimethylsilyl groups of Cp‚Ä≤. Additionally, 4,4‚Ä≤-bpy is angled downward at just over 9¬∞, that is likely due to an interaction between hydrogen from the trimethylsilyl groups and nitrogen on the bridge.

question: What are the adsorption mechanisms that enable magnetic biochar to remove various organic pollutants such as antibiotics, dyes, and pesticides?
answer: Magnetic biochar removes organic pollutants through hydrogen bonding, œÄ-œÄ interactions, pore-filling effects, electrostatic adsorption, hydrophobic interactions, and additionally reductive dehalogenation when needed.
context: Yi et al., 2020, consider the magnetic biochar as a material possessing good adsorption features with respect to the organic pollutants. MBC is removing antibiotics, organic dyes, pesticides, phenol and organochlorine compounds . "The mechanism of antibiotic removal" involves "hydrogen bonding, œÄ-œÄ interactions, pore-filling effects, electrostatic adsorption, and hydrophobic interactions" . MBC are able of adsorbing the organic dyes "rhodamine B, methylene blue, malachite green, acid orange 7 (AO-7), and orange-G". And other organic pollutants that can be removed by magnetic biochar are "pesticides, phenol, organochlorine, and hormones", with mechanisms based on "hydrogen bonding, œÄ-œÄ interactions, pore-filling effects, electrostatic adsorption, hydrophobic interactions and reductive dehalogenation" (Yi et al., 2020).

question: Which spectroscopic feature confirms the formation of the stable diradical mixture during the Cu(II)-mediated C‚ÄìH bond cleavage process?
answer: A broad and pseudo-split ESR signal with a g value of 2.004 confirms the formation of the stable diradical mixture.
context: Cu(II)-mediated C-H bond cleavage to obtain planar phospha [6]dication from P2-OMe leads to an unexpected stable diradical mixture (t1/2>10 days) which can be verified by a broad and pseudo-split ESR signal with a g value of 2.004 (Figure ). In addition, the mixture has an NIR absorption up to 1100 nm, as shown in Figure . According to the reaction path (Figures ), the cyclized radical product [PDC2-OMe] 2‚Ä¢4+ [(OTf)4] 4+ and the oxidative radical product [P2O-OMe] 2‚Ä¢2+ [(OTf)2] 2+ could be responsible for the multiple radical characters. In fact, this Cu(II)-mediated annulation processes a short lifetime radical mechanism, and the trace could be found by means of the UV-vis-NIR monitor. For example, the addition of excess Cu(OTf)2 leads to two new longwavelength absorption bands up to 1500 nm (Figure ). Nevertheless, the separation and purification of radical [PDC2-OMe] 2‚Ä¢4+ [(OTf)4] and nonradical [PDC3] 2+ [(OTf)2] 2-are unprocurable due to poor solubility. Contrastively, the P1 ligand suffers exclusively radicalization on the BINAP core to produce [PDC3] 2+ [(OTf)2] 2-with the planar topology. This work demonstrates the first successful construction of predominant diradicals and extremely polar-dependent electron transfer in phospha [5]helicenes via the implantation of stark D-A motifs.

question: What experimental technique and conditions were used to study the redox behavior of copper(II) complexes with AŒ≤ peptides?
answer: Cyclic voltammetry was used with a 0.5 mM peptide concentration and a ligand-to-copper(II) ratio of 1:0.9, examining both AŒ≤(3-16) and its pyroglutamate counterpart, pAŒ≤(3-16).
context: Using cyclic voltammetry (CV), we have investigated the redox behaviour of copper(II) complexes formed with both the AŒ≤(3-16) peptide (sequence: EFRHDSGYEVHHQK-am) and its pyroglutamate counterpart, pAŒ≤(3-16) (sequence: pEFRHDSGYEVHHQK-am). The peptide concentration was 0.5 mM and the ligand-to-copper(II) ratio was 1:0.9 (in order to avoid the interference from uncomplexed Cu(II) ions). Apo peptides, i.e. peptides without a metal ion at the coordination site, were also examined.

question: How does replacing OPiv with more electron-withdrawing groups like 3,5-dinitrobenzoate or CN affect the 1 o sr values in the catalytic oxidation of the substrates?
answer: Replacing OPiv with more electron-withdrawing groups such as 3,5-dinitrobenzoate or CN substantially increases the 1 o sr values. For example, the oxidation of C4-3,5-DNBz (S15) and C4-CN (S21) gave 1 o sr values of 14.8 and 13.8, respectively, and for C6 substrates, the 1 o sr increased from 1.3 for C6-OPiv (S14) to 2.7 for C6-3,5-DNBz (S17), achieving a synthetically valuable yield.
context: Building on these results, the substrate scope was further expanded to other EWGs as hydrogen bond acceptors (HBA). The catalytic oxidation of substrates Cn-EWG in NFTBA are presented in Table . The data shows that the 1 o sr is influenced by the nature of the EWG. Replacing OPiv by more electron withdrawing 4-nitrobenzoate (4-NBz), 3,5-dinitrobenzoate (3,5-DNBz) or CN, the 1 o sr increases substantially. For instance, the oxidation of C4-3,5-DNBz (S15) and C4-CN (S21) proceeded with two of the highest 1 o sr (14.8 and 13.8 respectively) among the Cn-EWG substrates. This improvement is even more significant for the C5 and C6 substrates. Notably, the 1 o sr increased from 1.3 to 2.7 going from C6-OPiv (S14) to C6-3,5-DNBz (S17), delivering P17_1 o -OH in a synthetically valuable 34% yield.

question: What are the components and their concentrations in the buffer used for the enzymatic reaction?

After that, 10-¬µM Dabcyl-KTSAVLQSGFRKME-Edans was added to the solution and further incubated for 1 h.

question: What steps are involved in preparing Cobalt(II) tetraphenylporphyrin for use?
answer: Approximately 1 g of as-received Cobalt(II) tetraphenylporphyrin is dissolved in about 500 mL of methylene chloride through sonication for 2 hours. The solution is then filtered using 0.45 Œºm syringe filters, transferred to a crystallization dish for evaporation under ambient atmosphere overnight, followed by drying at 60 ¬∞C, and finally stored in an argon-filled glovebox.
context: METHODS Chemicals. Cobalt(II) tetraphenylporphyrin (Co II TPP) (TCI America, >80.0%) was recrystallized from methylene chloride (Fisher Chemical, HPLC) before use: ~1 g of as-received Co II TPP was dissolved in ~500 mL of methylene chloride via sonication for ~2 h; the solution was filtered with 0.45 Œºm syringe filters (VWR), transferred in a crystallization dish (Pyrex), and evaporated under ambient atmosphere overnight; the recrystallized solid was dried at 60 ¬∞C and stored in an Argonfilled glovebox. Tetrabutylammonium hexafluorophosphate (NBu4PF6) (TCI America, >98.0%) was dried at 90 ¬∞C under vacuum and stored in the glovebox. Dimethylformamide (DMF) (Sigma-Aldrich, anhydrous, 99.8%) was stored in the glovebox and used as received.

question: What were the specific amounts, reaction conditions, and purification method used to obtain the orange solid?

question: What pharmacological and toxicity properties of Fortunellin were evaluated and which tools were used for these assessments?
answer: The evaluations included comparative pharmacokinetic attributes such as absorption, distribution, metabolism, and excretion (ADME) along with important pharmacological properties like physicochemical properties, lipophilicity, water-solubility, and drug-likeness. The toxicity parameters included mutagenicity (AMES mutagenesis), hepatotoxicity, cytotoxicity, and minnow toxicity. ADMETlab 2.0 and pkCSM servers were used for these assessments.
context: To predict the drug-likeness the comparative pharmacokinetic attributes like absorption, distribution, metabolism, and excretion (ADME) and other important pharmacological properties (physicochemical properties, lipophilicity, water-solubility, and drug-likeness) of Fortunellin ADMETlab 2.0 and pkCSM servers were used. Furthermore, toxicity parameters like mutagenicity (AMES mutagenesis), hepatotoxicity, cytotoxicity, minnow toxicity, etc. of fortunellin were also predicted.

question: What were the components and their volume ratios in the cleavage solution used to treat the resin, and how long was the resin treatment performed?
answer: The cleavage solution consisted of trifluoroacetic acid (TFA), water, and triisopropyl silane in a 95:2.5:2.5 volume ratio, and the resin was treated for 2 hours.
context: For cleavage, the resin was treated with the cleavage solution (trifluoroacetic acid (TFA):H2O:triisopropyl silane 95:2.5:2.5 volume ratio) for 2 hours. TFA-peptide solutions were collected, and the resin was washed with TFA (2x3 mL). The collected fractions were concentrated under nitrogen flow and added to cold diethyl ether, leading to the precipitation of the peptide. The precipitate was centrifuged for 5 minutes at 3000 rpm and washed with cold diethyl ether (10 mL). The resulting peptide was dissolved in acetonitrile:water 1:5 (10 mL) and lyophilised. Peptides were purified by RP-HPLC. Elution was performed at a flow rate of 10 mL/min using a linear gradient of acetonitrile and ultrapure water (both containing 0.1% LCMS grade formic acid). The gradient ranged from 20% to 80% acetonitrile over 1 hour. UV absorption at 220 nm and 254 nm was used to monitor the collection of unprotected peptides. Fractions containing the target product were identified by mass spectrometry and lyophilised. ). question: What novel topologies and cage architectures are observed for UZIF-31 and UZIF-33, and how do their network matches correlate with hypothetical zeolite structures?
answer: UZIF-31 exhibits an unprecedented 4,4,4-c topology with the point symbol (4^2.6^2.8^2)(4^3.6.8^2)(4^3.6^2.8), named uft1, which matches the network of PCOD 8095196 (also known as 4,4,4T-3872HZ) and Tier 1 T-50. It is composed of three types of tiles including a t-cub cage and two other cages not observed in any zeolites, with the largest pore opening formed within a 12-membered ring cage. In contrast, UZIF-33 presents a novel 4,4,4-c topology with the point symbol (4.6^4.8)(4^2.6^3.8)(4^3.6^2.8), named uft2, which corresponds to PCOD 8096930 (also known as 4,4,4T-3884HZ) and Tier 1 T-12. It features eight distinct tile types, including newly observed cages such as t-kah and t-sty, as well as a novel [8.12^2] cage, with 12-membered rings serving as the largest pore openings.
context: Synthetic strategy. In ZIF chemistry, the link-link interactions, mainly van der Waals forces, between Im linkers stand as a crucial factor in stabilizing distinct cages and topologies, and introducing hydrogen bonds within ZIF crystals presents a challenging work. Our objective was to introduce weak hydrogen bonds ). The whole crystal structure of UZIF-31 was determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD) with help from the confirmed composition using 1 H-NMR spectroscopy (Figure ). The topology of UZIF-31 exhibited an unprecedented 4,4,4-c topology with the point symbol of (4 2 .6 2 .8 2 )(4 3 .6.8 2 )(4 3 .6 2 .8) named uft1. This novel topology, uft1, was documented in the personal topology repository and not observed in any materials even zeolites. Notably, the topology of uft1 exhibits the same topological network as PCOD 8095196, also known as 4,4,4T-3872HZ, which is among hypothetical zeolites proposed by Deem et al. Interestingly, the topology of UZIF-31 is exactly matched with one of Tier 1, T-50 (Figures and). Despite a slight distortion of Im, the difference in cell volume between UZIF-31 and the predicted structure was merely +6.14 %. During topological analysis of uft1, three types of tiles compose UZIF-31 (Figure ). One of the tiles is a ] cage, which is known as the t-cub, and the others ([4 4 .6 6 .8 2 ] and [4 6 .6 2 .8 2 .12 2 ] cages) are not observed in any zeolites. The largest pore opening with a 12-membered ring (MR) was observed within the surrounding [4 6 .6 2 .8 2 .12 2 ] cage. UZIF-32 and -33 (uft2) crystallized within the orthorhombic Cmmm (No. 65) space group. The composition of crystals was confirmed by SCXRD and 1 H-NMR (Tables and; Figures and). Thus far, due to the identical net, the topological analysis of UZIF-32 has been considered the same as that of UZIF-33 for clarity. UZIF-33 also presented a novel 4,4,4-c topology with the point symbol of (4.6 4 .8)(4 2 .6 3 .8)(4 3 .6 2 .8) named uft2, not encountered in any other porous materials, including zeolite structures. Similar to uft1, the topology of uft2 shows the identical topological network with PCOD 8096930, also referred to as 4,4,4T-3884HZ, in hypothetical zeolites suggested by Deem et al. The topology of UZIF-33 is completely matched to one of Tier 1, T-12, with a slight cell volume difference of +4.68 % (Figures and). Eight types of tiles ] cage as t-cub, [4 2 .6 2 ] cage as t-lov, ] cage as t-kah, ] cage as t-lau, [6 2 .8 2 ] cage as t-kaa, ] cage as t-ste, .6 4 .12 2 ] cage as t-sty, [8 .12 2 ] cage) compose UZIF-33 (Figure ). To the best of our knowledge, UZIF-33 has the highest number of tiles (8 types) within known ZIF topologies. Among these tiles, ] cage as t-kah and [4 4 .6 4 .12 2 ] cage as t-sty were first observed in ZIF structures, while [8 .12 2 ] cage was novel and not even present in zeolites. 12-MRs as the largest pore opening were enclosed by alternating .6 4 .12 2 ] cage (t-sty) and novel [8 .12 2 ] cage.

question: What spectroscopic evidence confirms the positioning of the butyl ester groups in the compound?
answer: The HMBC correlations observed from H-4 (Œ¥H 5.44) to a carbonyl at Œ¥C 171.9 and from H-6 (Œ¥H 4.89) to a carbonyl at Œ¥C 172.4, together with the gem-dimethyl HMBC correlations to both ester carbonyls, establish the butyl ester groups at positions C-4 and C-6.
context: The molecular formula for 12 (C22H37NO4) indicated incorporating an additional C2H6 while also containing one degree of unsaturation less than 11. Based on the GCMS analysis, 12 lacked the olefin between C2-C3 and contained two butyl esters. Comparing the 13 C spectra to 9-11 revealed that 12 lacks olefinic signals but had two deshielded esters (Œ¥C 172.4 and 171.9). The 1 H NMR spectra of 12 suggested the two butyl ester moieties at C-4 and C-6. Both methyl groups in the gem-dimethyl moiety (Œ¥H 1.11 and 0.78) exhibited HMBC correlations to both ester carbonyls, along with observed HMBC correlations between H-4 (Œ¥H 5.44) and C-13 (Œ¥C 171.9), and between H-6 (Œ¥H 4.89) and C-17 (Œ¥C 172.4). Thus, we deduced planar structures for ischnocybine A-C and ischnocybinone (Figure ).

question: Which compound among DPivOHAQ (7), AQDB (1e), and 1d exhibits the lowest redox potential, and what does this indicate about the effect of electron-donating methyl groups?
answer: DPivOHAQ (7) exhibits the lowest redox potential at -0.499 V, indicating that the presence of electron-donating methyl groups on the benzylic carbons results in lower redox potentials.
context: The effect of branched alkyl chains on redox potentials can be evaluated through the comparison of 1d, AQDB (1e), and DPivOHAQ (7). Addition of electron-donating methyl groups on the benzylic carbons can lead to lower redox potentials of AQs, with the order of potentials given by 7 (-0.499 V) < 1e (-0.480 V) < 1d (-0.456 V). question: What specific amino acid substitutions were performed to optimize the lead peptide sequence for antimicrobial activity?
answer: The lead peptide sequence was modified by exhaustively substituting one or two amino acids with several prepared options: three Œ±,Œ±-disubstituted nonproteinogenic amino acids (Aib, Ac5c, Ac6c), two additional Œ±-NPAAs (Dab and Orn), and amino acids for side‚Äêchain stapling ((S)-2-(4-pentenyl)alanine, designated S5, and (R)-2-(7-pentenyl)alanine, designated R8). Additionally, hydrophobic residues were replaced with Val and Leu to enhance the antimicrobial profile.
context: To generate AMP candidates, one or two amino acids in a lead peptide sequence were exhaustively converted into amino acids prepared for substitution. As the amino acids prepared for substitution, we selected three Œ±,Œ±disubstituted NPAAs, Œ±-aminoisobutyric acid (Aib), 1aminocyclopentanecarboxylic acid (Ac5c), and aminocyclohexyl carboxylic acid (Ac6c) (Fig. ). Two Œ±-NPAAs, diaminobutyric acid (Dab) and ornithine (Orn), were also used (Fig. ). (S)-2-(4pentenyl)alanine (S5) and (R)-2-(7-pentenyl)alanine (R8) were amino acids that were prepared as the building blocks of side-chain stapling, the combination of two S5 ("S5,S5") and that of R8 and S5 ("R8,S5") (Fig. ). Previous studies have reported that NPAAs and side-chain stapling improve helicity and antimicrobial activities. In addition, Val and Leu residues were also selected as amino acids prepared for substitution as a previous study reported that AMPs whose hydrophobic residues were converted into Val and Leu residues could suppress toxicity and exhibit potent antimicrobial activities. 41

question: What types of mCherry tagging were used for the plasmids expressing ubiquitin, Phogrin, and Tyrp1?
answer: Ubiquitin was tagged at the N-terminus with mCherry, while both Phogrin and Tyrp1 were tagged at the C-terminus with mCherry.
context: Plasmid Construction. We constructed plasmids for the expression of N-terminal mCherry-tagged ubiquitin (mCherry-ubiquitin) and C-terminal mCherry-tagged Phogrin and Tyrp1 (Phogrin-mCherry and Tyrp1-mCherry). Mouse Phogrin and Tyrp1 cDNAs were amplified using reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) from mRNAs prepared from AtT-20 cells and brain tissues. These cDNAs and mCherry cDNA were subcloned into the pCMV vector.

question: How do substituents at R1 and R2 influence the intramolecular distance and folding angle in [3]-ladderene structures?
answer: Substituents at R1 increase the intramolecular distance (r) from about 2.98 √Ö to approximately 3.02 √Ö and enlarge the folding angle (Œ∏) up to around 120¬∞, while substituents at R2 decrease r to about 2.86‚Äì2.89 √Ö and reduce the folding angle to approximately 114‚Äì116¬∞ (or even lower in ring‚Äêopening products), reflecting stronger steric repulsions at the R2 position.
context: These substituents can substantially perturb the [3]-ladderene geometries relative to 1 to minimize closed-shell repulsions. We defined two parameters, an intramolecular distance, r, and a folding angle Œ∏, to quantify the geometrical distortions (Figure ). The parameter r is the distance between the centroids of the two œÄ-bonds, and Œ∏ is the angle between the planes of the four-membered rings. These parameters are r = 2.98 √Ö and Œ∏ = 118¬∞ in 1; r = 1.56 √Ö and Œ∏ = 90¬∞ in 2; Œ∏ = 114¬∞ in 3, optimized with PBE0/cc-pVDZ. R1 tetra-CH3-substitutions increase the r to 3.02 √Ö. The CH3 at R2 show opposite effects; the r and Œ∏ values decrease to 2.89 √Ö and 115¬∞, maximizing the distance between adjacent substituents (Figure ). The CH3 at R2 bends the [3]-ladderenes 3¬∞ more than the CH3 at R1, introducing additional strain at the bridgehead carbons, and 4'' is 0.46 eV higher than 4' (Table ). The tetra-CF3-and cPr-substitution lead to similar geometrical distortions: the r and Œ∏ increase to 2.98-3.02 √Ö and 120¬∞ when substituting R1, whereas the r and Œ∏ values reduce to 2.86-2.87 √Ö and 114-116¬∞ when substituting R2. The energies of 7' and 10' are 0.21 and 0.59 eV lower than 7'' and 10'', respectively (Table ). Compared to 1, the r and Œ∏ parameters in the octa-substituted [3]-ladderenes, 4, 7, and 10 decreased to 2.89-2.95 √Ö and 116-118¬∞. It suggests the repulsive steric interaction at R2 generates the dominant geometrical distortions. The repulsive steric interactions at R1 enlarges the angle in the 4œÄ-disrotatory electrocyclic ring-opening products to 115-117¬∞, compared to 3 (Œ∏ = 114¬∞); the steric clash at R2 reduces the angle to 106-112¬∞. Figure shows that the substituents at R1 and R2 destabilize the reaction energies by 0.24-0.55 and 0.56-0.77 eV, respectively. The greater destabilization at R2 suggests stronger steric repulsions due to the inflexibility of the substituent at the bridgehead position. The octa-substitution additively increases the destabilizing effects of the R1 and R2 tetra-substitution. The reaction energy of 6, 9, and 12 is 0.68-2.34 eV higher than 1. The octa-substitutions with CF3 and cPr switch the reaction energies from exergonic to endergonic (0.65 and 0.30 eV), indicating unfavorable 4œÄ-disrotatory electrocyclic ring-opening to 9 and 12.

question: What distinguishes the structure of Int A2' from other hydroalumination products regarding its ligand fragment?
answer: Int A2' is the only structurally characterized example of a single hydroalumination product featuring an isothiocyanate fragment (-NCHS).

question: At what EV diameter do proteins in the surface and bulk of EVs have equal representation?
answer: They are equal at an EV diameter of 180 nm.
context: Arguably, both %ùëõ ùúé and %ùëõ ùëè are strongly influenced by EV diameter. This aspect is visualized in fig. , where %ùëõ ùúé and %ùëõ ùëè (calculated for ùõ§= 5.0 ‚Ä¢ 10 -20 moles/¬µm 2 and ÔÅ≤ = 1.7 ‚Ä¢10 -18 moles/¬µm 3 ) have been plotted as functions of EV diameter. According to the calculation, smaller EVs carry more proteins on their surface (blue dashed line) than in their bulk (red dashed line) and vice versa. Protein repartition eventually reaches a switch point (%ùëõ ùúé = %ùëõ ùëè ) at d =180 nm (fig. , black-dotted line), within the size range typical of S-EVs (50-200 nm). The trend then inverts, with bulk proteins quickly overtaking surface ones, until the ratios stabilize in the size range typical of larger EVs, such as large oncosomes (d > 1000 nm).

question: How do the identification percentages of type 2 peptides with a two-fraction XIC pattern compare among the different digestion methods?
answer: For LEP digestion, 54% of type 2 peptides showed the pattern, increasing to 77% with LEP+v8. With LEP+trypsin it was 87%, and with LEP+trypsin+v8, 92% of the peptides exhibited the expected two-fraction XIC pattern.
context: In a different LC-MS/MS system #2 (11) the type 2 peptides derived from LEP and LEP+v8 digestions of p64k-Cys 1 pP0 showed the expected two-fractions XIC pattern (Fig. ) for 54% and 77 % of them, respectively while the LEP+trypsin and LEP+trypsin+v8 tandem digestions allowed the identification of 87% and 92 % of type 2 peptides with a two-fraction XICs pattern, respectively (Fig. ).

question: What polymerization method is used to synthesize redox-active hyperbranched polymers for RFBs, and why is the ARGET ATRP technique particularly advantageous in this process?
answer: Redox-active hyperbranched polymers are synthesized by combining self-condensing vinyl copolymerization (SCVCP) with the oxygen-tolerant activator regenerated by electron transfer (ARGET) ATRP technique. The ARGET ATRP method is advantageous because it overcomes the oxygen sensitivity of traditional ATRP by continuously regenerating the Cu I activator with a reducing agent, thereby maintaining the necessary equilibrium for the reaction.
context: Therefore, to prepare redox-active hyperbranched polymers for RFBs, we use self-condensing vinyl copolymerization (SCVCP) to combine a water-soluble inimer and a redox-active comonomers . As traditional ATRP is susceptible to a trace of oxygen, it is unsuitable for the flow setup. Thus, we adopted the oxygen-tolerant activator regenerated by electron transfer (ARGET) ATRP technique. Its mechanism involves a process of the activator (Cu I species) continuously regenerated by a reducing agent while the Cu I /Cu II pair maintains the ATRP equilibrium. Based on previous reports on aqueous organic RFBs, we selected a viologen-bearing monomer (anolyte) and a 2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidyloxy (TEMPO)-bearing monomer (catholyte) as redox-active comonomers, respectively, and an ammoniumbearing inimer, N,N-dimethyl-N-(2-methacryloyloxy)ethyl(2-bromoisobutyryloxy)ethylammonium bromide (DMEAB), at a 1:1 molar ratio to prepare the hyperbranched copolymers (HCPs).

question: At what energies above the valence band maximum are the charge transition levels for the (SnBi-SnBi) defect located, and which transitions do these energies correspond to?
answer: The charge transition level Œµ(+2/0) is located at 1.04 eV above the valence band maximum, while Œµ(0/-2) is located at 1.60 eV above the valence band maximum.
context: The intra-gap charge transition levels of (SnBi-SnBi), Œµ(+2/0) and Œµ(0/-2), are located at 1.04 and 1.60 eV above the VBM, respectively. Both of these defect levels are 'negative-U' states i.e. the defect can trap two holes/electrons with the second bound more strongly than the first. As such, the singly-charged states, corresponding to (SnBi ‚Ä¢ -SnBi ÔÇ¥ ) and (SnBi ÔÇ¥ -SnBi / ), are predicted to be thermodynamically unstable at all Fermi level positions -at Œµ(+2/0) (SnBi ‚Ä¢ -SnBi ÔÇ¥ ) is 34 meV higher in energy than the neutral or +2 charge state while at Œµ(0/-2) (SnBi ÔÇ¥ -SnBi / ) is 16 meV higher in energy than the neutral or -2 charge state (see Section B in the SI for more on this).

question: What are the specific reagents, their equivalents, solvent concentrations, and reaction conditions used in the synthesis procedure involving amidine, aldehyde, and isocyanate?

question: What diastereoselectivity is observed in the nickel-catalyzed aryldifluoroalkylation of 2-azetines, and what type of azetidines does it produce?
answer: The reaction proceeds with a diastereoselectivity greater than 20:1 and produces trans-disubstituted azetidines.
context: Transition-metal-catalyzed additions across œÄ-systems have been extensively explored and have similarly been employed to control the reactivity of 2-azetines (Fig. ). In this area, Zhang and co-workers developed a nickel-catalyzed aryldifluoroalkylation across the alkene of 2-azetines (44) that affords trans-disubstituted azetidines (45). This metalcatalyzed transformation of 2-azetines (44) proceeded with a diastereoselectivity greater than 20:1, and produced azetidines with ester or amide functionality for subsequent modifications such as amide couplings. Functionalized Œ≤-lactams are a well-established motif that have demonstrated medicinal properties. 62-65 1-Azetines have been identified by researchers as precursors to functionalized Œ≤-lactam rings under a variety of reaction conditions (Fig 4D). The first example of a 1-azetine being converted to a Œ≤-lactam was disclosed by Atkinson and co-workers. The Atkinson group showed that two different 1-azetines (46, R 1 =Cl or MeO, R 2 =Ph, R 3 =Cl, R 4 =Me, R 5 =H) were converted to the same Nhydro Œ≤-lactam (47) upon exposure to 10% hydrochloric acid. Likewise, Aue and Thomas were able to synthesize a N-methyl Œ≤-lactam (47, R 2 =R 3 =Me, R 4 =R 5 =H) from a 1-azetine (46, R 1 =OMe) via a thermally induced Chapman rearrangement. Ghosez and co-workers developed a general protocol that allows conversion of a 1-azetine (46, R 1 =NMe2, R 2 =R 3 =Me, R 4 =Ph, R 5 =H) to Œ≤-lactams with an N-electrophile bond (47) in the presence of an electrophile such as methyl iodide or acrylonitrile following basic hydrolysis. Pifferi and co-workers synthesized a series of 1-azetines (46, R 1 =OEt, R 2 =alkyl or aryl, R 3 =alkyl or aryl, R 4 =R 5 =H) from beta lactams (47). The authors observed that anhydrous hydrochloric acid in ethereal solvents reverted 1-azetines (46) to the corresponding Œ≤-lactams (47) from which they were formed. The four protocols described (vide supra) allow access to highly functionalized Œ≤-lactams from 1-azetines and proceed through different mechanisms, which highlights the potential of 1-azetines as useful building blocks to access Œ≤-lactam rings.

question: How are the Pt-Fe catalysts prepared and how is the ratio between Pt and Fe controlled?
answer: The catalysts are prepared by sequentially grafting two molecular precursors, Fe2Mes4 and Pt(C3H5)(DIA), onto silica that has been partially dehydroxylated at 700¬∞C, and then treating the material under H2 at 600¬∞C to form supported nanoparticles. The ratio between Pt and Fe is controlled by adjusting the stoichiometry of the precursors relative to the surface -OH groups, which yields Pt/Fe ratios ranging from 0.22 to 3.23.
context: First, a series of Pt-Fe catalysts are synthesized by sequential grafting of two molecular precursors, Fe2Mes4 (Mes = Mesityl) and Pt(C3H5)(DIA) (C3H5 = ÔÅ® 3 -allyl, DIA = N,N'-diisopropylacetimidinate), onto a silica partially dehydroxylated at 700¬∞C (SiO2-700, 0.9 -OH nm -2 ). The resulting materials contain two metal surface species (Figure ), for which the Pt/Fe-ratios (ÔÅ£Pt/Fe) can be tuned at the grafting step, by choosing an adequate stoichiometry between the precursors and the surface -OH density. A subsequent treatment under H2 flow at 600¬∞C (ramp: 1¬∞C min -1 ) yields a series of supported nanoparticles (vide infra), coined PtxFey@SiO2 (Figure ). By this approach, bimetallic materials with different ÔÅ£Pt/Fe are produced along with monometallic Pt@SiO2 and Fe@SiO2 systems. The metal loadings in all catalysts are determined by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES), revealing Pt/Fe ratios ranging between 0.22 < ÔÅ£Pt/Fe < 3.23 in bimetallic systems (Table ).

question: What criteria were used to select the reference inhibitors for the kinases and how was the activity threshold determined?
answer: Inhibitors with pIC50/pKi/pKd values of 6 or higher were selected from ChEMBL33 as reference compounds, and the median docking score of known inhibitors docked into the proteins was used as the activity threshold.
context: We investigated possible selectivity of generated compounds to highly related protein targets. For each kinase we determined protein-ligand interaction patterns encoding the hinge region and collected inhibitors having pIC50/pKi/pKd ‚â• 6 from ChEMBL33 as reference compounds. Known inhibitors were docked into corresponding proteins and we chose the median docking score as an activity threshold for further assessments (Table ).

question: What performance metrics did the GTNN models achieve when predicting reaction yields and binary outcomes in the Minisci reaction dataset?
answer: The GTNN models achieved a mean absolute error of 18.7% (¬±0.2) and a Pearson correlation coefficient of 0.687 (¬±0.006) for reaction yield predictions. They correctly predicted the yield category 55.7% (¬±0.7) of the time, while binary reaction outcomes were predicted with an accuracy of 81% (¬±1) and an F-score of 82.7% (¬±0.6).
context: Based on these initial studies, GTNN models were trained on the full experimental data set of 691 Minisci reactions generated by HTE (277 from the LSF informer library and 414 from the in silico reaction screening). Reaction yields were predicted with a mean absolute error (MAE) of 18.7 (¬±0.2)% and a Pearson correlation coefficient (PCC) of 0.687 (¬±0.006) (Figure ). Reaction yields were categorized into four ranges: no reaction (<1% yield), poor (>1-11%), medium (>11-35%), and high reaction yield (>35-100%). The model predicted the correct category in 55.7 (¬±0.7)% of the cases. Binary reaction outcomes were predicted with an absolute accuracy of 81 (¬±1), and an F -score of 82.7 (¬±0.6)% (Figure ). For additional neural network analyses and descriptions of the chosen metric, see Section SI2.

question: Which types of substituents and functional groups on aryl halides are compatible with the enantioconvergent cross-coupling reaction?
answer: Both electron-donating and electron-withdrawing substituents on aryl halides work well, including sterically hindered ortho-substituted ones. The reaction tolerates a variety of functional groups, such as ketones, aldehydes, esters, amides, alkyl and aryl nitriles, sulfones, as well as OAc and boronic esters. In addition, a range of heterocycles‚Äîincluding quinoline, benzothiazole, indole, benzofuran, phenothiazine, and pyrimidine‚Äîand derivatives from bioactive molecules like clofibrate, fenofibrate, indometacin, amino acids, and cholesterol are compatible with the reaction conditions.
context: Under the established reaction conditions, we first explored the scope of aryl halide in this enantioconvergent cross-coupling (Table 2). A wide range of aryl halides with electron-donating groups (3b-3d) or electron-withdrawing groups (3i-3v) were viable substrates under standard conditions. Moreover, the reaction was not sensitive to steric resistance, and the ortho-substituted substrates (3e, 3f) were converted to the desired products in good yields with high er values. A series of aryl electrophiles possessing functional groups, such as ketones (3i-3k), aldehydes (3l), esters (3m) amide (3n), alkyl nitrile substrates (3o), aryl nitrile at para (3p), meta (3q), or ortho (3r) positions, as well as sulfones (3u, 3v) were all well accommodated without any traces of functional group interconversion. Furthermore, the reaction also showed good compatibility with OAc (3w) or boronic esters (3x), which can be further functionalized via traditional cross-coupling reactions. Remarkably, the introduction of heterocycles, such as quinoline (3y, 3z), benzothiazole (4a), indole (4b, 4c), benzofuran (4d), phenothiazine (4e), pyrimidine (4f, 4g) did not diminish the reaction efficiency, affording the desired corresponding products with high levels of enantiocontrol. The compatibility of this protocol with bioactive molecules was also investigated. For instance, substrates bearing clofibrate (4h), fenofibrate (4i), indometacin (4k), and derivatives of amino acids (4j) and cholesterol (4l) could be employed to provide the corresponding products in moderate to good yields with excellent ee, which underscore the potential application for rapid modification of drugs and natural products.

In contrast to ZIF-zni(Zn), milling does not increase the porosity of ZIF-Cu-1 but progressively densifies the material so that # '() *'+ amounts to only about 5 cm Cu-1 both contain the same im -linkers, the drastic difference in milling-induced structural evolution between these two materials may be ascribed to their inorganic building units. question: How did replacing the quinoline ring with a pyridine ring affect the Gi-protein activation parameters?
answer: Replacing the quinoline ring with a pyridine ring resulted in a 23-fold reduction in potency, increasing the EC50 from 2.70 nM to 63.2 nM, and it decreased the efficacy from 94% to 71%.
context: To investigate the effect of the quinoline ring on signaling bias, specifically Gi-protein dissociation and Œ≤arr2 recruitment through the activation of the DORs, we used a split NanoLuc Binary Technology (NanoBiT) assay (Figure , Table ). dissociation activity (EC50 = 2.70 nM, Emax = 94%), but only partial agonist activity for Œ≤arr2-recruitment activity (EC50 = 15.9 nM, Emax = 37%). These results are consistent with previous reports highlighting the efficacy-dominant G-protein-biased DOR agonism of KNT-127. Conversion of the quinoline to a pyridine ring resulted in a 23-fold reduction in potency for Gi-protein activation (1; EC50 = 63.2 nM, Emax = 71%), while maintaining an efficacy close to that of KNT-127. In contrast, the Œ≤arr2-recruitment activity showed a 8-fold reduction in potency and a 76% decrease in efficacy (1; EC50 = 121 nM, Emax = 9%).

question: How do the use of Selectfluor as the oxidant and the presence of an iodine catalyst impact the reaction outcome?
answer: When Selectfluor is used as the oxidant, the reaction produces an acceptable yield but with a reduced diastereomeric ratio of 6:1, whereas the reaction does not proceed at all in the absence of the iodine catalyst.
context: Additionally, other anionic fluorine sources were found to be ineffective in this reaction (entry 13). Using Selectfluor as the oxidant provided an acceptable yield, although the diastereomeric ratio decreased to 6:1 (entry 14). As expected, the transformation did not proceed in the absence of the iodine catalyst (entry 15). groups (5-6 and 8) underwent the dearomative difluorination with moderate to good yields ranging from 40% to 72%. 3-Methylindoles carrying a trifluoromethyl or carbonyl substituent at the 6-position were generally compatible with the reaction conditions (9-10). Disubstituted 3-methylindoles yielded the corresponding products in good yields (11). Notably, indoles featuring different N-acyl protecting groups such as benzoyl, pivaloyl, or acetyl underwent the reaction smoothly, leading to good yields of the desired products (12-14). Importantly, the protocol was not limited to 3-methylindoles alone. A series of N-SO2Ph-indoles bearing electron-withdrawing substituents, including nitro, ester and cyano at various positions, were also amenable to the reaction conditions, albeit with slightly reduced yields (15-20). Encouragingly, by introducing stronger electron-withdrawing N-protecting groups, even weakly electron-poor 2,3-dihydroindoles were tolerated, providing moderate yields of the desired products (21-24). the successful transformation of indoles with varying alkyl chain lengths (25, 29). Furthermore, protected tryptamine and tryptophan were successfully converted into the corresponding dearomative products (27, 28) with moderate yields. Notably, a wide range of functional groups (FGs), including bromo (26, 30), phthalimide (27, 28), sulfonate ester (31, 32), benzoate (33), sulfonic ester (34), phenyl ether (35), methyl ester (36), and chloro (38) on the alkyl chain, remained unreacted, indicating the high chemoselectivity and mild reaction conditions of the protocol. To further assess the compatibility of this method in more structurally complex contexts, several natural products and biologically active compounds containing indoles were subjected to the reaction. Functionalized indoles derived from febuxostat (40), probenecid (41), epiandrosterone (42), dehydrocholic acid (43), and L-menthol ( ) were all suitable substrates, affording the corresponding trans-2,3difluorinated indolines with good efficiency. These results underscored the robustness and versatility of the method.

question: What record adsorption performance was achieved using 3M MgBr2 at 0.6 V with a gas mixture containing 15% CO2, 5% O2, and 80% N2?

The influence of oxygen on CO2 adsorption was further investigated with 3M MgCl2 (Figure and Figure ), another deliquescent electrolyte. When a 15% CO2/85% N2 gas mixture is used, CO2 sorption profiles during charging and discharging behave very similarly to those shown by electrodes infiltrated with 3M MgBr2 electrolyte (Figure and Figure ). A capacitance of ‚àº80 F.g -1 , a resistance of ‚àº9 Œ©.cm 2 , a CO2 adsorption capacity of 75 mmol.kg -1 , an adsorption rate of ‚àº32 Œºmol.kg -1 .s -1 , a coulombic efficiency of ‚àº98%, an energy efficiency of ‚àº80%, an energy loss of ‚àº4J and an energy consumption of ‚àº73 kJ.mol -1 were measured (Figure ).
