question: How does substituting Pt with MoS2 as the co-catalyst impact the reaction outcome for the dehydrogenation of hydroxymethylfurfural?
answer: Utilizing Pt nanoparticles with CdS microspheres leads to the production of 2,5-diformylfuran with an AQY of 12.3% at 450 nm, whereas replacing Pt with MoS2 results in both 2,5-diformylfuran and a pinacol-like coupling product, as the lower H2-evolution activity of MoS2 prolongs the lifetime of hydroxyalkyl radicals, encouraging their dimerization.
context: A hybrid material composed of Pt nanoparticles (~4 nm in diameter, optimal loading 1 wt. %) and CdS microspheres (~1.5 ¬µm in diameter) enable dehydrogenation of hydroxymethylfurfural in MeCN/water (1:1) mixture. The AQY of 2,5-diformylfuran is 12.3% at 450 nm. When H2O was replaced by D2O, only H2 evolved. When MoS2 was used instead of Pt as a co-catalyst, in addition to 2,5-diformylfuran, pinacol-like coupling product formed, suggesting that in the presence of less active H2-evolution catalyst, MoS2, lifetime of hydroxyalkyl radicals is longer, which favors their dimerization.

question: How do the structural and computational findings support that there is no covalent bond between the tetrel and cobalt atoms in compounds 1‚Äì3?
answer: The tetrel‚Äìcobalt distances in compounds 1‚Äì3 are longer than the sum of the covalent radii (for example, Pb‚ÄìCo distance of 3.0318 √Ö exceeds the expected 2.96 √Ö), and the corresponding Wiberg bond indices are very low (0.20 for Ge‚ÄìCo, 0.15 for Sn‚ÄìCo, and 0.13 for Pb‚ÄìCo). Additionally, analyses using AIM did not identify any bond critical points between the tetrel atoms and the cobalt center, all of which indicate only a weak interaction rather than a covalent bond.
context: A recent work from our group has successfully utilised the reaction of white phosphorus (P4) with heterobimetallic complexes to prepare unusual polyphosphorus compounds. Using this strategy, we have now synthesised the heavy tetraphospholide anions SnP4 2-and PbP4 2-. These hitherto unknown ÔÅ∞-aromatic molecules are stabilised by the coordination to two cobalt atoms in the triple-decker sandwich compounds [(Œ∑ 4 -tBu2C2P2)2Co2(Œº,Œ∑ 5 :Œ∑ 5 -P4Tt)] [Tt = Sn (6), Pb (7)]. We describe the structural and spectroscopic characterization of these complexes and analyse the electronic structure of the P4Tt 2‚îÄ ligands with quantum chemical methods. The molecular structures of 1-3 were determined by singlecrystal X-ray diffraction. Since all three structures share the same motif, only the molecular structure of 2 is displayed in Figure , while those of 1 and 3 are shown in the SI (Figures and). The cobalt atoms feature Œ∑ 4 -coordinated 1,5-cyclooctadiene and 1,3-diphosphacyclobutadiene ligands, while the tetrel atom (Ge, Sn, or Pb) is in a pseudo-two-coordinate environment by terphenyl-substituent and one of the P atoms of the diphosphacyclobutadiene ligand. The Tt-P bond lengths in 1-3 (2.3946(8) √Ö, 2.6442(7) √Ö, 2.7402(10) √Ö, respectively) are similar to those of tertiary phosphine adducts of tetrelylenes. The Tt-Co distances in 1-3 (Ge-Co 2.8434(6) √Ö, Sn-Co 2.9534(5) √Ö, Pb-Co: 3.0318(6) √Ö) are longer than the sum of their covalent radii (‚àërGeCo 2.70 √Ö, ‚àërSnCo 2.89 √Ö, ‚àërPbCo 2.96 √Ö). These parameters suggest the absence of a covalent metal-metal bond, which is in line with quantum chemical calculations (vide infra). By contrast, a previously reported, related cluster compound (Ar‚Ä≤SnCo)2 features strong covalent Sn-Co bonds, which even have partial multiple bond character. It is noteworthy that although the Tt-Co and Tt-P distances for 1-3 increase down the group, the bond angles are approximately the same (C1-Tt-Co1 127¬∞-129¬∞, C1-Tt-P1 102¬∞-103¬∞). As a consequence of the relatively short atomic radius of germanium, the terphenyl substituent and the Co( ), C1-Sn1-P1 102.17 (7). This is presumably due to the large chemical shift anisotropy of the signals and/or relaxation effects as previously observed for the (Ar‚Ä≤SnCo)2 cluster. Intrinsic bond orbital (IBO), natural bond orbital (NBO) and Atoms in Molecules (AIM) analyses of DFT calculated electron densities were employed to analyse the bonding situation in 1-3. The IBO analyses show the expected bond-like localised molecular orbitals. Additionally, there is a delocalised MO between the tetrel, coordinating phosphorus and cobalt centres, but with low contributions from Co (1: Ge (24%) Co (8%) P (59%), 2: Sn (14%) Co (10%) P (59%), 3: Pb (13%) Co (10%) P (59%)). The Wiberg bond indices for Ge-Co, Sn-Co and Pb-Co likage in 1-3 (0.20, 0.15 and 0.13, respectively) are lower than expected for a covalent bond. In line with the results from DFT, the AIM analysis shows bond critical point (BCP) between cobalt and phosphorus, as well as the tetrel atoms and phosphorus (see Figure and SI). However, no BCPs were found between the tetrel atoms and the cobalt centre. All these results indicate the presence of only a weak interaction between Tt and Co. It was also possible to synthesise the homoleptic tin(II) complex Sn[Co(Œ∑ 4 -P2C2tBu2)(COD)]2 (4) by reacting E with commercially available Sn(acac)2 (Figure ). Single-crystal X-ray diffraction on 4 revealed that the tin atom is coordinated by the two P atoms of the diphosphacyclobutadiene ligands with Sn-P distances (Sn1-P1 2.6490 (10), Sn1-P2 2.6484(10) √Ö) similar to 2 and a P-Sn-P angle of 102.17 Having compounds 1-4 at hand, we studied their reactivity towards P4 to ascertain whether they can be used as precursors to novel polyphosphorus compounds. Reactions between 1 and P4 were unsuccessful. While no reaction occurs at ambient temperature, heating to 55 ¬∞C affords an intractable mixture of products according to 31 P NMR spectra (see Figure , SI). By contrast, reactions of 2 or 4 with P4 at elevated temperatures afford dark red, crystalline compound [(tBu2C2P2)2Co2(Œº,Œ∑ 5 :Œ∑ 5 -SnP4)] (6) in each case (Figure ). When using 2, separation of 6 from the terphenyl containing by-products proved difficult due to their similar solubility. Fortunately, reaction of 4 with P4 forms 6 selectively at ambient temperature, with 1,5-cycloctadiene being the only by-product, making isolation facile and allowing the crystallographic characterisation of 6 by singlecrystal X-ray diffraction (Figure ). The crystallographic analysis reveals the formation of a triple decker complex of two (Œ∑ 4 -P2C2tBu2)Co units and a planar cyclo-SnP4 middle deck, for which a pronounced alternation of the P-P bond lengths is observed. The P-P bonds adjacent to the Sn atom (P1-P2 Internal 2.1101( ) and P3-P4 2.094(4) √Ö) approach the range for a P=P double bond. The P2-P3 bond length (2.2296(11) √Ö) suggests the presence of a single bond. The bond lengths between phosphorus and tin (av. P-Sn 2.52865( ) √Ö are comparable to the single bonds found in diphosphastannylenes. The 31 P{ 1 H} spectrum of 6 shows one singlet and two multiplets with an integral ratio of 4:2:2. The singlet at Œ¥ = 67.1 ppm can be assigned to the P atoms within the P2C2tBu2 rings. One of the two multiplet signals (Œ¥ = 29.6 and 77.0 ppm), the highfield shifted signal shows coupling to 117/119 Sn, allowing for its definitive assignment to the P atoms adjacent to the Sn atom (P1 and P4). Simulation of the 31 P{ 1 H} spectrum by an iterative fitting procedure gave a 1 JPP coupling constant of ‚îÄ434.7 Hz for the P1-P2/P3-P4 pairs, whereas the 1 JPP coupling for P2-P3 (magnetically not equivalent) it is ‚îÄ289.0 Hz (see Figure , SI). A 119 Sn NMR spectrum of 6, shows a broad triplet at Œ¥ = 339.7 ppm with a 1 JSnP coupling constant of 797 Hz, which is in agreement with the simulated 31 P{ 1 H} NMR spectrum (see the SI). The line broadening of the 119 Sn NMR is likely due to interactions with the quadrupolar 59 Co nuclei. 22 ), Sn1-P4 2.5375( ), P1-P2 2.1101( ), P2-P3 2.2296( ), P3-P4 2.1104( ), Co1-Co2 3.050, P1-Sn1-P4 88.17( ), Sn1-P1-P2 118.23(4), P1-P2-P3 107.96( ), P2-P3-P4 107.60( ), P3-P4-Sn1 118.02(4); c) Sections of the measured (upward) and simulated (downward) P{ 1 H} NMR spectrum of 6.

question: What was the final yield of the purified copolymer after drying under high vacuum?
answer: 185 mg of a white powder.
context: P(AAm-co-BMDO) were synthesized following a previously developed procedure and adapted as follows. Two initial AAm:BMDO molar ratios (56:44 and 57:43) were tested. For P(AAm-co-BMDO) 56:44 (P5), AAm (112 eq., 4.48 mmol, 0.32 g), BMDO (88 eq., 3.52 mmol, 0.57 g) (total mole = 8 mmol), CDP (1 eq., 0.04 mmol, 16.1 mg) and AIBN (0.6 eq., 0.024 mmol, 3.9 mg) were dissolved into anhydrous DMSO (10 mL). The solution was bubbled with dry argon to remove dissolved oxygen for 20 min at room temperature and then immersed in a preheated oil bath at 70 ¬∞C for 16 h. The solution was then rapidly cooled under air. The copolymer was precipitated into cold methanol and then washed three times with cold methanol followed by centrifugation (5,000 rpm, 10 min). The copolymer was then dried under high vacuum to give 185 mg of a white powder. The purified copolymers were characterized by H-NMR and SEC.

question: What levels of enzyme inhibition did compounds 2a and 3a achieve on E. coli DXPS compared to the DXPS enzymes from Klebsiella pneumoniae, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Deinococcus radiodurans at a concentration of 1 mM?

question: How was the pH-meter calibrated during the experiments?
answer: The pH-meter was calibrated daily using Roti CALIPURE pH standards ranging from 2 to 9 with an InLab Micro-Pro-SIM electrode.
context: We prepared 1mM and 100 mM stock solutions of NaCl (>99.8%, Roth) and CaCl2 (dihydrate, ‚â•99.9%, p.a., ACS, ROTH) using sterile, DNA-and nuclease-free water (Roth) and adjusted the pH with 1 M NaOH or 1M HCl (FIXANAL, Fluka Analytical). We used short DNA strands (from salmon testes, ~30 bp, Roth) representative of degraded, ancient DNA. We prepared fresh DNA stock solution of 2 mgml -1 or 1 mgml -1 using NaCl or CaCl2 stock before each adsorption and intercalation experiment. The pH of DNA stock was additionally adjusted with 0.1 mM NaOH or 0.1 mM HCl. All pH measurements were conducted with Mettler Toledo FiveEasyPlus pH-meter using InLab Micro-Pro-SIM electrode calibrated on a daily basis with Roti ¬Æ CALIPURE standards (pH = 2 -9).

question: How does the lamellar d-spacing of pFAST-20-Li+G4 compare to that of dry pFAST-C20-Li and what does this indicate about Li+ coordination?
answer: The lamellar d-spacing for pFAST-20-Li+G4 is 35.7 √Ö, which is 2.3 √Ö larger than the 33.4 √Ö observed for dry pFAST-C20-Li. This difference is consistent with the expected size increase when Li+ is coordinated by G4 or crown ethers compared to Li+ alone.
context: Notably, VT-SAXS and VT-WAXS analysis (Figure ; Figure ) suggested that the G4-containing material maintained a highly ordered lamellar structure with scattering peaks at q1 = .166 √Ö -1 , 2q1, and 3q1 until ~100 ¬∞C. Moreover, the lamellar d-spacing for pFAST-20-Li + G4 (35.7 √Ö) was greater than that for dry pFAST-C20-Li (33.4 √Ö) by 2.3 √Ö, which is within the expected size difference of reported Li + coordinated by G4 or crown ethers compared to Li + alone. DSC analysis (Figure ) showed Tg and Tm transitions for pFAST-C20-Li + G4 that were >100 ¬∞C lower than for the dry ionene, indicative of plasticization, which is expected to increase ion conductivity. Finally, crystallization of G4 (Tc = -9.4 ¬∞C) was not observed, suggesting the presence of minimal bulk G4.

question: Under which growth conditions can Bi-CuSeO be effectively doped as an n-type material?
answer: Bi-CuSeO is n-type dopable under Cu-rich growth conditions.
context: Our calculated native defect formation energetics reveal that Bi-CuSeO is n-type dopable under Cu-rich growth conditions (Section 3.1). Combined with the fact that the n-type performance of BiCuSeO is predicted to surpass that of p-type (Section 1), it is worthwhile to search for efficient n-type dopants. In our search for n-type dopants, we assess 19 different elements, including those in group-1 (Li), group-3 (Sc, Y), group-4 (Ti, Zr, Hf), group-12 (Zn), group-13 (Al, Ga, In, Tl) group-14 (Si, Ge, Sn, Pb), and group-17 (F, Cl, Br, I).

question: What are the two principal challenges in synthesizing piperazine-fused 1,2-thiaselenanes?
answer: The challenges are achieving ring fusion diastereoselectivity (cis/trans) and ensuring regioselective chalcogen installation (SeS versus SSe), both of which are predicted to completely determine the biological selectivity.
context: Accessing piperazine-fused 1,2-thiaselenanes (SeSPs) faces two challenges: ring fusion diastereoselectivity (cis/trans), and regioselective chalcogen installation (SeS/SSe), that both were predicted to completely determine the biological selectivity. For diastereoselectivity, we could adapt routes to cis-/trans-piperazinefused disulfides that we previously 9 built by subjecting E/Z-olefins to Minakata's 1,2-anti-diamination then Ritter's 1,2-electrophile vinyl thianthrenium (VTT). However, we found no precedent to regioselectively access the desired Se-proximal probes (SeSC type) rather than the Se-distal control (SSeC type), so developing a scalable regiopure synthesis became our main focus. We aimed to set up orthogonal N-protecting groups in a common precursor 7, that could be removed selectively: e.g. replacing PG 1 to create Se-proximal probes, or PG 2 for Se-distal controls (Figure ).

question: What do the KIE values obtained from intra- and intermolecular competition experiments reveal about the dehydrogenation process of alcohols?
answer: The KIE values, kH/kD = 3.35, indicate that the cleavage of the C(sp3)-H bond adjacent to the hydroxyl group is the rate-limiting step in the dehydrogenation process.
context: A hybrid material composed of Ag nanoparticles (~66.4 wt. % of silver) deposited in situ at g-CN fibers upon calcining Ag-cyanoguanidine complex produces formaldehyde from methanol. Binuclear complex, [Me2(C16H33)2N]4[Pt2(pop-BF2)4] (see Figure for chemical structure), which comprise chromophore (onset of absorption at ~380 nm), photoredox and H2-evolution sites (Pt), mediate dehydrogenation of benzylic alcohols and nitrogen-containing heterocycles (Figure ). When reaction was performed in homogeneous fashion, i.e., using water/organic solvent mixture (2:1) in which all components are fully soluble, the catalyst yields up to 78% diphenylbutandiol. Employing two-phase system, water/CH2Cl2 (1:3) and the phase transfer reagent Bu4NCl, shifted selectivity completely to acetophenone. K4[Pt2(pop-BF2)4], however, failed to enable dehydrogenation of aliphatic alcohols. [Me2(C16H33)2N]4[Pt2(pop-BF2)4], which excited state is a stronger oxidant compared to K4[Pt2(pop-BF2)4], Ered +0.85 vs. +0.70 V (Fc + /Fc), 298 catalyzes dehydrogenation of secondary aliphatic alcohols upon irradiation at 365 nm. While primary alcohols, such as ethanol and n-butanol gave the corresponding aldehydes with <10% yield, butanediol-1,4 and pentanediol-1,5 gave Œ≥-butyrolactone and Œ¥-valerolactone with yields as high as 83%. KIE values (kH/kD = 3.35) obtained from intra-and intermolecular competition experiments revealed that cleavage of C(sp 3 )-H bond in Œ±-position to hydroxyl group is the rate-limiting step. Dehydrogenation of indoline in the presence of styrene gives phenylethyl indole, which supports involvement of Pt2-hydride and Pt2-CH(CH3)Ph, i.e., Pt acts as a catalytic site, while the reaction proceeds via inner sphere atom abstraction. Given that in anhydrous environment, pinacol coupling product is formed, it is likely that intermediary ketyl radicals remain bound to Pt long enough so that dimerization competes effectively with hydrogen atom transfer with the liberation of H2 and aldehyde. A catalytic system composed [Mes-Acr-Me]ClO4, thiophosphoric acid and Ni(Tf2)2 enables dehydrogenation of aliphatic alcohols to aldehydes (Figure ). Using the same catalytic system, esters were obtained from aldehydes and trichloroethanol with evolution of one H2 equivalent. Comparison of the ketone yield obtained from benzhydrol (11%) and dicyclohexylmethanol (72%) revealed that the reaction proceeds via Œ≤-hydride elimination from Ni species -the latter has Œ≤-C-H bond, while the former -does not. Dehydrogenation of admanatanol gave non-enolizable ketone with low (27%) yield suggesting the reaction proceeds via enol intermediate. Using cyclododecanol-d4 as the substrate, gave ketone with relatively high (84%) enrichment in H vs. D, again suggesting formation of enol. CdS modified with Ni (0) nanoparticles, which were photochemically deposited using NiCl2 enables dehydrogenation of methanol to formaldehyde. Differently from other reports, no H2 evolved in the absence of Ni salts. The AQY is 95% at 405 nm.

question: What specific reagents and conditions are required to achieve a 99% yield in the aziridination reaction of cyclohexene?
answer: The aziridination reaction is successfully carried out by using cyclohexene as the limiting reagent, along with N-aminopyridinium triflate, an excess of iodosylbenzene, and 4√Ö molecular sieves in hexafluoroisopropanol (HFIP), which is the optimal solvent. Additionally, using an excess of one of the key reagents is crucial, and commonly used metal salts such as AgOTf, Cu(I), Cu(II), Rh‚ÇÇ(tfacam)‚ÇÑ, and Mn(TPP)Cl negatively impact the reaction efficiency.
context: Using cyclohexene as an archetypal unactivated olefin, we identified conditions for highly efficient aziridination (99% NMR yield) to the corresponding N-pyridinium aziridine (5a) using N-aminopyridinium triflate, excess iodosylbenzene ( ), and 4√Ö molecules sieves in hexafluoroisopropanol (HFIP) (Equation ). Excess 4 is crucial to accomplish efficient aziridination using cyclohexene as the limiting reagent and the reaction is highly solvent dependent, with HFIP being optimal (see Supporting Information for optimization details and comparison with iodide-catalyzed conditions). Of significance, metal salts that are often utilized in aziridination catalysis, such as AgOTf, Cu(I), Cu(II), Rh2(tfacam)4, and Mn(TPP)Cl negatively impacted aziridination efficiency.

question: What is the general chemical formula of the Li-deficient antifluorite phases that form a solid solution on the Li3N-LiCl tie line?
answer: The general chemical formula is Li1+2xCl1-xNx, where x is between 0.33 and 0.5.
context: (1) Synthetically, we demonstrate that the antifluorite framework is compositionally flexible; Lideficient and Li-excess antifluorite phases can be mechanochemically stabilized. We find that the previously reported Li5NCl2 and Li9N2Cl3 phases (refs. 15,16) are both members of the same solid solution of Li-deficient antifluorite phases on the Li3N-LiCl tie line with the general chemical formula of Li1+2xCl1-xNx with 0.33< x <0.5. Additionally, we show that Li1+2xCl1-xNx phases are compositionally highly modifiable; we synthesize SCl-and BrCl-substituted analogues boosting the ionic conductivities of Li1+2xCl1-xNx phases by an order of magnitude enabling conductivity enhancements up to 0.2 mS cm -1 for Li2.31S0.41Br0.14N0.45.

context: Procedure for enzyme library curation. Sequence similarity networks (SSNs) were generated through EFI-EST using TropC as a BLAST query sequence with an e-value of 5 and an alignment score threshold of 100. The genes encoding tropC, xenC, and each of the 12 homologs were codon-optimized for overexpression in E. coli and synthesized by Twist Biosciences. The synthesized sequences were subcloned by Twist biosciences into a pET-28a vector containing the T7 expression system, kanamycin resistance, and N-terminal 6xHis-tag encoded upstream from the insert gene. Overexpression and preparation of clarified crude cell lysates of tropC, xenC, and homologs 1-12 was accomplished utilizing previously reported methods. In vitro analytical-scale reactions. Dearomatization reactions contained KPi buffer pH 8.0 (500 ¬µL, 1 M), 5 mM substrate (500 ŒºL, 1 M in DMSO), 1 mM NADP (100 ŒºL, 100 mM), 10 mM G6P (200 ŒºL, 500 mM), 5 U/mL G6PDH (500 ŒºL, 100 U/mL), and 40 mg/mL TropB lysate (2 mL, 200 mg/mL) diluted with milliQ water (6.2 mL) to a final volume of 10 mL in an Erlenmeyer flask fitted with a breathable cover. These were then shaken at 125 rpm at 30 ¬∞C for 18 h and monitored for conversion to the intermediate product by UPLC-DAD analysis. After 18 h, the reaction was divided into individual 500 ŒºL-scale ring expansion reactions with TropC, XenC, and the 12 homologs in 96-well plate format as follows: Each well contained 50 mM TES buffer pH 7.5 (25 ŒºL, 1 M), 2 mM substrate (200 ŒºL, 5 mM), 4 mM Œ±-KG (20 ŒºL, 100 mM), 4 mM sodium ascorbate (20 ŒºL, 100 mM), 10 mM Fe2SO4 (10 ŒºL, 10 mM), and 40 mg/mL NHI lysate (100 ŒºL, 200 mg/mL) diluted with milliQ water (125 ŒºL) to a final volume of 500 ŒºL. 96-well plates were shaken at 300 rpm at 30 ¬∞C for 4 h and quenched by addition of 3 volumes of MeOH containing 500 ŒºM pentamethylbenzene as an internal standard. Precipitated biological debris was pelleted by centrifugation of the 96-well plates (1250 x g, 20 min). The supernatant was analyzed by UPLC-DAD and conversion obtained by comparison of the dearomatized substrate and ring expanded product peaks.

question: How do the carbon shifts for vinylic protons differ between isomers with the hydroperoxide on the glycerol side of the double bond and those on the methyl terminal end?

context: They corresponded to hydroperoxides next to an E -double bond (O1) and to hydroperoxides next to a Z -double bond (O2). The isomer with a hydroperoxide on the glycerol side of the double bond (e.g., 9Z -8-HPOME, 10E -9-HPOME) have a slightly lower carbon shift for the vinylic protons than the isomers with the hydroperoxide on the methyl terminal end of the fatty acid (8E -10-HPOME, 9Z -11-HPOME) (Figure ), which enables determining the ratio of 8-HPOME + 9-HPOME relative to 10-HPOME + 11-HPOME.

question: Which ruthenium complex demonstrated catalytic activity comparable to Ru-1 at 120 ¬∞C, and what does the observed ligand behavior under high-temperature conditions imply?
answer: Ru-3 exhibited catalytic activity comparable to Ru-1 at 120 ¬∞C. The results imply that the trans ligands in these complexes likely remain coordinated to ruthenium or dissociate only very slowly, even under harsh thermal conditions.
context: Interestingly, the initial screening shows that Ru-3 exhibits high catalytic activity, comparable to Ru-1 at 120 ¬∞C (Entry 5 vs Entry 1). At the same temperature, Ru-2 and the phosphine complexes Ru-6 and Ru-7 also demonstrate good conversion rates (75%, 99%, and 94%, respectively) and yields towards GVL (76%, 87%, and 82%, respectively, entries 3, 9, and 11). In contrast, Ru-4, Ru-5, and Ru-11 show lower conversion rates (entries 7, 8, and 13). Based on ATR-IR data, hydride NMR shifts, and XRD bond lengths, this outcome was expected for the DMF complex (Ru-4) but unexpected for the DMSO complex (Ru-5). Moreover, the vastly different outcomes based on different trans ligands suggests that these ligands, or at least most of them, either stay coordinated to Ru or dissociate only slowly under these thermally harsh conditions.

question: What role do tetra-alkyl ammonium chlorides play in enhancing the solubility of the reduced anthraquinone derivatives when CO‚ÇÇ is present?
answer: Tetra-alkyl ammonium chlorides, when used as supporting salts, prevent the formation of bright yellow precipitates by forming loose ion pairs with the reduced anthraquinones. This looser pairing, which includes more water molecules separating the ions, weakens Coulomb attractions and leads to clear, transparent bright yellow solutions.
context: Informed by a decade of endeavors in developing aqueous anthraquinone flow batteries, 35-41 we selected three anthraquinone derivatives that are aqueous-soluble at neutral pH: 2,7-disulfonated anthraquinone (AQDS), 1,8-bis(2-(2-(2-hydroxyethoxy)ethoxy)ethoxy)anthracene-9,10-dione (AQ-1,8-3E-OH), and 2,2‚Ä≤-((9,10-dioxo-9,10dihydroanthracene-2,6-diyl)bis(oxy))-dipropionic acid (2,6-D2PEAQ) (Figure ). Although those quinones show decent aqueous solubility in both oxidized and reduced states, bright yellow precipitates formed when CO2 was introduced to the reduced electrolytes. The yellow precipitates did not form, and clear solutions were afforded when tetra-alkyl ammonium chlorides were used as the supporting salts (Figure , Table ). Specifically, substituting 1 M NaCl with 1 M tetramethylammonium chloride (TMACl) as the supporting salt in 0.1 M AQDS electrolyte (Figure ), replacing 1 M KCl with 1 M tetrabutylammonium chloride (TBACl) as the supporting salt in 0.1 M 2,6-D2PEAQ (Figure ) or in 0.1 M AQ-1,8-3E-OH electrolytes produce transparent bright yellow solutions. One plausible explanation is that the bulky, amphiphilic tetra-alkyl ammonium cations and Q(CO2)2 2-can form loose ion pairs rather than the tight ion pairs between alkali metal cations and Q(CO2)2 2-. There are more water molecules separating positively and negatively charged ions in loose ion pairs than in tight ion pairs, weakening the Coulomb attraction and enhancing solubility. However, the bulkiness of tetra-alkyl ammonium cations causes extremely high cell resistance (Figure ) in the flow cell systems because, in such cells, cation-exchange membranes must be used, resulting in prohibitively high energetic cost. Inspired by the observation of dramatic change in aqueous solubility of reduced AQs in the presence of CO2 caused by tetra-alkyl ammonium salts (Figure , Table ), we hypothesized that anthraquinone derivatives tethered with bulky alkyl ammonium cations via covalent bonds might not only have high aqueous solubility in all states, but also be compatible with anion exchange membranes: the oxidized forms are positively charged and the reduced forms are charge-neutral but large in size, with correspondingly low expected cross-over rates. We designed and synthesized 1,4-, 1,5-, 1,8-, and 2,6-bis [3-(trimethylammonio)propyl]-anthraquinone (BTMAPAQs) in which the numbers represent the positions of water-solubilizing chains (TMAP) bonded to anthraquinone (AQ) core. Of the four isomers, 2,6-BTMAPAQ exhibits very limited solubility (< 0.1 M) even in its oxidized state (Table ); 1,8-BTMAPAQ(CO2)2 2-becomes soluble when TBA + is used as the supporting salt cation (Figure ); 1,4-, and 1,5-BTMAPAQs are soluble in all states even if KCl is used as the supporting salt. Therefore, 1,4-, 1,5-, and 1,8-BTMAPAQs (Figure ) were investigated for electrochemical CO2 capture. . (e) NMR specimens, from left to right in the same order as the molecular structures in (d), and their 1 H NMR (f) and 13 C NMR (g) spectra. Note that 1 H NMR peak broadening was initially observed from the electrochemically reduced aqueous quinone due to the occurrence of residual radicals, but addition of a tiny amount of HCl afforded well-defined peak splitting in the aromatic region (Figure , orange). The chemical shift at 124.6 ppm in 1,5-BTMAPAQ(CO2)2 2-(Figure , purple, identified with asterisk) is from the dissolved CO2. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) was employed to investigate BTMAPAQs in buffered and unbuffered solutions. As shown in Figure , at pH 7 in N2, 1,5-BTMAPAQ exhibits a redox potential of -0.465 V vs. SHE with a peak separation of 90 mV. When the solution was constantly purged with CO2, the major cathodic peak appears at -0.51 V along with a minor cathodic peak at -0.28 V (Figure ), which might be caused by a CO2 buffering effect, enabling 1,5-BTMAPAQ to partially undergo a PCET process. The anodic peak of 1,5-BTMAPAQ largely shifts to +0.28 V, suggesting that extra energy is required to trigger the electrochemical oxidation: 1,5-BTMAPAQ(CO2)2 2-√† 1,5-BTMAPAQ + 2CO2 + 2e -. Similar electrochemical behaviors were also shown by 1,4-and 1,8-BTMAPAQs.

question: How does the aziridination stereoselectivity vary for different sizes of cyclic alkenes?
answer: Aziridination of five- and six-membered cyclic alkenes results in exclusively cis-aziridines, whereas eight-membered cyclic alkenes yield both cis and trans aziridines. For example, one eight-membered cyclic alkene produced a cis to trans ratio of 6.25:1 with the cis isomer isolable at analytical purity, while another case using 1,5-cyclooctadiene gave a 1:1 mixture with the trans product confirmed by single-crystal X-ray diffraction.
context: Figure depicts the array of aliphatic alkenes that participate in efficient aziridination. Yields are based on isolated N-pyridinium aziridines from reactions on 0.30 mmol scale; in some cases, both NMR and isolated yields are provided to emphasize that aziridination is typically efficient but isolation of highly polar N-pyridinium aziridines can be challenging. Cyclic alkenes (cyclohexene, cyclopentene, cyclooctene, and 3-carene) engaged in efficient aziridination to afford pyridinium aziridines 5a to 5d, respectively. Five-and six-membered aziridines are formed with exclusively cis-stereochemistry. For 8-membered cyclic alkenes, both cis-and trans-aziridines are observed (c-5c : t-5c = 6.25 : 1.00; 73% yield). Cis-5c could be isolated at analytical purity and the stereochemical assignment was based on measured coupling constants in the 1 H NMR spectrum. Assignment of cis-/ trans-mixtures was bolstered by aziridination with 1,5cyclooctadiene 5f, which afforded a 1.0 : 1.0 c-5f : t-5f mixture (69% yield, Figure ). The transstereochemistry of t-5f was confirmed by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Norbornene undergoes exo-aziridination to afford 5e in 69% yield; the stereochemistry of aziridination was confirmed by single-crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD) following cross coupling (vide infra). Terminal alkenes with different functional groups including alkyl halide, ester, nitrile, and azide underwent aziridination with good yield (5g to 5p). N-Heterocycles were tolerated as demonstrated in the aziridination of 2q. With 4-vinyl homoallylbenzene 2r, aziridination occurred selectively at the styrenyl C=C bond to afford 5r in 65% isolated yield. imine by-products (vide infra); for carvone, the imine byproduct (5z') was isolated in 18% yield.

question: How does the DSC experiment demonstrate that ZIF compounds can be vitrified using ball milling at room temperature?
answer: The DSC experiment shows a well-defined glass transition signal in ZIF glass formers after only 5 minutes of ball milling, indicating that the materials transition to a supercooled liquid upon heating. This confirms that vitrification is achieved by room temperature ball milling rather than by heating past the melting points and melt-quenching.
context: With the aim of screening the samples for thermal phase changes, additional cyclic DSC experiments (two upscans, one downscan) were performed between ambient temperature and Td also under N2 atmosphere (Figures 6, S74-77 and S85). Excitingly, the ZIFs which are known glass formers (ZIF-62(M), ZIF-4(M), ZIF-zni(Zn), ZIF-76/UC-5 and TIF-4) exhibit a welldefined glass transition signal in the first upscan of the DSC already after only 5 minutes of PSBM (Figures and). Hence, these PSBM-amorphized materials represent ZIF MIGs that transition to a supercooled liquid upon heating. This proves that the vitrification of these compounds can be achieved by ball milling at room temperature instead of heating across the materials' melting points, followed by melt-quenching. The DSC data of both ZIF-4(Zn/Co) and ZIF-zni(Zn/Co) reveal distinct thermal characteristics (Figure and). Similar to crystalline ZIF-4(Zn), which recrystallizes to ZIF-zni(Zn) after thermal amorphization, the MIGs ZIF-4(Zn)-5min, -10min and -15min, also recrystallize to the ZIF-zni(Zn) polymorph after passing through their glass transition (confirmed by variable temperature XRPD, Figure ). Interestingly, the recrystallization temperature (Trc) and the corresponding enthalpy (‚àÜHrc) decrease slightly with increased milling time (Table -S8).

question: What are the hydrogen uptake capacities of ZOF-1 at 77 K and 87 K under 1 bar, and what is the isosteric heat of adsorption for H2?
answer: The hydrogen uptake capacities of ZOF-1 are 223 cm¬≥/g (1.99 wt%) at 77 K and 154 cm¬≥/g (1.38 wt%) at 87 K under 1 bar, and the isosteric heat of adsorption for H2 is 6.37 kJ/mol.
context: We further investigated the H2 adsorption performance of ZOF-1. As shown in Figures showed a high capacity in H2 uptake up to 223 cm 3 /g (1.99 wt%) at 77 K and 154 cm 3 /g (1.38 wt%) at 87 K at 1 bar, which is comparable with best performing porous materials, such as CTC-COF (125 cm 3 /g or 1.12 wt%), MOF-177 (139 cm 3 /g or 1.25 wt%), PAF-1 (179 cm 3 /g or 1.60 wt%). Furthermore, the isosteric heat of adsorption (Qst) of ZOF-1 for H2 was calculated to be 6.37 kJ/mol (Figure ). In addition, we studied the potential application of ZOF-1 for CO2 adsorption and separation. The adsorption isotherms of CO2, N2, and CH4 were measured at 273 K (Figure ). Notably, the sorption amount of ZOF-1 for CO2 was as high as 78.78 cm 3 /g, which is much higher than the other two gases, CH4 (32.34 cm 3 /g) and N2 (7.01 cm 3 /g). The ideal adsorption selectivity of ZOF-1 was calculated from the ratio of the initial slopes based on the Henry region of the isotherms (Figure ), and good selectivity of CO2/N2 (6.7) or CO2/CH4 (19.1) was observed (Table ).

question: How is the bright yellow solid DAP-I synthesized from (DAP)2?
answer: A stirred suspension of (DAP)2 (797 mg, 2.00 mmol) in 6 mL of MeCN is reacted with iodobenzene (223 ¬µL, 408 mg, 1.00 mmol) at room temperature. The mixture is stirred for 2 hours, after which all volatiles are removed in vacuo, and the remaining bright yellow solid is washed with n-pentane and dried in vacuo to yield DAP-I (608 mg, 93%).
context: Outside the glovebox, the prior obtained solution of LiAlD4 in Et2O was added to a stirred solution of DAP-Br (2.79 g, 10.0 mmol, 1.00 equiv.) in THF (70 mL) inside a Schlenk tube at -78 ¬∞C. The mixture was stirred for further 30 min at this temperature and was allowed to reach rt, at which the stirring was continued for additional All spectroscopic data in corresponded to the reported literature values. 1,3-Di-tert-butyl-2-iodo-2,3-dihydro-1H-1,3,2-diazaphosphole (DAP-I) g) To a stirred suspension of (DAP)2 (797 mg, 2.00 mmol, 1.00 equiv.) in MeCN (6 mL) was added iodobenzene (223 ¬µL, 408 mg, 1.00 mmol, 1.00 equiv.) at rt. The mixture was stirred for 2 h and all volatiles were removed in vacuo. The bright yellow solid residue was washed with n-pentane and dried in vacuo to afford DAP-I (608 mg, 1.86 mmol, 93 %) as a bright yellow solid.

question: Why is the oxidation to monoanions challenging, and how do the two oxidants used influence the outcome of oxidizing (NBu4)2tripak (2-a)?
answer: Oxidizing to monoanions is challenging because the electrochemical stability window ‚Äì the difference between the reduction potential Ered 1-/0 and the oxidation potential Eox 2-/1- ‚Äì is very narrow, varying among solvents (285 mV in THF, 227 mV in MeCN, 158 mV in DCM, and only 109 mV in DMF). When (NBu4)2tripak (2-a) is oxidized with Ce(IV) in the form of (NBu4)2[Ce IV (NO3)6], a mixed-valence salt forms in which each tripak anion is accompanied by 1.5 NBu4+ cations, indicating both tripak1‚Äì and tripak2‚Äì coexist. In contrast, using [Fe III (phen)3](PF6)3 as the oxidant in MeCN leads to a smooth reaction that yields a tripak1‚Äì salt incorporating the diamagnetic [Fe II (phen)3]2+ countercation and PF6‚Äì as an additional counteranion.
context: Oxidation to monoanions is particularly challenging as the electrochemical stability window for this valence state calculated as the difference between Ered 1-/0 and Eox 2-/1-(see Table ) is narrow: 285 mV in THF, 227 mV in MeCN, 158 mV in DCM and only 109 mV in DMF. A suitable oxidant needs to meet several requirements: 1e -oxidation must take place in a narrow electrochemical window, the oxidant must be soluble either in THF or MeCN and should facilitate the removal of the redundant organic cations. Ce(IV) in the form of the tetrabutylammonium salt of [Ce IV (NO3)6] 2-anion: (NBu4)2[Ce IV (NO3)6] (CTAN) was found to be suitable (Ce IV /Ce III couple E1/2 = +0.610 V vs Fc/Fc + in MeCN, Figure in the SI). However, the corresponding oxidation of (NBu4)2tripak (2-a) resulted in the formation of a mixed-valence salt, in which each tripak anion was accompanied by 1.5 NBu4 + cations: (NBu4)1.5tripak‚Ä¢4THF (1-b) that leads to the conclusion that it comprises both tripak 1-and tripak 2-in a 1:1 ratio. Therefore, another oxidant was used to prepare tripak 1-: [Fe III (phen)3](PF6)3 with formal potential of the Fe III /Fe II couple E1/2 = +0.696 V vs Fc/Fc + in MeCN, Figure in the SI). Oxidation of (NBu4)2tripak (2-a) in MeCN with [Fe III (phen)3](PF6)3 proceeds smoothly resulting in the formation of tripak 1-salt that incorporates the diamagnetic [Fe II (phen)3] 2+ as the countercation and PF6 -as an additional counteranion: [Fe II (phen

question: What types of substituents on aryl acylsilanes were found to be compatible with the coupling reaction and what yield range was observed?
answer: Aryl acylsilanes bearing both electron-rich and electron-deficient groups, such as methoxy, methyl, tert-butyl, phenyl, chloro, bromo, and iodo substituents, were compatible with the reaction. The corresponding products were obtained in yields ranging from 46% to 80%.
context: Next, we turned to investigate the substrate scope of acylsilanes (Scheme 4). Employing 1,3-benzoxazole (2a) as the model substrate, a wide range of acylsilanes were well tolerated, providing the corresponding products in moderate to excellent yields. This protocol is compatible with a variety of aryl acylsilanes bearing both electron-rich and electron-deficient functional groups. As listed in Scheme 4, functional groups such as methoxy (4a, 4i), methyl (4b, 4h), tert-butyl (4c), phenyl (4d), chloro (4e, 4j), bromo (4f) and iodo (4g) etc., are all tolerated, providing corresponding coupling products in 46-80% yields. In addition, polycyclic aromatic substituted acylsilanes including 1-naphthyl (4l) and 2-naphthyl (4m) are also suitable substrates, delivering the corresponding products in moderate yields. Notably, this coupling reaction underwent with high chemoselectivity when acylsilane substrate 4k containing a terminal alkene was employed. The cyclopropanation of terminal alkene was not observed with electron-rich siloxy cupper carbene species under our conditions. The piperonyl substituted acylsilane 4n couple with benzoxazole in 53% yield. The acylsilane bearing thienyl group (4o) is also reactive under our conditions. It is noteworthy that our protocol could be used in the late-stage installation of azoles in bioactive molecules. Substrates derived from citronellol (4p), pitavastatin int P1 (4q) and D-ribofuranoside derivative (4r) are all reactive, providing corresponding products in 53-61% yields.

question: How was spatial patterning implemented in the system?
answer: Spatial patterning was implemented by illuminating a spatial light modulator with a 405 nm single mode diode laser, which was then integrated into the iSCAT beam path using a dichroic filter.
context: LED illumination was delivered via a liquid light guide (pE4000/pE1906, CoolLED) placed 10 mm above the reaction chamber. Spatial patterning was achieved via 405 nm single mode diode laser illumination of a SLM (SN 4719, Meadowlark Optics) combined into the iSCAT beam path via a dichroic filter (Di01-E405, Semrock) (Fig. ).

question: What illumination conditions were applied during the decarboxylation reaction?
answer: The reactions were illuminated using 455 nm LEDs at a photon flux density of 42 ¬µmol‚Ä¢L‚Åª¬π‚Ä¢s‚Åª¬π, with constant shaking at 500 rpm.
context: General procedure for the decarboxylation of palmitic acid in batch. A 1.5 mL screw cap vial was charged with Tris‚Ä¢HCl buffer (100 mM, pH 8.5), the lyophilized lysate or purified CvFAP dissolved in the same buffer (700 ¬µL total volume), 65 mM palmitic acid in DMSO (200 ¬µL) and DMSO (100 ¬µL), unless stated otherwise. The reactions were illuminated for the designated amount of time, using 455 nm LEDs at 42 ¬µmol‚Ä¢L -1 ‚Ä¢s -1 photon flux density (unless stated otherwise), and with constant shaking of 500 rpm. Reactions were run in triplicates, unless stated otherwise. Aliquots (500 ¬µL) were taken from each reaction mixture, diluted with brine (500 ¬µL), and acidified with hydrochloric acid (6 M, 50 ¬µL). The mixtures were extracted with ethyl acetate containing ndecanol (5 mM) (2 √ó 500 ¬µL, 300 ¬µL were withdrawn after the first extraction, and 500 ¬µL after the second extraction). All mixtures were centrifuged after each extraction step. The combined organic phases (total volume 800 ¬µL) were dried over anhydrous Na2SO4. Each sample (100 ¬µL) was then derivatized with a mixture of BSTFA/pyridine (1:1 v/v, 200 ¬µL) and heated at 60 ¬∞C, 600 rpm shaking, for 1 h and analyzed by GC-FID.

When these criteria are met, both Kdyn C‚ÜíB and Kdyn A‚ÜíB exceed their equilibrium counterparts, leading to complete selectivity and yield of B as ŒîBE B approaches infinity.

question: What are the components of the HyBRID solution and how is its acidity controlled?
answer: The solution is composed of hydrazine monohydrate, sulfuric acid, copper(II) sulfate, and magnetite powder, and its acidity is controlled by using sulfuric acid to achieve a pH of 2.6 (¬±0.05).
context: The chemicals used in the HyBRID solutions were hydrazine monohydrate (N2H4 . H2O, 80%, Junsei chemical, extra pure reagent), sulfuric acid (H2SO4, Showa, guaranteed extra pure reagent), copper (II) sulfate (CuSO4, 97.5%, Junsei chemical, extra pure), and magnetite powder (Fe3O4, Junsei chemical >99%). All of the experimental solutions were made in demineralized water. Experiments on the magnetite dissolution were performed in a stirred batch glass reactor using the solution. Since hydrazine is basic, H2SO4 was used to reach a pH of 2.6 (¬±0.05), to prepare an acidic HyBRID solution.

question: What solvent was used to dissolve the reactants in the synthesis of PAAm and what technique was implemented to eliminate oxygen?
answer: Anhydrous DMSO was used to dissolve the reactants, and the solution was bubbled with dry argon for 20 minutes to remove dissolved oxygen.
context: PAAm was synthesized as follows. A mixture of AAm (135 eq., 4 mmol, 0.28 g) (total mole = 4 mmol), CDP (1 eq., 0.03 mmol, 11.9 mg) and AIBN (0.6 eq., 0.018 mmol, 2.9 mg) was dissolved in anhydrous DMSO (3 mL). The solution was bubbled with dry argon to remove dissolved oxygen for 20 min at room temperature and then immersed in a preheated oil bath at 70 ¬∞C overnight. The solution was then rapidly cooled under air. The polymer was precipitated into cold THF and then washed three times using cold volumes of THF and centrifugations (5,000 rpm, 10 min). PAAm obtained was then dried under high vacuum until to give 310 mg of white powder. The purified polymer was characterized by 1 H-NMR and SEC. (m, 2H), 2.02-2.22 (s, 1H), 6.60-7.36 (dd, 2H).

question: How does substituting glycine at position 305 with glutamic acid affect the enzyme's product profile?
answer: Replacing glycine 305 with glutamic acid leads to the formation of the sesquiterpene alcohol selin-7(11)-en-4-ol (20%), a compound not produced by the wild-type, along with selina-4(15),7(11)-diene as the major product (52.9%). Furthermore, the mutation causes a significant alteration in the active site water cluster compared to the G305D replacement.
context: G305 in the K-helix of SdS (corresponding to S303 in AS and H320 in Gd11olS) was investigated next. Although replacement of G305 with H and D did not change the product profile, replacement with E resulted in the formation of the sesquiterpene alcohol selin-7(11)-en-4-ol (10, 20%), which is not produced by wild-type, along with selina-4(15),7(11)-diene as a major product (52.9%, Figure , Table ). Notably, G305E caused a more significant change in the active site water cluster compared to G305D in our FDP-complex MD simulations (Figure ). Formation of selin-7(11)-en-4-ol ( ) is expected to arise from hydroxylation of carbocation B on C3, instead of deprotonation of C15 to form selina-4(15),7(11)-diene (2, Scheme 1). SdS W304S and SdS W304E were also created, as this is expected to increase water availability around carbocation B (see e.g., Figure ), but these variants did not result in hydroxylated product formation: both variants produced germacrene B (3) as major product along with reduced level of selina-4(15),7(11)-diene (2) (Figure , Table ).

question: How did the performance of the Ni(COD)(DQ) complex compare to other nickel sources in terms of product yields?
answer: The Ni(COD)(DQ) complex enabled nearly quantitative coupling, achieving a 95% yield for substrate 1a, which was significantly higher than the 63% to 69% yields observed with other nickel sources.
context: Initially, a screen of different Ni sources was undertaken under our standard conditions, which for the purpose of this report shall mean reaction of aryl halide (0.7 mmol), a Ni source (0.07 mmol), KOtBu (1.4 mmol) and benzene (5 mL) at 130 o C for 16h in a 25 mL pressure tube under a N2 atmosphere, unless otherwise stated. As expected, in the absence of a Ni source, the coupled products from 1a and 1b were obtained in low yields (13 % and 15%, Table , entries 1-2) which, under these conditions, is proposed to arise via a benzyne-initiated BHAS mechanism. The addition of Ni(OAc)2 provided only marginally improved yields in coupled products obtained from 1a and 1b (15% and 20%, entries 3-4). Ni(acac)2 (acac = 2,4-pentanedionate), Ni(PPh3)4 and Ni(COD)2 (COD = 1,5-cyclooctadiene) facilitated coupling in good yields (63% -69%, entries 5-10). Recently, the Engle lab reported that bench-stable 18-electron complex Ni(COD)(DQ) (DQ = duroquinone) serves as an active pre-catalyst in a variety of Ni-mediated reactions. Inspired by the simple synthesis and remarkable stability of this complex, it was employed in our system. Pleasingly, Ni(COD)(DQ) facilitated the coupling in excellent yields (entries 11 and 12), with near quantitative coupling of 1a (95%). [a] isolated yields

question: What is the overall binding energy of the fortunellin-nucleocapsid CTD complex and its standard deviation?
answer: The overall binding energy is -51.3094 kcal/mol with a standard deviation of ¬±3.7282 kcal/mol.
context: Similarly, the stability of the Nucleocapsid CTD complexed with fortunellin was examined. The RMSD value was observed to vary between 0.70 ¬±.12 nm (figure )). The low fluctuations indicate that the protease has not undergone significant structural changes. The Rg value varied within a narrow range of 1.7¬±0.1 nm, suggesting the compactness and integrity of the produced complex (figure )). The distance between fortunellin and nucleocapsid CTD was found to a minimum of 0.2 nm (figure )). The important residues had a low RMSF value of 0.25 nm on average throughout the simulation (figure )). Throughout the simulation, there are an average of 2-3 H-bonds, showing the protein-ligand complex's stability (figure )). Furthermore, we used the representative snapshot of the most populated cluster acquired from the 70-100ns simulations to analyze the CTD-fortunellin interactions. Fortunellin showed non-polar hydrophobic interactions with Phe274, Phe286, Ile304, Ala305, Phe307, Ala308, Pro309, Ala311, Phe314, Phe315, Trp330, Leu331, Tyr333, Ala336, Ile337, Leu353, and Ile357 residues in complex with nucleocapsid C-terminal dimerization domain. During complex formation, there were polar contacts with Gln260, Gln281, Thr282, Gln283, Asn285, Ser310, Ser312, Ser318, Thr325, and Thr332 residues, as well as a charged interaction with Arg277 and Glu280 (figure (IV-F)). MM-GBSA energy calculations revealed that fortunellin has the highest binding affinity to N-CTD of any target under consideration. Figure ) depicts the overall binding energy as -51.3094kcal/mol with a standard deviation of ¬±3.7282kcal/mol. Arg259, Gln260, Phe274, Arg277, Gly284, Asn285, Phe286, Leu291, Trp301, Ile304, Phe307, Ala308, Pro309, Ser310, Ala311, Phe314, Phe315, Tyr333, Ile337, Leu353, and Ile357 are among the residues that contribute to binding affinity (figure )). All energies are in kcal/mol along with their standard deviation. ŒîE VDW , van der Waals contribution from MM; ŒîE EEL , electrostatic energy as calculated by the MM force field; ŒîG GB , the electrostatic contribution to the solvation free energy calculated by GB; ŒîG Surf , solvent-accessible surface area; ŒîG Sol , solvation free energy; ŒîG gas , gas-phase interaction energy and ŒîG bind , is the binding free energy.

question: What are the components of the Buffered Charcoal Yeast Extract (BCYE) agar used to grow the L. pneumophila strains?
answer: The BCYE agar comprises 10 g/L yeast extract, 10 g/L ACES buffer (pH 6.9), 0.4 g/L L-cysteine, 0.25 g/L iron (III) nitrate, 15 g/L agar, and for mutant strains, 20 ¬µg/mL kanamycin.
context: L. pneumophila Corby wild type and Œîmip 21 strains were grown on Buffered Charcoal Yeast Extract (BCYE) agar (10 g/L yeast extract and 10 g/L ACES (N-(2-Acetamido)-2-aminoethanesulfonic acid) buffer [pH 6.9] supplemented with 0.4 g/L L-cysteine, 0.25 g/L iron (III) nitrate, 15 g/L agar, and 20 ¬µg/mL kanamycin for mutant strains). Plate grown bacteria were used to inoculate Buffered Yeast Extract (YEB) medium (10 g/L yeast extract, 10 g/L ACES buffer [pH 6.9] supplemented with 0.4 g/L L-cysteine and 0.25 g/L iron (III) pyrophosphate), and the cultures were grown till they reached stationary growth phase. Bacteria were adjusted to an OD600nm of 0.01 in YEB, and let grown with substances at concentrations ranging from 100 ¬µM to 3,125 ¬µM in a volume of 100 ¬µL for 24 h. Bacterial growth was measured at OD600nm using a microplate fluorimeter (TECAN Infinite¬Æ M Nano).

question: What changes in national mean pollutant exposures were reported for the study period regarding both the five pollutants from 1990 to 2010 and PM2.5 from 2000 to 2010?
answer: The national mean exposures for the five pollutants decreased by an average of 40% from 1990 to 2010‚Äîwith reductions ranging from -6% for O3 to -71% for SO2 and -34% to -55% for the remaining three pollutants‚Äîwhile PM2.5 exposures decreased by 29% from 2000 to 2010.
context: National mean pollution levels of all six pollutants fell over the study period. For example, from 1990 to 2010, the national mean exposures decreased for all five pollutants by an average of 40% relative to national mean exposures in 1990 (range: -6% [O3] to -71% [SO2]; -34% to -55% for remaining three pollutants). PM2.5 exposures decreased 29% from 2000 to 2010 (Table ).

question: What differences in emission wavelength and aggregation behavior are observed for (1,7)tBuCzpPhTrz when comparing devices using a co-host system to those using DPEPO?
answer: The emission wavelength for (1,7)tBuCzpPhTrz is 475 nm in the co-host system, which is blue-shifted compared to 490 nm observed with DPEPO. Additionally, aggregates causing a red-shift in emission appear only at higher doping concentrations in the co-host system, indicating a reduced tendency to aggregate compared to DPEPO.
context: (1,7)tBuCzpPhTrz was 475 nm, which was blue-shifted compared to the device using DPEPO (490 nm), but is close to the lPL (467 nm in 1:1 mCP:PPT). These results point to a reduced propensity to aggregate in the co-host system compared to DPEPO for the vacuum-deposited films with (1,7)tBuCzpPhTrz. Indeed, aggregates were found to contribute to a red-shifting of the emission of (1,7)tBuCzpPhTrz in the 1:1 mCP:PPT co-host only at higher doping concentrations (Figure ). The CIE coordinates for the device with (1,4)tBuCzpPhTrz were (0.19, 0.38) while those for the device with (1,7)tBuCzpPhTrz were (0.16, 0.27) (Figure ).

question: What do the measured low quantum yields reveal about the reaction mechanism?
answer: The measured quantum yields, which are much less than one, indicate that a chain reaction is unlikely to play a significant role in the process, although a short, inefficient chain mechanism cannot be completely ruled out.
context: To assess the potential contribution of a chain mechanism, we determined the quantum yield (Œ¶) of the reaction. Using potassium ferrioxalate actinometry, we established a radiant flux of 9.6 ¬± 0.6 nE/s. 32a, Irradiating the reaction with substrate 1a for a one-hour under identical conditions gave a quantum yield of Œ¶Ce = 0.0025 ¬± 0.0008 and Œ¶Ce-free = 0.00111 ¬± 0.00008 (see SI for details). Theese low quantum yields (Œ¶ ‚â™ 1) suggest that a chain reaction is unlikely but cannot be entirely ruled out based on these experiments alone. 32c Poor excited-state quenching kinetics may also contribute to the low Œ¶-values, as indicated by our steady-state emission kinetics experiments. 32c Additionally, Julia's pioneering work on HAT cyclizations of C(sp¬≥-H) acids shows that short, inefficient chains are possible. Based on these mechanistic investigations, we propose the following tentative catalytic cycles (Scheme 3). Under cerium-employing conditions A, we propose an Xligand exchange between the putative complex [Et4N]3[Ce III Cl6] and LiTFA to give a Ce(III)‚Ä¢O2CCF3 complex. The Œ≤-ketoester substrates then coordinate with this Ce(III)carboxylate, triggering a metalation deprotonation event that exchanges carboxylate and enolate ligands. The newly formed ketoester‚Ä¢Ce(III) complex is then oxidized by photoexcited 9,10-DPA* to give a ketoester‚Ä¢Ce(IV) complex and radical anion 9,10-DPA ‚Ä¢-(E1/2(DPA/DPA ‚Ä¢-) = -1.80 V vs SCE in MeCN). The Ce(IV)‚Ä¢ketoester complex may then undergo thermal or photochemical LMCT, oxidizing the ketoester to furnish radical II and reducing Ce(IV) back to /PhS -) = +0.16 V vs SCE in MeCN). Thiolate V then deprotonates trifluoroacetic acid, regenerating carboxylate X and yielding TRIPSH (VI) (pKa(S-H) ~7 in water, pKa(CF3COO-H) -0.25 in water). HAT from TRIPSH (VI) to C-centred radical III regenerates thiyl species IV simultaneously forming the closed shell ketolactone product 2a (BDE(TRIPS-H) ~83 kcal/mol, BDE (primary alkyl C-H) ~100 kcal/mol, kHAT ~1x10 8 M -1 s -1 ). Activation of the substrate differs under Ce-free conditions (B) compared to Ce-conditions (A). We propose that dicarbonyl substrates bind LiTFA, forming a PCETcompetent substrate‚Ä¢LiTFA complex VII. This cvomplex can undergo a MS-PCET with photoexcited 9,10-DPA*, transferring a proton to LiTFA while reducing the photocatalyst simultaneously (BDE(PhO-H) ~92 kcal/mol, 37 effective BDFE ~91 kcal/mol, see SI). The remaining steps to complete the multicatalytic cycle operate identically to the cycles described for condition A.

question: What are the energy barriers for the two-step ligand hopping events, and what does this indicate about the diffusion process?
answer: The ligand hopping events have energy barriers of +0.32 eV from IS1 to IS2 and +0.38 eV from IS2 to IS3, indicating that the two-step diffusion process is kinetically favored while requiring alternating hopping events to maintain the proper geometric configuration.
context: During the growth of copper surface oxides, T-Cu2O (Fig. ) exemplifies compact morphologies, developed by efficient precursor diffusion and slower attachment processes . The terrace diffusion mechanisms of Cu3Ox was evaluated in Figs. , which are pivotal for the growth of T-Cu2O via subsequent coalescence when followed by coalescence. This process is formed by two energetically favorable unstrained Cu3O4 states (ŒîEads = +0 eV, Fig. and) and a less favorable strained state (ŒîEads = +0.30 eV, Fig. ). Secondly, a two-step mechanism, involves less restricted ligand hopping events (IS1 ‚Üí IS2, Ediff(2,1) = +0.32 eV; IS2 ‚Üí IS3, Ediff(2,2) = +0.38 eV), suggesting a kinetically favored process, although alternating hopping events must occur in sequence for maintaining the geometric feasibility of the two-step diffusion process .

question: What are the specific characteristics of the out-of-plane N-H deformation mode in terms of its wavenumber, IR intensity, percentage of electronic displacement (PED), and Raman activity?
answer: The out-of-plane N-H deformation, known as the Œ≥N-H mode, is observed at 612 cm‚Åª¬π with an IR intensity of 60.95, a PED of 73%, and a low Raman activity of less than 10.00.
context: In the present case the N-H in-plane deformation band is observed at 1439 cm -1 theoretically and this mode has IR intensity 35.79, Raman activity 131.12 with a PED 22%. The out-ofplane deformation bands of N-H are expected in the range 650 ¬± 50 cm -1 and the bands observed at 612 cm -1 (DFT) are assigned as Œ≥N-H mode of the title compound. This mode has 73% PED with 60.95 as IR intensity and a low Raman activity less than 10.00. In the present case, the quinoline CC stretching ring modes are observed at 1413 cm -1 in the IR spectrum, 1414 cm -1 in the Raman spectrum, 1413 cm -1 theoretically with high Raman activity and the C-N stretching modes are at 1114 cm -1 in the IR spectrum, 1233, 1106,1082 cm -1 theoretically. Both the modes possess moderate IR intensities. Rajeev et al. reported the quinoline stretching modes at 1610, 1445, 1020 cm -1 (C-C), 1262 cm -1 (C-N) in the IR spectrum, 1609, 1051, 1022 cm -1 (C-C), 1202 cm -1 (C-N) in the Raman spectrum, 1607, 1433, 1045, 1035 cm -1 (C-C), 1270, 1230 cm -1 (C-N) theoretically . The DFT calculations give the C-H stretching modes of the phenyl ringI and phenyl ringII of the title compound at 3128, 3101, 3067 cm -1 and 3151, 3099, 3098, 3061 cm -1 . Similarly, the bands observed at 3132, 3103, 3078 cm -1 (Raman) and 3157, 2990 cm -1 (IR) are assigned as C-HI and C-HII stretching modes of the phenyl rings of parent molecule . The bands observed at 1470, 1372 and 1593, 1505, 1314 cm -1 in IR spectrum, 1477 and 1602, 1503, 1382, 1323 cm -1 in Raman spectrum and at 1618, 1580, 1485, 1369, 1342 and 1609, 1591, 1538,1403,1321 cm -1 theoretically are assigned as phenyl rings stretching modes of the title compound which are expected in the region 1620-1250 cm -1 . In asymmetric trisubstituted benzene, when all the three substituents are heavy, the ring breathing mode appears above 1100 cm -1 . For the tri-substituted phenyl ring PhI, the ring breathing mode is assigned at 1066 cm -1 theoretically with moderate IR intensity and PED 18%.

question: How can pure samples of 3-Re be obtained from a mixture containing both 3-Re and 3-Re'?
answer: Pure samples of 3-Re are obtained by allowing a selective reaction in which only 3-Re reacts with 3-Re' to form 4-Re. The 4-Re is then separated from 3-Re' through fractional crystallisation, and subsequent heating of 4-Re under static vacuum causes CO de-insertion, yielding pure 3-Re.
context: Under more forcing conditions (1 atm., 100 ¬∞C), 3-Cr, 3-Mo, 3-W, 3-Mn, and 3-Co could all be converted to the C4 products 4-Cr, 4-Mo, 4-W, 4-Mn, and 4-Co respectively. These reactions were found to be reversible and at elevated temperatures (100 -150 ¬∞C) under a dinitrogen atmosphere the de-insertion of CO could be observed spectroscopically. Mixtures of 3-Re : 3-Re' reacted selectively to form 4-Re. Only 3-Re was consumed in this reaction suggesting that the strained [6,4] fused ring system is more labile than the [5,5] isomer. 4-Re could be separated from 3-Re' through fractional crystallisation. Subsequent heating of 4-Re under static vacuum to effect CO de-insertion allowed the isolation of pure samples of 3-Re. Solid-State Characterisation of 2-4: The X-ray structure of 2-Mn incorporates a [7,4] ortho-fused ring system.

question: What are the different water cluster data sets used in the work and how are they categorized?
answer: The work uses four water cluster data sets. One set is the benchmark energy and geometry database (BEGDB) neutral water cluster subset. Another is the WATER27 set, which comprises 14 neutral, 5 protonated, 7 deprotonated, and one auto-ionized water cluster. The remaining two sets consist of ion-water clusters expressed as M...(H2O)n, where M is one of Li+, Na+, K+, F‚Äì, Cl‚Äì, or Br‚Äì and n is 1 or 2.
context: Four data sets of water clusters are considered in this work: the benchmark energy and geometry database (BEGDB) neutral water cluster subset; 22 the WATER27 23 set of 14 neutral, 5 protonated, 7 deprotonated, and one auto-ionized water cluster; and two sets of ion-water clusters M...(H 2 O) n , where M = Li + , Na + , K + , F -, Cl -, or Br -, and n = 1, 2.

question: How did changing substituents on the aromatic ring influence the yield of C3-arylbenzothiophene products?
answer: Replacing the anisyl group with a phenyl group produced C3-phenylbenzothiophene in high yield, while using groups such as 4-fluorophenyl, naphthyl, pyrenyl, xylyl, and even the hydroxy group led to the formation of the corresponding products in moderate yields.
context: With the optimal conditions in hand, we investigated the generality of the substrate (Scheme 2). Changing the anisyl group to a phenyl group gave the desired C3phenylbenzothiophene 4b in high yield. 4-Fluorophenyl (3c), naphthyl (3d), pyrenyl (3e) and xylyl (3f) groups could also be derived to C3-arylbenzothiophenes 4c-4f in moderate yields. Benzothiophene with functional groups instead of methoxy groups was also tried, and these reactions proceeded even in the case of ethoxy (3g), pentoxy (3h), and phenoxy (3i) groups. The hydroxy group (3j) also gave the desired C3-arylated compound 4j, albeit in moderate yield.

question: What reagents, catalyst, and reaction conditions were used to synthesize TetraALA?
answer: TetraALA was synthesized using 0.05 mol of Pentaerythritol, 0.21 mol of ALA, and 0.002 mol of SnCl2 as a catalyst, along with 0.02 mol of TEA, 10 ml of acetone, and 4 ml of 1,4-dioxane. question: What was the percentage decrease in carbon monoxide (CO) disparities from 1990 to 2010?
answer: CO disparities decreased by 88%, dropping from 0.40 ppm in 1990 to 0.044 ppm in 2010.
context: The average racial-ethnic exposure disparities also declined from 1990 -2010. The amount of change depends in part on whether one considers absolute or relative disparities. In terms of absolute disparities, the disparities between the most-and least-exposed racial-ethnic groups decreased on average by 69% relative to absolute disparity in 1990 across the five pollutants. The largest change was an 88% decrease for CO disparities (0.40 ppm in 1990, 0.044 ppm in 2010, a 0.35 ppm [i.e., 88%] change) and the smallest change was a 54% decrease for NO2 , 4.6 ppb [2010], a 5.3 ppb [54%] change). question: What are the component amounts and weight percentages used in the printing formulation that employs SUA-1 oligomer to make a 30 g formulation?
answer: The formulation consists of 5.4 g of SR335 (18 wt%), 2.4 g of IBOA (8 wt%), 0.6 g of TPO (2 wt%), and 0.002 g of Sudan III (0.01 wt%) dissolved under bath sonication. Afterwards, 20.1 g of SUA-1 (67 wt%) is added, followed by 1.5 g of HFS particles (5 wt%).
context: For the experiments conducted, 30 g of SUA printing formulation was typically prepared. Using SUA-1 oligomer, the ink was formulated by mixing 5.4 g of SR335 (18 wt%) and 2.4 g of IBOA (8 wt%). Next, 0.6 g of TPO (2 wt%) was added. To obtain a high resolution, 0.002 g of Sudan III (0.01 wt%) was added to some formulations. The mixture was dissolved under bath sonication (Elmasonic P 30H) at 60‚ÑÉ with 100% power at 80 kHz for 20 minutes. Afterward, 20.1 g of SUA-1 (67 wt%) was added under manual mixing. Finally, 1.5 g of HFS particles (5 wt%) were added under additional manual mixing. A second printing composition with enhanced mechanical properties was made by using SUA-2 oligomer. In this mixture, SR335 and XRLH-3-142 were mixed at a 1:1 weight ratio. First, 13.950 g of SR335 (46.5 wt%), 0.600 g of TPO (2 wt%), and 0.002 g of Sudan III (0.01 wt%) were mixed and dissolved under bath sonication using the above parameters. Afterward, 13.950 g of SUA-2 (46.5 wt%) was added under manual mixing. Subsequently, 1.5 g of HFS particles (5 wt%) were added under 5 min mechanical mixing using DISPERMAT CV (Reichshof). Both ink compositions underwent 2 min defoaming process using a Planetary Centrifugal Mixer (Thinky).

question: How does the incorporation of PPy affect the compressive stress retention of the sensors after multiple compression-decompression cycles?
answer: Incorporating PPy significantly improves the compressive stress retention of the sensors. Without PPy, the sensor‚Äôs compressive stress drops to 52% of its initial value after 2000 cycles. With PPy, the retention increases to 81.5%, 93.1%, and 91.2% for different PPy loadings after 2000 cycles, and specifically, one formulation retains 81.8% after 5000 cycles, demonstrating excellent mechanical stability.
context: To further investigate the mechanical stability of the sensors, the compressiondecompression cycling tests with 40% strain were carried out (Figure ). As expected, the introduction of PPy can enhance the mechanical performance of the sensors. For S-PUF/V2O5, the compressive stress shows an obvious decrease (52% of the initial value at 40% strain) after compression-decompression for 2000 cycles. The compressive stresses at 40% strain for S-PUF/V2O5/PPy-10, S-PUF/V2O5/PPy-15, and S-PUF/V2O5/PPy-33 are 81.5%, 93.1%, and 91.2% of the initial values after 2000 compression-decompression cycles. For S-PUF/V2O5/PPy-15, the compressive stress at 40% strain retains 81.8% of its initial value after 5000 compression-decompression cycles, indicating an excellent mechanical stability.

question: What confluency percentages were used for electrophysiology and imaging, and what coating did the coverslips have?

question: What were the specific column and gradient conditions used to separate the reaction mixture?

context: The scission products were confirmed using a quadrupole-time-of-flight mass spectrometer (Q-TOF, X500R, Sciex (MA, USA)) connected with ultra-highperformance liquid chromatography (UHPLC, Exion, Sciex). After the reaction, the reaction mixture was then separated using a Thermo Scientific Hypersil Gold column (2.1 √ó 100 mm, 1.9 ¬µm) by gradient elution using 0.1% formic acid in water (solvent A) and CH3CN (solvent B) at a flow rate of 0.4 mL/min. The gradient program was as follows: initial B10%, 2 min B100%, 2.1 min B10%, and 4 min B10%. Finally, the eluate was introduced into the Q-TOF mass spectrometer and analyzed using information-dependent analysis mode.

question: What are the detailed parameters used in the Raman spectroscopy measurements?
answer: Raman spectroscopy was performed with an Andor Kymera 328i Raman spectrometer connected to a Nikon air objective featuring 60x magnification and a 0.7 numerical aperture. The analysis used an excitation wavelength of 532 nm with an output power of 10 mW, a diffraction grating of 600 lines per millimeter blazed at 500 nm, and a thermoelectrically cooled EMCCD camera (Andor Newton DU970P-BVF) maintained at -80 ¬∞C.
context: Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra were obtained via a VERTEX spectrometer (Bruker, USA) equipped with an attenuated total reflection (ATR) measuring cell. Raman spectroscopy was conducted using an Andor Kymera 328i Raman spectrometer connected to a Nikon air objective (60x, 0.7 N.A), using an excitation wavelength of 532 nm and an output power of 10 mW. The spectrometer was outfitted with a diffraction grating of 600 l/mm (blazed at 500 nm) and a thermoelectrically cooled (-80 ÀöC) EMCCD camera (Andor Newton DU970P-BVF). Xray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analyses were conducted with an Axis Ultra DLD instrument (Kratos Analytical, UK) equipped with a monochromatic Al KŒ± X-ray radiation source (hŒΩ = 1486.6 eV). The base pressure was better than 1.1√ó10 Torr (1.5√ó10 -7 Pa), while the anode was operated at 150 W (10 mA, 15 kV). The sample area analysed was 0.3√ó0.7 mm 2 .

question: What instrument is used for measuring the mass of the electrodes and what is its accuracy?
answer: A microbalance (Sartorius, Germany) is used with an accuracy of ¬± 0.01 mg.
context: Liquid phase exfoliation and other suspension processing was performed using an ultrasonication bath (Elmasonic P120H, 330 W effective power) and an ultrasonic probe processor (Fisherbrand ultrasonic Q500 , 500 W). Suspensions were cooled using a refrigerated circulation thermostat (CORIO CD-600F, Julabo, USA). Centrifugation was performed using a centrifuge (Thermo Scientific Heraeus Multifuge X1R) equipped with a TX-400 rotor (16.8 cm radius) and a FIBERLite F15-8x 50cy rotor (10.4 cm radius). The concentration of suspensions was determined using a UV-Vis-IR spectrometer (Cary 5000, Agilent Technologies). The mass of the electrodes was measured using a microbalance (Sartorius, Germany) with a ¬± 0.01 mg accuracy. Electrochemical measurements were performed in a VMP3 (Bio-Logic) potentiostat.

question: What purification method and conditions were employed to obtain the final product after the extraction process?
answer: The crude product was purified using GRACE chromatography on 12 g of silica (REVELERIS) with a gradient of 50% to 100% ethyl acetate in pet ether.
context: To a solution of 2-(2,6-dioxopiperidin-3-yl)-4-fluoroisoindoline-1,3-dione (1 equiv.) in DMSO (10 v), amine (1.2 equiv.) and DIPEA (3 equiv.) in a sealed tube were added at room temperature. The reaction mixture was stirred at 100 ¬∞C for 1 h and monitored by TLC. After completion, the reaction mixture was poured into water (5 mL) and extracted with ethyl acetate (3 √ó 10 mL). The combined organic layers were washed with brine (2 √ó 10 mL), dried over sodium sulfate, and evaporated to yield the crude product. The crude product was purified by GRACE chromatography using 12 g of silica (REVELERIS) with a gradient of 50-100% ethyl acetate in pet ether to afford the final product.

question: What virus in the protocol has the same viral structure and genome as SARS-CoV-2, even though it primarily infects pigs?
answer: Porcine transmissible gastroenteritis virus (TGEV) is categorized in the Coronaviridae family, making it an enveloped (+)ssRNA virus that matches the structure and genome of SARS-CoV-2.
context: To fulfill the FDA requirements for viral inactivation, we used four different viruses with different virus genomes and capsid structures that included: dsDNA virus (respiratory human adenovirus type 2, single-layered non-enveloped virion), dsRNA virus (rotavirus OSU, triple-layered nonenveloped virion), 7 kb ssRNA virus (Tulane virus, surrogate for human norovirus, single-layered non-enveloped virion), 9 and 28.5 kb ssRNA virus (porcine transmissible gastroenteritis virus (TGEV), 10 single-layered enveloped virion). TGEV is categorized into Coronaviridae, the same family as SARS-CoV-2. It has the same viral structure and genome as SARS-CoV-2 (enveloped and (+)ssRNA virus), but it primarily infects pigs. 11 Tulane virus, rotavirus (OSU strain), and human adenovirus type 2 belong to Caliciviridae, Reoviridae, and Adenoviridae, respectively. Details of the virus preparation methods are described in Text S1 and Table .

question: What incubation steps were performed on the brain slices after cutting them with the vibratome?
answer: After cutting, the 300 ¬µm thick brain slices were transferred to oxygenated artificial cerebrospinal fluid (ACSF) at 37¬∞C for 15 minutes, then incubated in oxygenated ACSF at room temperature for 30 minutes before imaging.
context: Preparation of acute murine brain slices. All animal protocols were approved by the Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee of New York State Psychiatric Institute/Columbia University Irving Medical Center. All protocols followed the Guide for the Care and Use of Laboratory Animals by National Institute of Health (NIH). All animals used were C57BL/6, wild-type mice from The Jackson Laboratory (Bar Harbor, ME), included both males and females, and sacrificed between 8 to 10 weeks. Coronal slices (300 ¬µm thick) were cut by a Leica VT1200 vibratome in ice-cold slicing solution (in mM: 194 sucrose, 30 NaCl, 4.5 KCl, 26 NaHCO3, 1 MgCl2ÔÉó6H2O, 1.2 NaH2PO4, 10 D-Glucose), and transferred to oxygenated (95% O2 + 5% CO2), 37 ÔÇ∞C artificial cerebrospinal fluid (ACSF, in mM: 124 NaCl, 4.5 KCl, 26 NaHCO3, 1 MgCl2ÔÉó6H2O, 2 CaCl2, 1.2 NaH2PO4, 10 D-Glucose; pH = 7.30; 295 mOsm) in a slice chamber for 15 min. Slices were then incubated in oxygenated ACSF at room temperature for 30 min before imaging.

question: What is the layer structure and the functions of the transport layers in the n-i-p solar cell device?
answer: The solar cell device is structured with an FTO substrate, a compact TiO2 layer which acts as the electron-transport layer, an absorber layer (either CsMAFA-Sb or CsMAFA-Sb:Bi), a P3HT layer serving as the hole-transport layer, and a gold electrode.
context: To study the effect of cation engineering, i.e., Bi incorporation into CsMAFA-Sb on its solar cell performance, we fabricated planar n-i-p devices using CsMAFA-Sb or CsMAFA-Sb:Bi as light-harvesting layers. The device structure was FTO|c-TiO2|absorber (CsMAFA-Sb or CsMAFA-Sb:Bi)|P3HT|Au, where compact TiO2 (c-TiO2) and poly(3-hexylthiophene-2,5diyl) (P3HT) were selected as the electron-transport layer (ETL) and hole-transport layer (HTL), respectively. The details of the solar cell fabrication are provided in the Methods section.

question: Which combination of catalysts achieved the highest product yield with superior branch selectivity?
answer: The use of Cp*TiMe3 with AlMe3, each at 5 mol%, reached over 99% yield with a branch selectivity ratio of 98:2.
context: In combination with Cp*TiMe3, various trialkylaluminum and triphenylaluminum worked as effective cocatalysts with high branch-selectivity for the hydroaminoalkylation (Table , entries 2-5). In contrast, the use of AlClEt2 resulted in significantly lower catalytic activities (Table , entry 8) and the lack of Al-additives gave the products in nearly stoichiometric amounts with respect to catalyst loading (12%) with low branch-selectivity (3aa:4aa = 64:34) (entry 9). B(C6F5)3 was a typical cocatalyst for generating cationic alkyl group 4 metal species, giving the product in moderate yield with a low branch-selectivity (56% yield, 3aa:4aa = 68:32), though the catalytic activity was observed at 30 ¬∞C (entry 10). Finally, the combination of Cp*TiMe3 and AlMe3 in both 5 mol% produced the highest yield (>99%) and high branchselectivity (3aa:4aa = 98:2) (Table , entry 11, see also Table for the result with other alkylaluminium cocatalysts). question: What improvements in hydroxylation activity are observed with the [BS-Fe-bTAML]-‚Ä¢ hCAII TS complex compared to its free cofactor and the wild-type enzyme?
answer: The complex shows a twofold improvement in activity over the free cofactor and a 1.8-fold improvement compared to the wild-type enzyme.
context: The activity of [BS-Fe-bTAML] -‚Ä¢ hCAII TS was evaluated for the hydroxylation of the ethylbenzene derivative 1. Gratifyingly, the activity of [BS-Fe-bTAML] -‚Ä¢ hCAII TS was significantly improved compared to both the free cofactor and the wild-type ArHase (two fold for the free cofactor and 1.8 fold for [BS-Fe-bTAML] -‚Ä¢ hCAII WT , Table , entry 3). Such activity enhancement was not observed with the previously-reported biotinylated-[Fe-TAML] ‚Ä¢ streptavidin system. The affinity of [BS-Fe-bTAML] -for hCAII TS was comparable to hCAII WT (52 ¬± 8 nM, Table , Figure ). Differential scanning fluorimetry confirmed that the melting temperature of hCAII TS increased by 14 ¬∫C compared to hCAII WT (i.e. 71 ¬∫C and 57 ¬∫C, Figure ). Accordingly, we selected hCAII TS for the remainder of this study. Next, we investigated whether the hydroxylation proceeds in cell lysates using E. coli BL21(DE3) cells harboring a plasmid encoding hCAII TS . Gratifyingly, upon cell lysis and thermal treatment at 55 ¬∫C for 30 minutes, followed by addition of [BS-Fe-bTAML] -, the ethylbenzene derivative 1 (2500 equiv. vs. [BS-Fe-bTAML] -) and H2O2 (5000 equiv. vs. [BS-Fe-bTAML] -), we were delighted to detect the alcohol 2 and the ketone 3, albeit in significantly lower yield compared to the purified ArHase (17 vs. 2140 TTON, Figure ). Upon increasing the number of equivalents of H2O2 (50,000 equiv. vs. [BS-Fe-bTAML] -), yields (1929 TTON) comparable to those of the purified ArHase were obtained. We surmise that the background activity resulting from catalysis with the free cofactor in the empty plasmid cell-lysates (1020 TTON, corresponding to ca. 53% of the TTON for ethylbenzene 1) should remain constant during the directed evolution campaign, thus enabling to detect improved ArHase activity resulting from [BS-Fe-bTAML] -‚Ä¢ hCAII TS mutants. Accordingly, we set out to evolve the ArHase performance using heat-treated E. coli cell lysates.

question: How does the protonation state of His198 differ between the studied protein and AmpC P99?
answer: In the studied protein, His198 is protonated on ND1, while in AmpC P99 it is protonated on NE2.
context: CpHMD simulations were carried out with the Amber20 program employing the modified Amber ff10 force field and appropriate PBRadii set (mbondi2). The protonation states (including histidine tautomers) of the other residues were estimated using the H++ web server. His198 was protonated on ND1, while His186, His193 and His313 were protonated on NE2. His39 and His210 are protonated on both ND1 and NE2. The corresponding histidines in AmpC P99 are protonated accordingly: His39 (ND1), His186 (both ND1 and NE2), His198 (NE2) and His313 (ND1). All other titratable residues are in their standard protonation states.
